DIV1.P: ORIGINAL LETTERS Written to the Earl of ARLINGTON BY Sir RICHARD BULSTRODE, ENVOY at the COURT of Brussels from King CHARLES II, &c. CONTAINING The most remarkable Transactions, both in Court and Camp, during his MINISTRY, particularly the Famous Battel of Seneff, between the Prince of Orange and the Prince of Conde.
WITH A PREFACE, Giving an Account of the AUTHOR's LIFE and FAMILY.
LONDON: Printed for R. Sare at Gray's-Inn-Gate in Holborn, and sold by J. Morphew near Stationers Hall. 1712.

DIV1.HEAD: To the RIGHT HONOURABLE, GEORGE EARL of CARDIGAN, &c.
DIV1.P:
ENcourag'd by Your Lordship's Permission, I presume to in∣scribe Your Name to the fol∣lowing Sheets. The Author of them, Sir Richard Bulstrode, was descended from a very ancient Family, to an Heiress of which one of Your Lord∣ship's Ancestors was marry'd, and the Bulstrodes now living have Reason to
acknowledge it, as they do, to be no small Honour to them, that the Earl of CARDIGAN quarters their Arms.

My Lord, it would be next to im∣pertinent to tell the World what they sufficiently know already; that Your Lordship derives Your Descent from a Race truly Noble, as well for the Length of their Duration, as for the Honours our Kings, in Reward of their Services, at several times conferr'd on them. They have for many Ages been Great in Title, and Good a∣bove Greatness. Their Inclinations and Endeavours were the general Good of Mankind: They delighted in obliging others, and were pleas'd to see them pleas'd with their Bounty: They have been renown'd for relie∣ving Merit in Want, and for succou∣ring Vertue in Distress.

These and many other Vertues seem an Inheritance in Your Lordship, and deriv'd from Your Ancestors with Your Blood. My Lord, I cannot be
guilty of Flattery if I would, nor needs there any Trial of Skill to shew how I can praise: Nature has done it to my Hands, and represented fai∣rer Ideas than I can describe: She has endow'd You with all her Blessings; with a Gracefulness of Person, Ex∣cellence of Understanding, Largeness of Heart, with Integrity, and Justice of Principles, with Humanity, Affa∣bility, and many other Qualities, far above my Description, and that would secure me from the Censure of Flat∣tery, even though I should launch into a Panegyrick.

Fortune too, my Lord, in your Regard, has been more wise than u∣sual: for she frequently honours and enriches others to her own Disgrace; but she participates in the Praise, and commends her own Wisdom, in what she has bestow'd on Your Lordship: Wealth is of some Value in Your Hands; and so good an Use is made of Your great Estate, that even Envy
does not wish it less. Be pleas'd, my Lord, to give me leave to speak to You in the Words of Horace, which are so justly applicable to Your Lordship.

Q.L: Non Tu Corpus eras sine Pectore: Dii Tibi Formam,
Dii Tibi Divitias dederunt, artemque fruendi.

DIV1.P: But I come to beg Protection, not to give Praise: And my greatest Am∣bition, which I beseech Your Lord∣ship to pardon, is, to subscribe my self, with the most profound Sub∣mission and Respect,

CLOSER.SIGNED: Your Lordship's most humble, and most obedient Servant, E. BYSSHE.

DIV1.HEAD: THE PREFACE.
DIV1.P:
SINCE most of the Nations of Europe have been engag'd in Wars, how dif∣ficult it has been to come at the true Knowledge of publick Occurrences, is evident from the different Relations, that have been given us of them; one would al∣most think, that we had not only engag'd in Leagues and Confederacies against one ano∣ther, but that all of us in general were en∣ter'd into one Grand Alliance, and had una∣nimously declar'd War against the Truth of History: So artfully disingenuous have we shewn our selves in extenuating, disguising, and concealing our own Losses, and in mag∣nifying, misrepresenting, and publishing those of the adverse Party. Had the Common Ene∣my been seven Years ago brought to that low Condition, to which it was then industriously given out that he was, when it was even
made a Mark of Disaffection to suggest or believe the contrary, we should not at this Day be thus divided in Opinion concerning a safe and honourable Peace, nor perplex'd with the Uncertainty, whether it were best to en∣ter into a Treaty upon the Preliminaries now offer'd us.

But this Misrepresentation of the true Po∣sture of Affairs may be so far indulg'd and excus'd, in that it may in some Measure pro∣ceed from a political Reason of State; eve∣ry Potentate concern'd being desirous, nay, deeming it of absolute Necessity, to keep up the almost dejected Hearts of their dispirited Vassals, and to inspire them with fresh Cou∣rage, by giving them every Year repeated Hopes of a speedy End of this bloody, expen∣sive, and consequently destructive War. This, perhaps, may have been the chief Reason, for I can discover no other, that may have induc'd some of the Princes, who are now engag'd in Arms, to connive at the great number of scurrilous lying Pamphlets, as well News-Papers as others, and to permit them to be publish'd and spread abroad through∣out all their Dominions, impunibly and with∣out the least Controul. I have observ'd, and any one who has read the Relations they have given us, with the least, that is, with more Attention than they deserve, may have done so too, that all the Actions, which, du∣ring
the whole Course of this War, have hap∣pen'd between the Armies abroad, have been related in the same manner, nay, almost in the same Words. So miserably are these pi∣tiful. Scriblers put to their shifts for new Words, and a fresh manner of Lying, to fill up the length of their Papers. With them, the beaten Party is very modest if he lay not Claim to the Victory, or at least to a drawn Battel; for, excepting in the Battels of Landen and Turin, where, the Advantages were so great as to strike the Eyes of the most Incredulous, and to leave scarce any Room for Disguise, he has always kill'd as many of the Enemies, as he lost of his own Troops; or else he came off with little Loss, and made his Retreat in good Order: Be∣sides, were his Loss ever so great, he has daily found it to be less than it was at first reported, by reason of the great Number of Soldiers that had been given over for kill'd or taken, but were continually coming back to the Camp. On the other Hand, he, who got the better of the Day, has never failed to magnify his Advantages proportionably: He has routed his Enemies to that Degree, that, as we were told, we had reason to believe, they would never be able to recruit their Armies, nor ever more shew their Fa∣ces in a Camp. To this wretched Plight have our Enemies been reduc'd at the end of
several Campaigns; and yet the succeeding Spring has beheld this Hydra, with two Heads sprouted out in the room of one that was cut off; and we have met in the Field a more terrible Monster to encounter. Their Narratives of other Matters of Fact are of the like Stamp, and I appeal to any impar∣tial Person what Credit is to be given to them. The Governments themselves have, no doubt, had more authentick Advices; tho', as I hinted before, they have, for certain Rea∣sons of State, suffer'd these Impositions to be Post-Man'd and Post-Boy'd upon the Pub∣lick. And with this Encouragement these im∣perfect and lying Relations are bungled and patch'd up together, and pass currently with some, for what they falsely and scandalously call themselves, The Annals of the Reigns of our Sovereigns. But these impudent News-Writers stop not here, for they presume to intrude into the Councils and Cabinets of Princes, and give the World an Account of what passes, and is resolv'd on there, as well in regard to our own Affairs as those of Fo∣reign States. An Insolence without Exam∣ple, 'till of late Days.

Now, that the following Letters may not be thought to deserve as little Credit as the Relations of which I have been speaking; and that too the rather, because they treat of Affairs of the same Nature; it will be
necessary to premise, in a few Words, what they contain, and by whom, as well as to whom they were written.

First then, They were written in the Year 1674, all of them, except two to Sir Robert Southwell, to the Earl of Arlington, then Secretary of State, by Sir Richard Bulstrode, who then resided at the Court of Bruxelles, as Agent for King Charles the Second, and they contain the History of all the remarkable Transactions in the Low Countries, in Al∣satia and Burgundy, during the Campaign of that Year, when the Imperialists, Spaniards, and Dutch were engag'd in War against the French. This was that Campaign in which was fought the memorable Battel of Seneff, between the Confederates under the Command of the Prince of Orange, and the Army of France commanded by the Prince of Conde; which I chuse particularly to mention, that the Reader may take notice, that it is no new Custom for both Sides to ascribe to themselves the Honour of the Victory; for they did so even then, and made Rejoicings too every where for it. These Letters evidently shew to which side it inclin'd, and whoever reads them will, I believe, be of Opinion, that this Relation of that Battel is the only impartial and true Account of it, that is yet any where extant. We may affirm the same too of the other Oc∣currences that are here related; as of the
Account of the Battel that happen'd the same Year on the Banks of the Neckar, between the Imperialists and the French; the first of them commanded by the Duke of Lorrain, the last by Marshal Turenne; and also of the several Sieges, and other military Exploits of that Campaign; together, with all the secret Cabals and Intrigues of the then Court of Brussels; all which is the Subject of these Letters, which are written with such an Air of Candour, Integrity, and Impartiality, as plainly evinces them to be authentick, and would in a manner command our Belief, e∣ven tho' we were ignorant of the Author.

As for the Style in which they are written, it is purely Epistolatory, such as one Gentleman writes off-hand to another, and such as best becomes Composures of this Nature, when they are written as they ought to be: For they require not elaborate Elegancies, but should have only a native Clearness and Bre∣vity; they should not consist of fulsome Com∣pliments, but should have a respectful kind of Plainness and Familiarity, to affect only the Humour of those to whom they are inten∣ded. In Letters like these, the Souls of Men should appear undress'd, and in a negli∣gent Habit, not trick'd up with artful Gaw∣deries, or the study'd Ornaments of Rheto∣rick; and such I dare affirm the following Letters to be.

As for the submissive Expressions the Au∣thor uses in the Conclusion of his Letters, as that of Laying my self low at your Lord∣ship's Feet with all Zeal and Humility, it was a Compliment us'd by Gentlemen of the best Quality, one towards another in those Times, tho' now laid aside; nay, I cou'd give Instances of Subscriptions more humble and abject in the Letters of several Envoys, &c. some of whom are now living, than are to be found any where in our Author.

It will be necessary, in the next Place, to give some Account of our Author, that may serve rather for the Information of his Rea∣ders, than for the Increase of his Fame, which stands not in need of any such Helps to establish it.

He was descended of the ancient Family of Bulstrode, in the County of Bucks. Their first Name was Shobbington, and came to be chang'd into that of Bulstrode by this re∣markable Adventure, which I have learn'd from some of the Family themselves. The Story, as they report it, runs thus. When William the Conqueror had subdu'd this Kingdom to his Obedience, he granted the E∣state of the Shobbington's, whose capital Seat, now likewise call'd Bulstrode's, was situa∣ted in the middle of a fine Park, by Gerard's Cross near Beaconsfield, and had been in their Family for several Ages before, to a certain
Norman Lord who came over with him: of which the Shobbington, who then enjoy'd it, having notice, he resolv'd rather to die upon the Spot, than tamely to suffer himself to be turn'd out of Possession of that Inheritance, which had descended to him from his Ance∣stors. In this Resolution he arm'd his Ser∣vants and his Tenants, whose Number was very considerable. Upon which the Norman Lord, who had Advice of it, obtain'd of the King a thousand of his Regular Troops, to help him to take Possession of the Estate by Force: whereupon Shobbington apply'd him∣self to his Relations and Neighbours to assist him; and the two ancient Families of the Hambden's and Penn's took Arms, together with their Servants and Tenants, and came to his Relief. When they were all joyn'd, they cast up Works, whose Remains appear to this Day, in the Place where the Park now is; and the Norman Lord, with his Forces, came and encamp'd before their Intrench∣ments. Now whether it were that they wanted Horses, or not, is uncertain; but the Story goes, That having manag'd a par∣cel of Bulls, they mounted them, and sally∣ing out of their Intrenchments in the Night, surpriz'd the Normans in their Camp, kill'd many of them, and put the rest to Flight. The King having Intelligence of it, and not thinking it safe for him, while his
Power was yet new and unsettled, to drive a daring and obstinate People to Despair, sent a Herald to them, to know what they would have, and promis'd Shobbington a Safe Con∣duct, if he would come to Court; which Shobbington accordingly did, riding thither upon a Bull. Being introduc'd into the Royal Presence, the King ask'd him his Demands, and why he alone dar'd to resist, when the rest of the Kingdom had submitted to his Go∣vernment, and own'd him for their Sove∣reign? Shobbington answer'd, That he and his Ancestors had long been Inhabitants of this Island, and had enjoy'd that Estate for many Years; that if the King would permit him to keep it, he would become his Subject, and be faithful to him, as he had been to his Predecessors. The King gave him his Royal Word, that he would, and immediately grant∣ed him the free Enjoyment of his Estate: Upon which the Family was from thence call'd Shobbington, aliàs Bulstrode; but in Process of Time the first Name was discon∣tinued, and that of Bulstrode only has re∣main'd to them. The Truth of this Story is not only confirm'd by long Tradition in the Family, but by several Memoirs which they have still remaining, and by the Ruins of the Works, that are to this Day seen in the Park of Bulstrodes, as well as by the Crest of their Arms, which is, a Bull's Head caboss'd
Gules, attir'd Or, between two Wings Sa∣ble. The Estate of Bulstrodes remain'd in, and continu'd to be, the Seat of the Family, till about forty Years ago, when it was first sold, and has since pass'd through several Hands. The Earl of Portland now enjoys it by Inheritance from his Father, who was the last that purchas'd it. But to return to our Author.

Sir Richard Bulstrode was born in the Year of our Lord 1610. He was the el∣dest Son of Edward Bulstrode of the Inner-Temple, Esq a very learned Lawyer, as ap∣pears by his Book of Reports, a Work in great Esteem to this Day. The first Years of his Youth were, as usual, spent at School; whence he was remov'd to Pembroke Hall in Cambridge, where he continu'd his Stu∣dies for several Years. In 1633, being then about twenty three Years of Age, he writ a Poem on the Birth of the Duke of York, which is still extant in the Collections of the Poems of that University. From Cambridge he went to the Inns of Court, and was en∣ter'd in the same House with his Father. He became a Barrister at Law, and pra∣ctis'd as such till the breaking out of the Civil Wars, when his Affection to the King's Cause made him quit the Gown, and drew him to the Army; where he behav'd himself with so much Prudence, Bravery, and Con∣duct,
that King Charles the 1st soon made him Adjutant General of his Army, and af∣terwards Quarter-Master General; in which Post he continued to serve till the disbanding of the King's Forces at Truro.

When that unnatural Rebellion was ended, and King Charles the 2d happily restor'd, our Author after some Years Atten∣dance on the Court, and being now above sixty years of Age, was at length, in Reward of his long and faithful Services to the Crown, sent to reside at Brussels in Quality of Agent for that Prince; and from thence he writ these Letters, with which we here present the Publick.

In the Year 1675. he return'd to England to give the King an Account of his Negotia∣tions, with which his Majesty was so well sa∣tisfy'd, that he conferr'd on him the Honour of Knighthood, and in a few Months sent him back again to that Court with the Cha∣racter of his Resident there. This is confirm'd by the Credential Letters, which the King writ in his behalf to the Duke de Villa Her∣mosa, then Governour General of the Spanish Netherlands, and which are as follows.

DIV3.HEAD: Illustrissimo & Ex∣cellentissimo Do∣mino Carolo de A∣rogana, Duci de Villa Hermosa, Comiti de Luna, Serenissimi Hispa∣niarum Regis, in Provinciis Belgicis Burgundia{que} Pre∣fecto Generali, A∣mico Nostro Cha∣rissimo.
DIV3.P:
CArolus Secundus, Dei Gratiâ Mag∣nae Britanniae, Fran∣ciae & Hiberniae Rex, Fidei Defensor, &c. Illustrissimo & Ex∣cellentissimo Domino, Carolo de Arogana, Duci de Villa Her∣mosa, Comii de Lu∣na, Serenissimi Hispa∣niarum Regis, in Pro∣vinciis Belgiis Bur∣gundia{que} Praefco Ge∣nerali, Ai notro
Charissimo salutem. Illustrissime & Ex∣cellentissime Domine, Amice Charissime; Dilectus & Fidelis Subditus noster Ri∣chardus Bulstrode, quem anteà Chara∣ctere Agentis nostri indutum Bruxellis com∣morari mandavimus, nuper ad Nos re∣diit, inter aliâ quae Nobis exposuit, de Excellentiae Vestrae af∣fectu erga Nos & erga Subditos Nostros benevolentiâ amplissi∣mè locutus. Eun∣dem Richardum Bul∣strode jam Bruxellos remittimus, Residen∣tis Nostri Titulo, & Equitis Aurati digni∣tate Auctum; ut sci∣at Excellentia Ve∣stra eum Nobis in priori Ministerio suo placuisse: Ne{que} Ex∣cellentiae Vestrae dis∣plitisse credimus, ex
Literis quas Ipsa duo∣decimo die Decembris novissimè elapsi nobis per eum rescripsit. A Nobis in Mandatis habet, Excellentiam Vestram summo (quo fas est) honore pro∣sequi, & quamdiu in illis Provinciis hae∣serit, non magis No∣stris & Nostrorum Rebus, quàm Amici∣tiae, quae Nobis cum Serenissimo Rege Ca∣tholico intercedit, se∣dulo inservirè. Qua∣re non dubitabimus quin Excellentia Ve∣stra praedictum Re∣sidentem Nostrum be∣nignè acceptura st, ei∣dem{que} in omnibus, quae Nomine Nostro protu∣lerit, fidem habitura, de caetris Excellen∣tium Vesram Do∣mini O. Max. Tute∣lae ex men∣da. Da in Pal∣ltio Nostro de White∣hall
26 die Janua∣rii 1675/6.

CLOSER.SIGNED: Excellentiae Vestrae Bonus Amicus, CAROLUS R.

DIV3.HEAD: To the most Illustrious and most Excellent Lord, Charles de Arogana, Duke de Villa Hermosa, Count de Luna, Go∣vernour General, for the most Serene King of Spain, in the Provinces of the Netherlands and Burgundy, Our most Dear Friend.
DIV3.P:
CHarles the Se∣cond, by the Grace of God King of Great Britain, France and Ireland, Defen∣der of the Faith, &c. To the most Illustri∣ous and most Excel∣lent Lord, Charles de Arogana, Duke de Vil∣la Hermosa, Count de Luna, Governour General, from the Part of the most Se∣rene King of Spain,
of the Provinces of the Netherlands and of Burgundy, Our most Dear Friend, Greeting. Most Illu∣strious and most Ex∣cellent Lord, most Dear Friend; Our Beloved and Faithful Subject Richard Bul∣strode, whom We sent formerly to reside at Brussels with the Cha∣racter of Our Agent, return'd lately to Us: Among other Things of which he has in∣form'd Us, he has spoken at large of your Excellency's Af∣fection towards Us, and of your good Will to our Subjects. We now send back the same Richard Bul∣strode to Brussels in Quality of Our Resi∣dent, having like∣wise conferr'd on him the Honour of Knighthood, that
your Excellency may know, that We are well satisfy'd with him, in the Discharge of his former Mini∣stry: Nor do We be∣lieve that he has been displeasing to your Excellency, by the Letters you writ to Us, of the 12th of December last past, which We receiv'd by his Hands. He has Instructions from Us to pay all due Re∣spect to your Excel∣lency, and as long as he continues in those Provinces, to be no less diligent in cul∣tivating the Friend∣ship there is between Us and the most Se∣rene Catholick King, than in taking Care of Our and Our Subjects Affairs. Wherefore We doubt not but your Excellency will kindly receive Our
said Resident, and give Credit to him in all Things he shall make known to you in Our Name. And so We heartily com∣mend your Excellen∣cy to the Protection of the Almighty. Gi∣ven at our Court at Whitehall the 28th day of January, 1675/6.

CLOSER.SIGNED: Your Excellency's Good Friend, CHARLES R.

DIV1.P:
Sir Richard Bulstrode continu'd Resident at Brussels till the Death of King Charles the 2d, when his Successor King James the 2d conferr'd on him a yet higher Honour, and made him his Envoy at the same Court, where he serv'd the Crown in that Ministry, till his unfortunate Master was forc'd to retire into France: whither his faithful Envoy soon follow'd him, and ended his Days at the Court of St. Germans, Octob. 3. N. S.
being a hundred and one Years old and two Months.

He was twice marry'd: His first Wife was Daughter of Edward Dineley of Charl∣ton, near Evesham, in the County of Worce∣ster, Esq, and Sister to Sir Edward Dineley lately deceas'd: By her he had two Sons, who are both living. Whitlock Bulstrode, Esq the youngest of them, a Barrister at Law, is now one of the Commissioners of Excise. And this honourable Gentleman gives me leave to assure the Publick, that he has seen the Ori∣ginals of these Letters, and knows them to be his Father Sir Richard Bulstrode's own Hand-writing: which ought to be Satisfa∣ction enough to the World that they are genu∣ine, and render it needless to give any Ac∣count how we came by them.

His second Wife was Daughter of M. Stam∣ford, who was Envoy to the Court of Eng∣land from the Duke of Newbourg, now Ele∣ctor Palatine of the Rhine. By her he has left behind him three Sons and four Daugh∣ters, several of whom are under twenty years of Age; but his eldest Son now living, whom he had by his former Wife, is Sixty one and upwards.

He enjoy'd a wonderful Firmness of Mind and Strength of Body to the very last. After he was fourscore Years old and more, he would often walk twelve Miles in a Morning,
and study as many Hours in a Day. And tho' it may seem a Paradox, old tho' he was, it cannot strictly be said, that he dy'd of old Age: The Disease that carry'd him off, was a Stoppage at his Stomach, caus'd by an In∣digestion: Nevertheless had proper Remedies been apply'd, he might, in all probability, have worn out several Years longer: But his Physician, who understood his Constitution, being out of the way, those that were sent for to his Relief, durst not, by reason of his Age, give him a Vomit; the want of which, 'tis thought, hasten'd his End.

He was accomplsh'd with all manner of Abilities for the greatest Business: He per∣fectly understood the Interests of Princes, and the Arts and Intriegues of Courts, and often transacted Affairs of the utmost Importance: In all which he ever behav'd himself with in∣defatigable Integrity, and unsuspected Secrecy. And certainly his Conduct must have been ve∣ry unblameable, which had been try'd in Bu∣siness of the highest Consequence, and pra∣ctis'd in the hazardous Secrets of Courts and Cabinets, and yet nothing disgraceful was ever alledg'd against it.

He was throughly acquainted with the an∣cient and the modern Languages, and had been very conversant in the Lecture of the best Authors; which he not only retain'd in
his Memory, but had digested likewise in his Judgment. With these Advantages he left behind him several Treatises of his own com∣posing; as the Lives of his three Masters, King Charles the 1st, King Charles the 2d, and King James the 2d, and Essays on seve∣ral Subjects; with all which we hope to oblige the Publick in a short time; none of them having yet seen the Light, except the Life of King James the 2d, which has been lately printed at Rome. His Essays are ve∣ry much commended by judicious Persons to whom he had shewn them in his Life-time: He design'd them for the Press, and we ex∣pect that they will e'er long be transmitted hither for that purpose.

When he was above eighty Years of Age he compos'd in Latin Verse 185, as well Ele∣gies as Epigrams, all of them on divine Sub∣jects. Those likewise he intended to be prin∣ted, and some time before his Death, sent them over to his Son, Whitlock Bulstrode, Esq for that purpose: But this worthy Gentleman, reflecting with good Reason, that a Book of Divine Poems would perhaps agree but ill with the Temper of the present Age, which seems to delight more in War, than in Piety, has hitherto kept them to himself, and reserves them for a more favourable Opportu∣nity. However to give the World a Taste of
them, as well as of his Essays, we have here, till they are publish'd together in one Volume, subjoin'd some of those Poems, together with a Letter, which, a few Years ago, he writ to his above-mention'd Son, on the Subject of Retirement: And thus we conclude this short Account of our Author.

DIV1.HEAD: Florilegium Metricum, sive Poemata Sacra. A D Candidum Lectorem.
DIV1.L: CArmina quiquondam scripsi florentibus annis
Mollia, nunc moestis carmina scribo modis;
Qui mihi Sacratae dictant scribenda Camoenae
Dum veris Elegi fletibus ora rigant.
Sed resonante tubâ quid inepte carmina scribo?
Non quadrant Musis tempora nostra piis.
Tempora plena malis, & quae pejora timemus,
Tempora fortunis invidiosa meis.
Scripsimus ista tamen quamvis mihin nulla voluptas
Scribendi tristi carmina duct a manu.
Nec laeto possum versus componere vultu,
Non nobis miseris convenit ille lepos.
Induo lugubres vultus, & sic color ater
Carminibus melius convenit iste meis.
Grande opus aggredior, Lector studiose, labori
Annue, dum parvo carmine magna lquor.
Exue crudeles animos paulisper amicos
Indue, censorem te decet esse meum.
Nec dedigneris steriles de messe maniplos,
Quos dat non fallax, sed male cultus ager.
Parva licet mea dona, hilari tamen accipe vultu
Haec sacros Vates gloria sola decet.
Displiceat frons atra licet sum foetus Olympo,
Foetaque sunt summo carmina nostra Deo.
Nomine tuta suo se ostendunt, & sua facta
Me licet immerito vate canente canunt.
Nil agitant mortale, Deus, Deus ipse canentis
Aspirat caeptis illius igne calent.
Illius urgentur stimulis, illoque premente
Numine, non hominem carmina nostra sonant.
Vertice ab aethereo Christum decanto migrantem,
Qualiter intactâ Virgine factus homo.
Si quos protulerim non dignos vivere versus,
Et qui debuerant nocte silente premi,
Torpuit ingenium nostrum torpente senecta
Dedidicit numeris currere Musa suis.
Nam subeunt anni fragiles & inertior aetas
Imminet & vitae frigida bruma meae,
Nunc mihi Bulstrode mea ecta labantia nutant.
Nec vigor est animi, serpit in ossa gelu.
Tempore mutato mores mutantur & ipsi.
Mutato studio nec mihi sum quod eram.
Et celeri cursu dum transit serior aetas
Poenitet heu primos praeteriisse dies.
Me piget ignavis studiis lusisse juventam
Saemina & incultum maereo jacta solum.
Sed sero sapimus, nimium sors Lector amica
Impediit studiis invigilare meis.
Dum fortuna favet mens ebria surgit in altum,
Optima sors hominum pessima corda facit,
Saepe donum est caruisse bonis, & ferre molesta
Nam prosunt multis tristia, laeta nocent,
Ast humiles animi sunt rebus saepe sub arctis
Discinctos mores fata sinistra fugant.
Froena det ingenio juvenilibus imperet annis
Optatum ingreditur qui pietatis iter.
Libertas servire Deo est, huic subdere discat
Qui sibi serviri libera colla velit.
Ergo Deo grates habeo, quas debeo summas,
Quod patrio affectu me per acerba tulit.
Et licet invalido languescant corpore vires
Attamen intrepidè quae toleranda feram.
Excelsâ quoque mente volo, vultuque sereno
Tam quae displiceant, quam placitura pati
Viribus infractis patiar quaecunque jubebit
Et laetâ accipiam tristia fata manu.
Dumque mihi tribuat numerari in sorte suorum
Talia gaudebo sustinuisse mala.
Nilque meae refert patriae valedicere, plus est
Quam fugisse domo sic rediisse Deo.

DIV2.L: DUM senior vates, cultor pietatis & aequi,
Proterit assiduo limina Sancta pede;
Inque tuis adytis, rerum Pater alme, moratur,
Ferventes referens in tua templa preces;
Thuricremos aris dum rite accenderat ignes,
Ut daret & Solymis debita thura focis;
Astitit oranti, claraque in luce refulsit
Angelus, aetherea missus ab arce Dei:
Ut stetit, expavit vates; dextraque trementi
Thura cadunt; currit tota per ossa tremor:
Angelus attonitum recreans haec ore profatur;
Audivit vestras en Deus ipse preces:
Cui mendax uteri spem saepe juventa fefellit,
Id modo supplebit sera senecta tibi:
Fertilis Elizae tumefient viscera prole,
Et Praecursorum progenitura Deo est.
Ridet Io, sterili modo tristis Eliza juventa.
Ridet Io, ridens altera Saca redit;
Et jam mater anus, quae se vix ante ferebat;
Illa feret prolem, (sarcina grata) marem:
Nec dubita, Vates, tua conjux obsita canis,
Intumuisse sinus sentit Eliza suos:
Et quod non peperit sol tot vertentibus annis,
Ad paucos pariet Luna novena dies.
Prodromus en Verbi veniet; vox ultima priscis
Vatibus, ut verbo sit tuba prima suo:
Fortunate senex, tot demum messibus actis,
Ergone sementis jam tibi tempus erit?
Quam selix dicére Pater geniture Prophetam,
Quo non majorem saecla tulere Patrum.
Obstupuit vates, nec nuncia credit Olympi;
Scilicet exsuperant nuncia mira fidem:
Miranti interea mutescit lingua Prophetae.
Et grave quod peccat cor, sua lingua luit.
Quippe Deo vatis qui credere nesciit error,
Error five timor vincula caeca dedit:
Angelus & strict's linguam compescit habenis,
Ut vocem Patri Pilius ipse daret.
ger hereus celso delapsus Olympo,
Ut mandata Dei rite minister agat,
Post iter immenum, volucremque per aëra cursum
Nazaridis subiit limina casta domus:
ui virgineo radins jubar ore tuetur,
rdidit ad uperas desruisse domos.
Virgineo attonitus Gabriel candore silebat,
Nec proferre sono nuntia verba datur:
Virgo immota silet, nec sursum lumina tollit,
Errat & in niveo plurimus ore rubor:
Quid facient? Graviora urgent mandata Tonantis;
Attamen & tacet haec; & nequit ille loqui:
Fulgidus at tandem stellatae nuntius aulae
Dixit ave, virgo candida, dixit, ave.
Virgo incerta tremens haec pensat nuntia coeli,
Nec capit aligeri quid volet istud Ave:
Cui Gabriel, ne te dubiam timor urgeat anceps,
Est tibi cum Domino gratia magna tuo;
Est tecum Dominus, tu sacro Numine plena,
Tu sola es Foelix hospite digna Deo:
Te Patris intrabit virtus, tua membra pudica.
Concipient salva virginitate Deum.
Utque tuum intactum foecundet Spiritus alvum,
En Deus assensum postulat ipse tuum:
Haec recolens virgo, nitet aurea gratia vultu,
Pulchra verecundus purpurat ora rubor.
Nescit virgineum partu violare pudorem
Sit gestura licet, sit paritura Deum:
Nempe stupet coeli donis cumulanda supremi,
Virgoque, dum Verbum fit caro, fiat, ait:
Sic, fiat, dixit Dominus, dum condidit Orbem;
Cum simili verbo jam parit illa Deum.
Protinus aetherea virtus hanc numinis umbra
Ambit virginei sic tumuere sinus.
Et miranda facit, cum corpus procreat umbram;
Attamen haec corpus procreat umbra suum.
Insantes capiunt aliae inter viscera matres;
Perfectum claudit Virgo Parensque virum:
In gremio Deus est, latet inviolabile Numen,
Virginis augustae membra pudica subit.
m capiunt humiles Numen caeleste Penates.
Haec vera est aedes, hoc penerale Dei.
Intus & inde nitet Coeli sine compare virgo
Qui Deus arcano est pectore, fronte micat.
Circumeunt tutilae flammantia tempora stellae,
Caetera sub radio membra nitente tegit.
Huic formam dedit Empyreum, sapientia mentem,
Corda amor, virginitas pectus & ora pudor.
Nec jam coelicolas solùm dignemur honore,
Terra etiam superi quam venerentur, habent.

Q.P: De Nativitate Domini nostri Jesu Christi.

DIV2.L: Plaudite mortales, rerum celebrate Parentem,
Voxque triumphantis tergeminetur Io:
Loeta dies instat; procul, hinc procul ora dolentis,
Gaudia festivis concelebranda choris.
Este procul vittae tristes, atraeque cupressi,
Naenia flebilibus maesta silete focis.
Exultent humiles valles, montesque superbi
Altius attollant loeta per astra caput:
Nempe Deum plaudant Elementa tacentia votis,
Ac sileant rigidi, turba molesta, Noti.
Ad plausum volucres cantillent, undique sylvae,
Et loetum ingeminent littora cuncta sonum.
Luce sacra requiescat hamus, requiescat arator,
Et grave suspenso vomere cesset opus.
Solvite vincla jugis, nunc ad praesepia fas est
Plena coronata sistere fronte boves:
Nunc pecus omne Thymo saturum, vel Rore-marino
Ducat inexpertos prata per alma choros:
Gestiat: herbosis agnus lusurus in agris;
Agnus Io! Supari Principis Agnus adest;
Surgite pastores▪ sylvarum candida pubes,
Pastorum Regem serior hora tulit.
Coelitus est primum vobis hic cognitus Infans,
Editus in lucem nam puer Agnus adest.
Ipsa Domus superum non se tenet, arduus aether
Panditur, aligerum deserit astra cohors.
Virgo parens facta est, Deus est è virgine natus,
Spectatum è Caelo turba beata veni.
Vos genus aethereum, cives stellantis Olympi,
Nomine jam pacis congeminare juvat:
Nec vos poeniteat Coelestes linquere sedes,
Nunc aliquid noster pulchrius Orbis habet:
Descendit Coelo Deus, & mortalia membra
Induit, & nasci paupere gaudet humo.
Nascitur humana sub imagine, nascitur ille
Qui sine matre polo, qui sine patre solo est.
Credere quis possit? Soboles aequaeva parenti,
De genetrice puer, de Genitore Deus:
Aeternique vigor Patris, Patrisque potestas,
Et quamvis genitus, nil genitore minor:
Nascitur, & divo devincit amore parentem,
Et natum aeterno vincit amore parens.
Scilicet humanos vultus, mortale subivit
Corpus, & hos artus induit ipse Deus.
Musa, quid hoc mirum est, quod Origine gaudet Origo,
Ut resilit totum a parte, Parente Parens.
A Jove principium numeravit Ephemeris olim,
Jamque repubescens in Jove principium est.
Virgineos intrare sinus dignatur, & ipsa
Qui parit est virgo, conjuge digna Deo.
Virginitas foelix, quae partu est digna Tonantis,
Quae meruit Dominum progenerâsse suum.
Huic necis, at fuerint aliis natalia vitae,
Et bene qui solus nascitur, orbus erat.
Ah genus ingratum! Tibi celsa palatia surgunt,
Tectaque divitiis conspicienda tuis:
Compositum lecto somnus te mollis eburno
Excipit, & pictâ stragula veste tegunt;
At misero rector superum compellitur antro,
Nec quo fessa toro membra reponat, habet.
Et quem nulla capit sedes jam sede moratur
Parva, ac in stabulo maximus hospes adest:
Immolles Christo praebent praesepia cunas,
Et durum stipulis culcitra farta torum.
Hic pecudes, stabulumque vides, & vile mapale;
Sufficiunt cunis attamen ista suis:
Nec sua strata nitent ullo cunabula cultu,
Sed vilem praestant stramen & herba torum:
In culmo & palea merito puer iste recumbens,
Frumentum populi cum foret ille sui;
Affatuque bovis, sociique fruetur aselli;
Hac rerum Dominus frigora pellit ope.
Virgo, Dei mater, tu non palatia curas,
Attia scis Domino non placitura tuo;
Sed secura tuum capiunt praesepia natum,
Facta puerperio jam pretiosa tuo.
Salve parva quidem, nec magnis usibus olim
Condita, nunc Coelis invidiosa domus.
Mille oculis puerum spectant hunc sydera nocte,
Candida (proh) paleae dum sua membra premunt:
Ardent se induere in paleas, & cedere Coelo
Sydera, sic membris esse beata suis.
Sydera sed patrias non fas est linquere sedes
Tempus erit victor cum premit astra puer.
Dius amor! Quae mira oculis spectacula pandis?
Vagitus, supera qui tonat arce, ciet.
Pro trabea pictoque ostro, vela obvia ovantis
Membra tegunt, facili & carbasa texta manu▪
Horrescunt stipulae sparsis pro fletibus imbres,
Fundis odoratos pupula blanda genis.
Qui nutu vincire potest, & solvere Cauros,
Nexibus hunc arctum candida lina ligant.
Scilicet & mollem constringit fascia dextram,
Qui rapida horrenti fulmina nube rotat.
Vincula sunt pueri, feret aspera grandior aetas
Vincula, cum palmam clavus utramque premet.
Ille tremit rapidis data praeda furoribus Euri,
Fulgere aethereas qui dedit igne faces:
Et sacra crudeli quatiuntur frigore membra,
Dum nescit teneris parcere bruma genis.
Frigore parce gelu Coelestem laedere prolem;
Si non vis puero parcere, parce Deo:
Si pueri lachrymis, si non moveare parentis,
Parce Deo, Dominum si vereare tuum.
Chare puer, quid post exordia talia speres?
Quis cursus vitae sic ineuntis erit?
Si primò crudelis amor te cogit in ista,
Quid faciet, cum te viderit esse virum?
Causa sumus fateor tantorum sola malorum,
Esse finas miseros, non eris ipse miser.
Ut lueres nostris quae sunt mala debita culpis,
Fles, puer, in cunis crimina nostra tuis,
Flet puer, & rides tu quem mage flere deceret,
Qui Domino tanti causa doloris eras.
Mitte jocos tandem, & meditare novissima Christi,
Principiis par est meta secuta suis.
Nempe ut Natales Christo statuêre nefandos,
Non minus adversam fata dedêre necem.
Ast humili puer infra hominem cum nascitur ortu,
Ortu supra hominem se probat esse suo.
Aspice nascentem, morientem conspice, dices,
Ille fuit minimus, maximus ille fuit.

Q.P: De Passione Domini nostri Jesu Christi.

DIV2.L: Currite nunc rivi, lachrymaeque per ora volutae,
Currite, largifluo mergite fonte genas.
Tristia flebilibus resonant nunc sata quaerelis,
Luctisonis etiam currat arena modis.
Quis modo non doleat, gemebundo pectore plangat,
Commemorans Domini tristia fata sui.
Pro nobis solum descendit Christus ad ima,
Asperaque in terris bis tria lustra tulit.
Ile Triumphator mundi, mortisque, stygisque,
Sente triumphali tempora cincta gerit.
Pro nobis passus jam pendet in arbore Christus,
Pro nobis etiam vulnera lata patent.
Insons sustinuit nostras in carne ruinas,
Sacrificae figens crimina nostra cruci.
Aeternum Authorem vitae quis credere possit,
Vel potuisse semel, vel voluisse-mori?
Hoc tamen hic voluit, magno percussus amore;
Et postquam voluit, quis potuisse neget?
In Coelis te fixit amor, mors in cruce fixit;
Te nasci facit hic, te facit illa mori.
Scilicet ut puros nascentibus innovet artus,
Humana nasci conditione tulit:
Solveret ut noxas, primique piacla parentis
Humana voluit conditione mori.
Quid tunc desperes, peccatis territus ullis,
Nec veniam facilem corde gemente petas?
Quippe pater placidus Deus est, veniaeque paratu
Qui solet ad poenas lentus, & esse levis:
Qui cum triste aliquid statuit, fit tristis & ipse,
Cuique ferè poenam sumere, poena sua est.
Non igitur debes ab amante timere repulsum,
Cui tua, crede, magis quam tibi chara salus.
Et quamvis Christo tu mortem infligis acerbam
Te tamen innumero crimine loeus amat.
Nec te odisse queat, nisi te sic oderis ipse
Oblatam ut spernas prorsus amantis opem.
Mortis in amplexu sat habet delicta fateri,
Exemplo pendens in cruce latro praeit,
Mille cui luces peperissent mille dolores,
Unica sed peperit gaudia mille dies.
Si nondum credis, fixus nunc respice fixum,
Cernitur in toto corpore sculptus amor.
Nunc pete, nam quondam cum sederit Iride Judex
Tunc dabit heu rigidè quod tua facta petent.
Aspice nunc Christum pro te tam dira ferentem,
Pastor ut incolumi pro grege praeda lupis.
Nunc splendor splendore caret, lux lucis egena est,
Qui modo sol fuerat, pendet ut umbra necis.
Quis dolor heu toro grassatur corpore saevo
Nulla Redemptoris memora dolore carent.
Vulnera deciduo decurrunt prodiga nimbo,
Et veluti rubro refluit unda freto.
Vulnifica sub dente secant tua tempora spinae;
Divinum terebrat spinea sylva caput.
Utque illum ostentent nova per ludibria regem,
Ponitur in dextrâ vilis arundo suâ.
Sed sceptrum fulgore caret, quoque luce corona,
Illius est sceptrum dextra, corona caput.
Sanguinolenta pedes horrendo vulnere cuspis
Trajicit, extentas sanguinolenta manus,
Sustinuit domitis quos olim fluctibus aequor,
Crux modo constrictus sustinet atra pedes.
In Cruce dum pender, clamant, cui credidit illi
Sit Deus auxilio, si quid amoris habet:
Et si numen adest, jam jam descendat ab orno.
Sed precor in ligno, Christe, recumbe tuo:
In cruce nempe tua stat mundi vita salusque,
Inque tuis poenis stat sua sola quies.
O amor! O qualis tua fit miseratio! Quando
Tu nostri miserans tam miserandus obis!
Mitius in foeno quam ligno, Christe, jacebas,
Suppliciisque crucis, ceu ros, stramen erat,
Sylva tibi missura lubens sua dona Sabaea,
In cunis quondam thurea dona dedit:
Talia, Dive, dedit tibi non jam sylva Sionis,
Quadrifidam in formam tignea dona dedit.
Vilius haud nasci poteras, lachrymabile dictu,
Denasci nunquam vilius ipse potes.
Nasceris & pecorum consors, denasceris inde
Latronum tibi dat Crux inhonora necem.
Soeva tigris misero poterat mitescere vultu,
Tigride vel si quid soevius orbis habet.
Et tamen in poenis queritur vox nulla doloris,
Sed quasi maeroris naenia gaudet, ovat.
Et patitur turbae placidà convicia mente,
Nec fuit in justas lingua soluta minas
Cernere tunc poteras Christum valedicere terris,
Ad sua dum rediit regna relicta poli.
Sic, O sic extremus amor sua brachia pandit!
Sic quasi in amplexus nos vocat ire suos.
Quis tamen è Coelis retinet vestigia clavus?
Quae religant teneras vincula dira manus?
Parcite tot clavis; hunc mollia vincla ligabunt.
Haec si defuerint, in cruce figet amor.
Heu mortem subeat, ne nos mors terreat, alma
Porta quibus vitae non nisi morte patet.
Heu jacet infami prostratus vulnere mortis,
Quae reliquis auget, sic sibi vita perit.
Vivendi qui solus erat, sic non erat, index,
Principio vitae vita negata fuit.
Majori quidnam potuit, majorve parari
Hostia, cum Deus est victima facta Deo.
Qui putat hunc hominem, qui vere est inscius idem
Qui te supremum non videt esse Deum.
Aspice luctantem cum morte Hominem{que} Deum
Sed vincit moriens, & tibi victor ovat.
Ut solet & riguos moriens sol spargere rores,
Quando cadens croceis proluit ora rotis;
Sicsol justitiae rubro est jam vespere tinctus,
Pulchrior ut surgat tertius ille dies.

Q.P: De Resurrectione Domini nostri Je∣su Christi.

DIV2.L: Plaudite mortales, & Io ter dicite Regi,
Plaudite victori terque quaterque Deo.
Sparge caput violis, & ovanti cingite lauru,
Raptaque victrici concute signa manu.
Scilicet Authorem vitae super aethera loetus
Tolle, resurgenti carmina pande Deo.
Feria salvato consurgunt gaudia mundo,
Efficit aeternos unicus ille dies.
Vera Dei soboles; homines quem vidimus una,
Nobiscumque hominem, cumque Parente Deum.
Nos modo quam tristes sub iniquo Judice poenas
Luximus, & nigrum se moriente diem;
Effusi in laudes, virides prosternite lauros,
Dum novus inferno victor ab hoste redit.
Pulchrior edomitâ victor jam morte resurgit,
Christus, avernales irradiando domos.
Mor sequitur captiva, jacent disrupta Sepulchri
Vincula, sydereae jam patuere fores.
Hoc jubar, hoc alba juvenes in veste loquuntur,
Quos Deus aethereà mittit ab arce Pater.
Quale decus! Quanti redit hic sol regna diei,
Postquam se rubro lavit in oceano:
Sic redit ille dies, nunquam lux clarior extans,
Occiduo postquam gurgite mersus erat.
Aurea jam fulget roseis Aurora capillis,
Lustrat mirantem lucida flamma polum.
Stella maris Christus, solem qui tempore vincit,
Antea quam Phoebus prodiit, orrus erat.
Abscondit lumen Phoebus, superatus ab ipso,
Qui Phoebo radios, qui dedit astra Polo.
Sic sol ille vetus tam magni conscius ortus,
Pene negat spretas comere luce comas;
Et modo nocte suâ caecis qui inglorius umbris
Nunc quoque pro nimio lumine coecus erat,
Sic sol Justitiae sol est aeternus, ab ipso
Alter splendorem sol periturus habet,
Dura tenebrosae disrupit vincula noctis,
Et nobis lucem sol remeare jubet:
Custodes trepidant, pia plebs exultat, & ipse,
Ipse remolitus pectore saxa venit,
Surgit Io Christus, referens nova gaudia matri,
Neonon dilectis gaudia grata suis.

Q.P: De Asensione Domini nostri Jesu Christi. Viri Gallilei, quid statis aspicientes in Coelum?

DIV2.L: Sins inter Proceres Mundi Viaeque Redemptor,
Discpulis praesert verba enigna suis:
Admner humanis quae sit fiducia rebus,
Et procul vetam tempus in omne fidem.
Haec ubi dicta dedit, vibrat se sponte per auras,
Et sest aethereâ tollit in astra viâ.
Pastor evile gregis Petro sic triste relinquit,
Discipulis vultus subtrahit ille suos.
Venit in hunc mundum Christus prosternere mortem,
Vicit, & ad saperos in sua regna redit.
Et foelix spolia ampla refert super aethera victor,
Sc nitet exuviis regia celsa novis.
I um{que} Triumphator patrium conscendit Olympum,
Post Dominum Proceres lumina fixa tenent.
Et quibus effusum lata ad spectacula Coelum,
Adventûsque Dei signa dedere poli.
Urbs auro quadrata micat, sunt aurea passim
Compita, divinâ vermiculata manu.
Et circumfusis pascuntur lumina gemmis;
Aethereumque sonat semper in aure melos,
Hic Christi solium nitidis stellisque coruscans,
Hic Pater aethereus dicere jura solet.
Illic eximio quoque Crux effulget honore,
Aurea stans celsa conspicienda trabe.
Lucet ubique Deus, sunt Numinis omnia plena,
Quo sine nube fluunt, & sine nocte dies.
Sic oculis Dominum jam pulsa nube tuentur
Spernentes miserum, quem modo liquit, humum.
O meritum sublime quibus spectare triumphum
Talem luminibus contigit orbe suis.
Nunc male sordet humus, sua lumina sydera spectant,
Quae fuerint votis sola adunata suis.
Illecebras, ah! terra, tuas, permittere cessa,
Implevit totos altera gaza sinus.
Tunc gemini pallis, coelestia corpora habentes,
Velati niveis, emicuere viri:
Huc quoque, dixerunt, cur o Galilaea propago,
Sic vultus sursum tollis in astra tuos.
Saeva nimis quin, crede mihi, sunt talia verba
Istis purpureis nec bene juncta genis
Nam Deus omnipotens, qui nos & cuncta creavit,
Os homini & vulcum, cernat ut astra, dedit.
Atque utinam in coelos mens nostra immota maneret,
Ut nunquam dubiis fluctuet illa malis.
Et licet ex istis sua lumina adempta fuissent,
Suspicient; fieret sic quoque caecus amor.
Pergite vos igitur, sursumque attollite vultus
Suspicitote Polum, despicitote solum.
Vos, animae illustres, vano valedicite mundo,
Vos decet aethereis nunc inhiare bonis.
Invisis tandem mentes subducite terris
Hic ubi spes semper lubrica, vita brevis.
Jam coelum coeli aspicitis, jam proxima vita
In visu est, retro vertere vela nefas.
Carpite iter coeli, quibus est coelestis origo,
Terra nihil pulchri, quod videatis, habet.
Terrorum plenus Solymûm frendebat in oris
Saulus, dum cassum lumine pectus erat:
Annuit ad mortem Stephani, spiratque furorem
In cunctos etiam qui coluere Deum.
Ad sacra dum ridet Christi mysteria Saulus,
De coelo subitum sentit adesse Deum:
Apparuit Christus Saulo, vox faucibus haesit,
Et jacuit toto corpore fusus humi.
Dum manet immotus, morum tamen ore fatetur,
Vivit, & est virae nescius ipse suae.
Omnipotens Verbi Divini fulmen ad aures
Demissum Sauli fulmine corda quatit:
Obvenit & ipsi divini stamma furoris,
Flamma vel extinctas docta ciere faces:
Et Deus ipse suo disponens omnia nutu,
Saulum ex obliqua mandat abire via.
Sic Deus hoc lapsu Sauli vestigia flectit,
Ire pedes coepit, qui prius ibat eques.
Quod magis admiror, velocius ultra subivit,
Quam cum pecipiti curreret actus equo.
Haec strages optanda fuit, succumbere Christo,
Haec fit ovis subitò, qui ferus ante lupus.
Quam gravis hic lapsus! quam pulsat pectora Christus
Quam suo praecipiti fulmine corda quatit!
Quae rerum foeces! nunc, quem despexit, adorat;
Nunc ante ignotum praedicat ore Deum.
Qui lupus ore gregem Christi absorbere parabat,
Quam cito, mutato vellere, factus ovis.
Saulus erat, modo Paulus abit; qui pessimus ante
Hostis erat Christi, verus amicus adest.
Illico mota calent flammis sua pectora sacris,
Saulus & en lapsu celsior ipse suo.
Lumine prae nimio fit Saulus luminis expers,
Protinus ut melius cerneret ille Deum.
Attrahit aethereo nigram de lumine noctem,
Stant oculis tenebrae, mente serena dies.
Illa suos foelix caligo texit ocellos,
Ut lucem coecis gentibus ille daret:
Et quamvis coeli privatus lumine, lucem,
Qua se, quaque Deum conspicit, intus habet.
Foelici lapsu sic visum perdidit, & cum
Perdidit ille oculos, repperit ille novos.
Hinc venit ut Paulus toti innotescere mundo
Coepit, & ex illo clarior esse die.
Ignea mens Pauli splendet, vox fulminis instar,
Doctaque coelestis pectora flammat amor.
Undique vicinas volitabat fama per urbes;
Tam subito Domini venit ab ore salus.
Quanta tuum in Paulum est clementia, Rector Olympi,
Qui moribundâ nova lumina luce beas!
Qui lupus ante rapax vestitur vellere molli,
Seductor quondam qui modo ductor adest
Jam tuba plena Dei, sed quondam plena furore,
Nunc & inexhausti vas sine labe boni.
Utque aliis esset lumen, sua lumina perdit,
Coecus cernit, erat coecus & ipse videns:
Mox late rutilans infundit lumina mundo,
Coecorum est medicus, qui modo coecus erat.

Q.P: De Nuptiis in Cana Galileae, ubi aqua in vi∣num vertitur.

DIV2.L: Solennes Epulas, & connubialia Festa
Dum Galilaea parat, Christus adesse petit;
Ac invitatis facilis conviva recumbit;
Sic vacat exiguis rebus adesse Jovi.
Ut ponunt mensae sua sercula grata secundae,
Mater ait Christo; deficit ecce merum.
Mox mandat Christus (cui tanta potentia verbo?)
Et vitem fassa est hanc pia lympha suam.
Dulcius vel citius nequit de palmite ferre
Quam faecunda scyphis vox tuis una dedit.
In vinum liquidae vertuntur fluminis undae,
Vasaque divino plena liquore rubent;
Nutu divino proprium mutantque colorem:
Lympha pudica Deum vidit, & erubuit.
Incipit in florem dulcis transire Falerni,
Ac invitatis gaudia mira dedit.
Obstupuit sponsus, famulorum & concita turb
Non expectantes talia dona meri.
Sic fontem viventis aquae quem saepe vocarunt,
Te fontem vini, Christe, vocare volo.
Elicuit Moses duplici cum verbere lymphas;
Elicit hic verbo vina Falerna suo.
Mutat aquas vino: nec Christi munera sperne,
Sed bibe; delicias fons habet iste suas.
Pergite coelestem sic evacuare liquorem,
Ebrius hinc nisi sis, sobrius esse nequis.

Q.P: Niedumus veniens per noctem ad Christum.

DIV2.L: Quid tenchras luci prefers, noctemque diei?
Hic fcit ex umbris lumina, nocte diem.
Non tenebris divinus amor fuscatur ab istis,
Sed noctem è media nocte repellit amor.
Invenis in tenebris Christum, Nicodeme; tenebras
Luce sui vultus dissipat ille tuas.
Ergo tuas has per tenebras dispelle tenebras,
Arque ex hac, noctem discute, nocte, tuam
Prodigus en haeres effrons deposcere gazas,
Visus & à patria perditus ire domo.
Filius hic demens, qui patri cedere nescit,
Qui facienda fugit, qui fugienda facit.
Mens vaga discurrit, quoque menti consonat aetas,
Mentis & aetatis turbine froena fugit.
Solliciti patris jussis parere recusans,
Effatus tales fudit ab ore sonos:
Pignora da, genitor, per quae tua vera propago
Credar, quae petiit pignora datque pater.
Ut data sunt, juvenis peregrinas tendit in oras
Et procul à patriis dissita regna focis.
Ibat ovans, alacri juvenum stipante caterva,
Alterius longas orbis ad usque plagas.
Jamque in sustra ruit, vacuas perpotus ad aures,
Lux Baccho, Veneri servit amica quies.
Pergraecando rosas inter mollesque Choreas
Laena fuit nummis infidiosa suis.
Quid facis ah demens? quae te malesuada voluptas
Duit in obliquam ventre jubente viam?
Qui mandata patris, vel dogmata sancta sophorum
Negligit, aut spernit; quam miser ille perit.
Cui corpus, cui colla regit violenta cupido
Colla licet jactat libera, servus erit.
Dissipat hic patris census, mox urget egestas
Et mendicato cogitur ipse ciho.
Hic canum hoc rutilis praefert male sedibus, istas
Hic male spurcitias diligit ante Deum.
Ah! pudet amplecti quasi dulcia cinnama coenum,
Et siliquis animum pascere, corda luto.
Dliciis jam finis erat, vilissima ventem
Pabula jam cogit pascere dira fames.
Mox stimulante same duras quatit illice glandes,
Et suis indignos quaeritat esse cibos.
Fercula sunt sordes cinerum, farrisque canini
Relliquiae; clamat voce manuque, date;
Et manus èque manu tenus cecidêre malignis
De dapibus micae, si modo mica dapes.
Jam stomachum subit aegra fames, praecordia vexat,
Occulto latrant ilia rauca sono.
Longa sames genuum juncturas laxat, & extant
Ossa per exanguem dinumeranda cutem.
Ventris erat pro ventre locus▪ pendere putares
Pectus, & in vultu mortis imago fuit.
Quae modo purpureis proefulsit gloria cunis,
Nunc latet in panno paupere, squallor habet.
Inde memor patriae tandem, mensaeque paternae,
Ingemit, & secum talia volvit iners.
Quò male sane ruis▪ tenerorum oblite parentum,
O oblite tui, quò male sane ruis?
Tandem post dubios sedet haec sententia fluctus,
Se patris in medium praecipitare sinum.
Protinus assurgit charum repetendo parentem,
Atque has jejuno protulit ore preces.
Oh pater! exundant gemini quasi flumina rivi,
Oh pater! elinguis vinxit ad ora stupor.
Fccavi pater, ab quo me vesania quo me
Impulit heu coeco coeca juventa pede;
Da veniam capae, pater, o pater optime, clama.
Te rogo per patrii quidquid amoris habes.
Inlama▪ ocjurga, coelique, tuique, meique
Immemorem; ingratum degenerem{que} voca.
Vincula si merui, si ergastula, laetus obibo,
Si me mancipium vis fore laetus ero.
Hoc unum obtestor, fieri, pater optime, nato
Ut recress pauco mortua membra cibo;
Tantum ut edam micas, & frustula panis adesi
Et quae non merui dentibus ossa teram.
Nil mihi cum vitulo, stola candida, nil mihi tecum
Non est conveniens hic cibus, ille color.
Inde pater motus nati prece, brachia tendit
Mox & in amplexus se jubet ire suos.
Prodigus ille domum rediit Germanus, & ecce
Tota domus plausu laetitiaque strepit.
Ornabat nati lumbos Holoserica vestis,
Tinctaque purpureo murice vestis erat.
Jamque saginatus generoso sanguine cultrum
Imbuit, & vitulus visus amare necem est.
Dicat adhinc proles patrium servare favorem,
Et discat quanto flagrat amore pater.
Ut piget hunc sceleris, genitor scelus omne remittit,
Et sua pacifico brachia more parat;
Poenitet illicitae quem Vitae, & conscius error
Quem praemit, in Coelis gloria major erit.
Nec cupit ut pereant peccati pondere pressi,
Sed magis ut vivant & relevetur onus.
Sed discat proles dum Patris spernit habenas,
Quas meruit poenas filius, ipse luit.
Prodigus hic porcos glandesque perosus, amantem
Longinquâ repetit de regione Patrem.
Vos regio longinqua tenet, vos pascere porcos,
Vos siliquis pastos Patre carere juvat:
O peregrinantes miseri qui tenditis illuc,
Spretus ubi aeterno vos cremet igne Pater.
Vos tandem remeate ad fulcrum dulce parentis,
Exemplo doctus quilibet esto suo.

Q.P: Bonus Pastor dabit animam pro o∣vibus.

DIV2.L: Pastoris fictà sub imagine cessit Olympo,
Admaeti teneras pascere Phoebus Oves.
Sol noster petiit Cereris sub imagine terras,
Esse ut idem ovibus Pastor & Esca suis.
Blandus & opilio miserum & pascit Iesus,
Per salebras gressus dirigit ille tuos,
Cum procul a Pastore Deo tu devius isti,
Protinus imbellem te revocarit ovem.
Te tenet ac inter morsus rictúsque ferarum,
Excubias sacro pro grege semper agit.
Caetera pastorum gens gaudet sorte benignâ,
Iste lupis pavido pro grege bella gerit.
Quàm bonus est Pastor, qui non detrectat acerbam
Pro grege Servando fortis adire necem!
Quim bonus est Pastor qui sacrificabitur agnis!
Sic erit ô sic non Pastor ut Agnus erit.
Agnus erit sine labe Crucis mactandus ad aras,
Peccatis hominum Victima grata cadet.
Victima grata cadet nec sacrificabitur ulla,
Hostia digna Deo ni Deus ipse cadat.
Quam praecor indomitam cruor hic non leniat iram
Ira e hoc gustans Sanguine, mitis erit.
Angelici caetus Princeps juhet arma parari
Lucifer, & socios raptar in arma suos.
Scilicet affectans solium sublime Tonantis,
En quatit in summum tela cruenta Deum.
Proh pudor! impatiens Majestatis{que} secundae
Postulat insultans sceptra suprema poli;
Authorm{que} suum spernit, Domino{que} rebelles
Aetheris indigenas sub sua signa trahit.
O quantes in bella duces! quae protulit arma
Perfidus, & quantâ praelia dira tuba!
Quantus in aethereis tollit se Lucifer armis!
At{que} ipso graditur vix Michaele minor!
Quantis & quam funestis concurritur iris!
Dum ferus hic stellas protegit, ille rapit!
Dum vulsos montes ceu tela reciproca torquent,
Et non mortali desuper igne pluunt.
Vibrantur flammae, commotu tonitrua rauco
Admistis flammis insonuêre polo,
Ac simul in coelis Messiae insignia fulgent
Cum Cruce Vexilla, praeda cruenta, Dei.
Attamen aethereis non cedet Lucifer armis
Et metuit pugnae non superesse suae.
O indigne poli fallax augere triumphos!
Audes tam certas sollicitare manus?
Falleris heu multùm, vanos raptaris in ausus
In superos tragicâ praelia flare tuba.
Tu coelum furiis agitas, agitatus iisdem
Ter miser aetherei vindicis igne cades!
Confestim missus cum fulminis igne, videbis
Ipse tuas tenebras, lux ubi nulla nitet.
Insanum est certare Deo cui milirat aether,
Cum propriis armis illicò vinctus eris.
Quippe novum acquirit Michael certamine robur,
Quo magis & premitur, tollitur ille magis.
Sub pedibus{que} suis jacet admirabile monstrum,
Et Sceptrum victi grande Draconis habet.
Sic cadit attonitis mens omnis, & impetus omnis,
Et cassis dextris irrita tela cadunt.
Ad poenas fugiunt, & ceu foret Orcus asylum,
Infernis certant condere se tenebris.
Dum Michael Victor spoliis & henoribus auctus
Luciferi, stellis, Lauro imitante, nitet.

CLOSER.SIGNED: R. BULSTRODE. Deo Gratias.

DIV1.HEAD: An EXTRACT of a Letter to his Son concerning RETIREMENT.
DIV1.P:
AS to what you have thought upon, and desire my Advice in, it is indeed one of the most difficult things a Man can do; for this solitary Entertainment of our selves, is either one of the best, or the worst things we can undertake. He that will withdraw himself must first prepare to receive himself. It is not Wisdom to o∣verdrive Nature, which is to draw a Blemish upon our Judgment. Men that retire should first examine the Difficulty of the Enterprize; for without this prelimi∣nary Prudence a Man may overburthen his Shoulders, and soon wade out of depth; and it is to many better in Prospect than in Possession. It is indeed no such ea∣sy matter as many Men believe, to make a safe Retreat from the World, to truss up our Baggage, and bid our Company farewel; this is a Burthen which few Men can take up handsomely. For a Man to leave off all Bu∣siness, to anticipate the Accidents of Fortune, to deprive himself of his present Advantages, to place himself up∣on the lowest Step in this World, thereby to secure himself from falling, is an Action of extream Difficulty, as well as of an extraordinary Vertue. Neither is it enough only to separate our selves from the Converse of Peo∣ple, for tho' we have freed our selves from Business, from the Court, from Westminster Hall, yet we are not thereby free from the principal Torments of our Life: And as Socrates being ask'd by one who had ben long abroad, why he had not more improv'd him∣self
by Travel, answered well, because he had not left himself behind him, when he went to travel. So be∣fore a Man leaves the World, if he do not first dis∣charge both himself and his mind from the burthen that presses her, retiring will but star it the more, and press it the harder; as a sick Man suffers more hurt than good by changing place: It is but setling an Evil instead of removing it; and if we cast but a kind look upon what we have left behind, we still carry our Fetters along with us, and are not at liberty; we ought therefore at first to recover our selves from our selves, for without managing our superiour part, all the pains taken about the inferiour is to no purpose.

It is certainly a rare thing, that every Man should sufficiently stand in awe of himself, Ut satis se quis∣que vereatur, That we should win so much upon our selves, as to be able to dwell and delight in our selves. We must not so tie up our selves to the things of this World, that our felicity depend upon them, but reserve a Store-house to our selves, (what need soever happen) wherein we may secure and establish our true content∣ment and principal retreat. This World is a Comedy wherein every Man acts that part which Providence hath assign'd him; and as it is esteem'd more noble to lok on than to act, so there is no securer Bx from which to behold it, than a safe retreat, it being easier to feel than express the pleasure you will take with that your own Family, in standing aloof off, and in con∣templating the reelings and busslings of the multitude upon this Stage of the World.

There is no Counsel more proper for Men, than Te∣cum habita, to dwell at home, and not suffer any thing to steal us from our selves; there is neither profit nor pleasure worth so much, that we should go abroad to sick it. Even many of the Epicurean Sect, (who propos'd to themselves no other end but their content∣ment)
did bereave themselves of all sensual delights, and contemn'd the pomp of all worldly Greatness for the only pleasure of Contemplation.

But you that are a wise Christian, and have well provided for your self and Family, and that may within your own heart enjoy both Vertue and God himself, have much higher advantages, and much more reason to keep within your own home, looking upon things without with an indifferent eye. That Man forgets his origin, who puts his soul out of possession of her self, by continually running after business, and plodding to Westminster full of embarrass; whereas he should abandon, and bid adieu to all manner of business, that may any way im∣peach the tranquillity of mind or body. He that thus re∣tires, draws no man's envy upon him; he reigns by himself over his family, and all the pomp which great∣ness draws after it, is not comparable to that which you will enjoy in secret by thus retiring; which is in∣deed to shut up the prospect of this world, that we may take the better view of the other, by a prudent precaution, to untwist our affections, and slide off from the World, before the World slips from us; whereas they that continue in the throng of business, their minds lose their rest; and many times after a man hath lost his rest he loseth his labour also.

We have never greater cause to consult our best wits, what we are to do, and how to carry our selves, than when preferment, or publick employments are offered us. He that hath strength and wisdom to manage such places, may receive them; but he that hath enough for himself and family, ought not to entangle himself again with more than he can well manage, and make his whole life a burthen to him. And those wisely retire who being harassed with the fatigues of a publick life, foreseeing ill weather, are willing to put into port, when keeping out at Sea might endanger the vessel.

When God intended to converse with Moses, he call'd him from the populous City to the top of Mount Sinai, and Christ did not disclose the Glories of his transfigu∣ration at Jerusalem, but upon the Mount of Olives; and when God did disciple his beloved but rebellious People of Israel, he chose first the Wilderness, and then the two Captivities to be his School.

You should consider the notable Answer given by Cy∣neas the Philsopher to Pyrrhus, who told him, he would conquer Greece, then Rome, and so all the World. Cyneas ask'd him, Why he would give him∣self so much trouble? To which Pyrrhus told him, He would do it, that he might afterwards live hap∣pily and merrily with his Friends. But Cyneas sharply reply'd, He might do so presently, and not take so much pains for it: And so you may do now with your Family. Indeed Men that are still busied in publick Affairs, whose mercurial Genius inclines them to a restless Life, they (like Moses on Pisgah) see Re∣tirement their Land of Canaan afar off, but without hopes of enjoyment. And I have known some good Men in the last Age, who would never leave Employments till outed of them; like Whales that never come on shoar till they are wounded. And certainly those who after possessing great Places have been unexpectedly dis∣grac'd, are more really convinc'd of its slipperyness than those that never found the Effects of such Revolution. Nay those very Men who seek greedily after Employ∣ments pretend thereby a design for Retirement. The Merchants who seek abroad so much for Riches, is on∣ly to gain so much as may afford the conveniency of a Retirement; and Soldiers do sweeten the bitterness of their life by the remote prospect of a good Garrison and Winter-quarter. And Caesar himself said, Ali∣quando mihi licebit mini vivere, he desired his spare
Hours, esteeming that part of his life to belong to others which he spent for other Men.

I know and have seen some Men retire from the World, who have yet look'd back at it, and oftentimes have kept their hearts in it. Thus many of the Phi∣losophers left the World in effect, but not in affection; for they had only their arms and legs out of the throng, their minds were still engaged. These Men did not take the right way; they thought they had wholly ta∣ken leave of all business, that they might live at more leisure and greater ease, but they mistook them∣selves; for tho' they had shaken off the Court, and pub∣lick Employments, they had not taken leave of the principal vexations of life, nor discharged their minds of the burthens which oppressed them: They had not order'd their contentment to depend wholly upon them∣selves, and that they could live alone in good earnest, and at ease.

However Men may converse with the World, and yet leave it; we may pass thro' a crowd, and not mingle with it. Every Ship that sails must needs have some part of the Ship under water; every Man that lives in this World, must needs have some of his labours spent upon the World; but as that part of the Ship by which a Man sails is above the water, so that part of us, which is above the earth, we must re∣move it from the World. Thus some Men (in which number I hope you are) have attain'd to that sublimity of mind as to be above all worldly cares; and tho' they meddle with the World as being in the World, yet they do it so safely, that they cleave not to it, nor are astonish'd to leave it.

It is a great misery for a Man never to be his own; too much business makes us strangers to our selves; the content we expect by our conversation is lost by too much conversation; and the advantages we get by our
Employments abroad, are not to be compared with the satisfaction we receive in Retirement, (which I have found by long experience in the multiplicity of business of greatest consequence, during the many Years I was in publick Employment:) For as Bees must retire to the honey after they have gather'd the matter from flowers, so is it necessary that we retire into our selves to ga∣ther the fruit of our experience; otherwise we shall be but ill Husbands of the wealth we have gotten.

To retire for quiet and thinking is very recommen∣dable; Business and Conversation are thieves that steal away a great part of our time, and usually stuffs our memory with rubbish; Retirement is a great relief in such a case, and wise Men are glad to get clear of the crowd, for fresh air and breathing; and a life led in sweet tranquillity (which is the work of reason) is much preferable to the great advantages which the World admires. In Retirement we taste the sweetness of a quiet repose, and entertain our selves with free∣dom; nay, we live more in two days of retreat, than in two years full of business and trouble. And in this you may trust me, who have gone thro' more business military and civil, than perhaps any Man now li∣ving; and yet I have seen greater things in my re∣tired life, than ever I saw abroad. For what do we see great in the World. but Armies, Sieges of Towns, Courts of Princes, which seem great at first sight? But in Retirement, we look upon the different works of Nature, the Sun rising and setting, a still Night, and those Planets which so majestically rowl over our heads, which we continually admire. I could say much more to you upon this Subject, having found great advantages since my removal from the throng of business, and shall conclude with what Similis a great General to the Emperor Adrian did, who after his Honours, Victories, and Preferments, retired into the
Country to his own house for seven years before he died, and desired the substance of this Epitaph to be engraved only upon his Tomb stone. Here lyes Ge∣neral Similis of a very great Age, who yet lived but seven years, relating only to the time of his Re∣tirement.

I hope you will excuse this long Letter; but I can never leave talking with you till I come to the bot∣tom, especially upon so good a Subject, and upon your own desire; and I doubt not but you will chuse what shall be most conducing to your own contentment. I have nothing else to add, but to assure you that I de∣sire nothing more in this World but once to have the satisfaction of embracing you, and giving you my last Blessing, with several Collections and Writings of my own, which may be satisfactory to you, and preserve my memory. Besides I have such a Collection of Let∣ters of the most eminent Persons of this last Age as are not any where else, and all digested into order, which I would most willingly put into your hands be∣fore I die. To which end I would very willingly meet you at Antwerp, or any other place within the Allies Dominions, believing my Lord Marleborough would easily grant me a Pass, from whom I have re∣ceived great Civilities during this War, which I do not find is now like to end so son as I thought: Adieu, and believe me over most intirely Yours.

DIV2.P:
UPON the Arrival of Don Bernardo Sali∣nas, the Master de Camp General was sent for from Flanders, who return'd hither on Sunday Morning. In his Pas∣sage between Bruges and Gaunt, having with him a good Convoy of Horse, they took a small Party of French Foot, who had before ta∣ken some Prisoners upon the River, and were convoying them to their Garrison of Pouke, a League and an half from the River; the French Par∣ty were all taken, and brought hither Prisoners on Sunday Night. The same Evening his Excellency was long in Council with his General Officers, where Don Bernardo Salinas was admitted; and there it was resolved, That the Master de Camp General should go with Don Bernardo to the Hague, to adjust all Matters with his Highness in
relation to the Campaign, and they depart hence either on Thursday or Friday at farthest. In the mean time the Duke de Villa Hermosa continues at Bruges in Flanders, for the receiving and dis∣posing of some Regiments that are marching thi∣ther from Holland. It seems the excessive Snow has made so great an Inundation between Gaunt and Bruges, that the Dike of the Passage River is broken on both Sides, and all that Country is like a Sea, there being no Passage either for Boats or Waggons; the Boats are forced to go to the Sas of Gaunt, and so by the way of Sluce. The High Way where the Dike is broken, on the North side the River, lies fourteen Foot deep in Water, but many Hands are at Work to repair it.

Monsieur Louvignies continues our Governor here, where he was Yesterday very busy in draw∣ing together our Forces both of Horse and Foot, who were all in Arms in the Market-Place, and the Sabloon, the Ports of the Town, being all kept shut for the more solemn Execution of Vant∣lo the Burgher: He was hanged in the Market Place, and afterwards his Body carry'd out and hung upon a Gibbet by the Fort, which he had designed to betray. After the Execution his Ex∣cellency declared publickly, That the Plot was so well laid, that had it not been prevented by the Spanish Captain's Discovery, it would infalli∣bly have succeeded, and the Fort, and consequent¦ly the Town, would have been taken. Befor his Execution, he confessed the Sentence agains him was just, that he had received for fiv Months past 100 Crowns a Month, Pension from France, and 100 Pistoles upon his first Agreement Some others, that are in Prison upon the sam Account, have not yet been put to the Question
As for his Wife and Sister, he declar'd them in∣nocent of the Plot, and that they knew not what was in the Letters they burnt, which was by his Command.

On Saturday Morning I waited upon D.B. Salinas, who told me, amongst other Discourses, that our Ambassadors at Cologn would not return for En∣gland so soon as was believ'd, there being great Appearance that one of them would go to Vienna and the other to the Hague, in order to His Ma∣jesty's Mediation for a General Peace; but with∣out France quitted all that was taken since the Pyrenean Treaty with Lorrain, and the Imperial Towns in Alsace, there would be no Peace; and said farther, though His Majesty had declar'd a Neutrality, yet 'twas visible by their Proceedings, that the Court of England was at this time as much French as before. I thought not fit to con∣test with him, and so only gave him a calm hearing.

Last Night being in Conversation with a prin∣cipal Person of this Court, who is privy to their most intimate Councils, a Discourse being raised concerning our present War, and His Majesty's making the late Peace, and quitting France; that Gentleman thereupon took an Occasion to say, That it was the Opinion of the wisest Men about his Excellency, that His Majesty had made this Peace with the full Consent of the King of France, which would in the end prove more to that King's Advantage than their Conjunction, and that it was a great Mistake in those, that thought this Peace was made by Constraint of the Parlia∣ment, which he had made rather by his own Ele∣ction; and that the Reasons inducing them here to be of this Opinion, were, That His Majesty
finding so strong an Union against France, that it was like to be a general War in these parts of Europe, and that there was no disinteressed Prince sufficiently puissant to become Mediator; His Majesty therefore by quitting France, and decla∣ring a Neutrality, was the only Prince in Europe able to balance, and consequently to be a Media∣tor, which he had resolv'd upon, and was at this time proposing; and that if the French King could but maintain the War this Summer, His Majesty of England would get so great Advantages by car∣rying away all the Trade, and would be so en∣rich'd by that and the Retrenchment of his Army, that he would the next Year be able, without the Assistance of Parliament, to carry on a War against those that should refuse a reasonable Peace. And that this was so much their Belief here and in Hol∣and, (confirm'd now to them by D. B. S.) that in case they could take His Majesty at an Advantage, upon a sufficient and visible Breach of this Peace by his succouring of France, that they would then prevent his Mediation by declaring against him. He said farther, That they feared either the Mar∣quess de Fresno had not taken that due Caution as he should, in relation to that Article of not giving Succours to the French, or else that he does not take sufficient notice of some Actions since the Peace, which have raised great Jealousies both in Holland and here, as to the Sincerity of His Ma∣jesty's Proceedings herein; and said, That it was apparent these were His Majesty's Intentions in clapping up the Peace, since he continued his Ambassadors still at Cologn, tho' the Work was done to their Hands, whose stay there is only in Order to His Majesty's Mediation, that from be∣ing Parties they may turn Mediators. In fine, he
concluded, That the weight of all depended upon the Success of this Campaign, and that if the French could bear out this Summer against so powerful Opposition without any great Shock, we must then be necessitated here to come to a Treaty in the Winter; and believ'd the Result of all would be, France to quit all their Conquests in Flanders and Holland, except Lisle and Doway, which he was confident they would never part with; Ma∣stricht to be given to us, and Ayre and St. Omers to the French, with the Restitution of Lorrain, and an Accommodement of the Differences in Al∣sace, and that a Peace upon Terms something near this would be the end of this War, notwith∣standing all our great Demands.

This being a Discourse from a Person very con∣siderable in their Councils, by which something of their present Temper may be judged, I thought fit to represent it to your Lordship, humbly be∣seeching your Honour to take my free Relation of these Particulars in good part; since I am of no Faction, nor have any End or Interest, but faithfully to perform that Duty I owe to his Sa∣cred Majesty, and that Service which I shall al∣ways pay to your Lordship with great Zeal and Observance, being in all Humility,

CLOSER.SIGNED: Your Honour's most obedient, and entirely devoted Servant, R. B.

DIV2.HEAD: To Sir ROBERT SOUTHWELL.
DIV2.P:
I am afraid I tire both your self and his Lord∣ship with the long Account I usually give; if so, I beg you will give me a little Caution, and I will be sure to govern my self according∣ly. Our last Letters from England, which were of the 30th past, and brought Orders for their Excellencies Returns, came too late to go by the Post, and so went not till Yesterday, and will not be with them 'till to morrow Morning; but his Excellency writes me Word by his of the 10th instant, that they are preparing for their Return though they had not then receiv'd their Orders, finding the Emperor's Ambassador begin to demes∣nage; and says he will send me the precise Time and Day of their Departure, desiring that I would give them a meeting in Holland, in their Passage, it being absolutely necessary in relation to some Affairs they have there, and that it will not take me up above five or six Days at most; in which time I will take Care the Wheel shall go in my Absence; and I beseech you to assure his Lord∣ship, that I will return with all imaginable Dili∣gence to my Station re. It will be the latter end of the next Week, I presume, before I can have an Assurance from his Excellency upon what Day they will depart: o that I shall scarce go from hence till Monday sennight, and shall be sure to give you a precise Account when I go, and when I shall return. I am in great want of Monsieur Theue, who has been absent above a Fortnight: I had much Light from him, he being daily with his Excellency. When I was at Antwerp I made
inquiry after him where he lodged; but from thence he went to an Irish Pastor in Flanders, and I have never since heard of him, nor know not where to send to him, to hasten him back; for if he were here in my Absence, I could well di∣rect how you should have a good Account. I intend writing to him to morrow by an English Je∣suit here, who tells me he will direct my Letters to him; and I hope he will be back before my going for Holland, and I will so contrive it, that I will not be absent above two Posts.

My whole Dependence is upon you, as to what Allowance his Lordship will please to give me, and I should be glad to be at a Certainty, that I might the better know how to govern my self. I can assure you my Charges are very great, all things growing dearer than ordinary, by reason of the Placaert for all House-keepers to store them∣selves with Provisions for two Months. I am necessitated to keep two Horses, the Charges of which are great, and my Journies to and again upon Occasions, with postage of Letters, not on∣ly from England but from other Places where I have a constant Correspondence, costs me much; besides, the Pains I take is more than ordinary, having only Sunday in the whole Week free to my self; but I confess when their Excellencies are re∣mov'd from Cologn it will not be so much. I humbly submit all to your Management, desiring you will please to manage it so tenderly, that his Lordship may not think I would not refer it wholly to his Generosity; but however, I beg you will get such Directions from him, that Mr. Thompson may have a general Order from you to furnish me with such a Proportion Monthly as may supply my present Occasions, that I may
not run in debt, and lose my Credit, for then I shall be able do his Lordship no Service. Mr. Ni∣pho had an Allowance of 20 s. a Day, and yet kept no Horse, and had all extraordinary Char∣ges paid, of sending Letters and Expresses; and I am sure I shall do as much Service as ever he did.
