I give you this Account more particularly, that you may the better know how to discourse it with his Lordship; but in the interim, I beg you will please to send a Letter to Mr. Thompson, that he may give me some Credit upon Occasion, for there may some Accident happen that may require my sudden co∣ming my self to give an Account of it. But I must beg your Pardon that I give you so great a Trouble in my Concerns, which your own Gene∣rosity and Kindness to me has brought upon you.

The Baron, I perceive by his Letter this Day, stays his Journey to accompany the Ambassadors. I must humbly beg you will give my hearty Service to Mr. Knatchbull, with my Excuse for not answer∣ing his kind Letter, and be pleas'd to accept of my humble Acknowledgment for the Favour you did in satisfying him for his Nagg. Mr. Lynch writes me Word, that if the Prince Barbanson went over before the Convoy, he would send my Ladies things in the Yatch, which I hope are come to her Ladiship by this; and I believe I shall have a Pair of very fine Servers to send over with the Ambassador's things from Antwerp, if not, to carry with me into Hol∣land, and so send them over by them.
And now 'tis time to put an end to your present trouble, by assuring you that I am with all due Re∣spect and Observance,

CLOSER.SIGNED: Your most obedient, faithful, and most obliged Servant, R. B.

DIV2.P: ON Friday Morning before his Excellency's De∣parture for Antwerp, he gave a Visit to the Condestabless of Colonna in the English Cloister, and there promis'd her if she would return to the Castle of Antwerp, she should not only have the liberty of it, but also sometimes to take a Turn in the City at the Tour la Mode, provided she should not alight from her Coach, but that some∣times in the Fields she should have liberty to walk; to which she willingly consented, and on Saturday Morning was convoy'd to Antwerp. 'Tis said his Excellency has receiv'd Orders from Rome for giving her this Liberty, upon Complaints sent thither of her strict Confinement, and like∣wise of the great Disturbance and Offence the Guard of Soldiers gave to the Religious. 'Tis thought she may towards the end of Summer re∣turn again for Italy.

We hear his Excellency finds but little ground for the Imprisonment of those Persons at Antwerp, that the Scout has been some Days since released, and the rest are like to be suddenly discharged; but I presume your Lordship will receive a more particular Account of that Affair from Mr. Nipho who is upon the Place. His Excellency returns not hither till towards the end of the Week, ha∣ving sent Yesterday for his Secretaries thither to make the Dispatches for Spain.

We hear there has been some tampering by the French at our Garrison at Lieuue to have had a Half-Moon deliver'd up, but it was discover'd and
prevented. The Deputy-Governour is secured, and sent away to Tilmont, to which Place he is con∣fin'd at present; but whether he were guilty of Treachery is not said. On Saturday eleven Spanish Companies of the Regiment of Velasco were drawn out of Lieune, and sent to Namur for the far∣ther strengthning that Place, upon intimation that the French design either upon that Place or Mons in these Parts, or Ypres in Flanders.

Last Night the Marquis d' Assenlart came hither by his Excellency's Command, having given him an Account of his Negotiation at the Hague. He assures us the Holland Troops are now marching, and that in fifteen Days Count Waldeck will be here with Seventeen thousand Foot and Eight thousand Horse. Great Preparations are making for the Lodgment of Ten thousand Men about this City, which we intend to have all this Campaign here, and Baracks are preparing round the Town accordingly, and the Fortifications are hastning with all imaginable Diligence. His Excellency's Resolutions are to have all his Garrisons well pro∣vided with Men and Ammunition, and with a Flying Army to attend the French Motions; and if they shall besiege any Place, he will be able to draw an Army of near Fifty thousand Men into the Field to raise their Siege. In the Interim we are resolv'd that the French Bravadoes shall not anger us into a Battel nor their Violence force us to fight, but upon great Advantage, being resol∣ved to take all, but to give no Advantage. I wish the Success of this Campaign may answer our Ex∣pectation; but usually when Men lay too great weight upon such Props, they are apt to break: The truth is, we are much encourag'd by all the Encounters we have lately had with the French,
wherein we have still succeeded, and that is a good Omen to begin a Campaign with, all their De∣signs having hitherto been broken.

This Afternoon an Express is come from the Duke de Bournovile, which tells us, that Monsieur Bovessey a French Major-General, and an old Lor∣rain Officer with Six hundred Horse, most of them Reform'd Officers and Gentlemen, plac'd himself in Ambuscado to have fallen upon a Quarter of the Duke's; but he having timely notice where and when they intended their Ambuscado, drew out Parties several ways, and so fell upon them, kill'd Two hundred upon the Place, and eighty Prisoners taken, most Officers and Gentlemen, and Monsieur Bovessey himself shot through the Body.

We have receiv'd certain Advice from Flushing that Two thousand Spaniards are arrived there, one entire Regiment of a thousand Men, the o∣ther thousand in distinct Companies for recruiting the old Regiments here: His Excellency sent them Orders to fail to Ostend, where we believe by this time they are safely arrived.

We hear also that Monsieur Rapenhaut that com∣mands Six hundred Hollanders against the Bishop of Munster, hath taken Newheuson in Westphalia, wherein were Five hundred Men: That eight Re∣giments of French are sent by Monsieur Belleford for the Assistance of the Bishop of Munster, but that the Bishop is like to be attacked on all sides.

From Burgundy we can hear no News yet of the Duke of Lorrain's Advance thither, which gives us much trouble, that after all the Moneys he has receiv'd, and the Promises he has made of mar∣ching with such a considerable Army thither, he should now fail us when we most needed him;
for which we are not backward in speaking very harshly of him.

This is all the News which at present occurs here worth your Lordship's Notice; and I must humbly presume upon your Lordship's Favour, to pardon my absence for two or three Posts, whilst I make a step to Rotterdam to meet their Excel∣lencies, which they most earnestly desire, both to convoy some things to them from Antwerp, and to adjust some Matters with their Excellencies there: But I shall take such Care here in my ab∣sence, that whatever of moment passes, your Lord∣ship shall have an Account of it by Sir Robert Southwell, to whom I have order'd a Friend at Court here to write. In the interim I humbly throw my self at your Honour's Feet, being with all Zeal and Humility,

CLOSER.SIGNED: Your Lordship's most obedient, humble, and most entirely devoted Servant, R. B.

DIV2.P:
AFter four Days being at Sea betwixt Rotter∣dam and this Place, I arriv'd here but last Night late, and so could not reach Brussels this Day time enough to write by the Post, and there∣fore thought best to give your Lordship an Account from hence, though not so full as I might have
done had I been at Brussels, whither I shall hasten to morrow Morning.

Notwithstanding our vigorous Preparations here, and that all the Prince of Orange's Army is now in these Parts to the number of Thirty thousand, yet the French have adventur'd to besiege the Fort of Navagne, which stands upon the River betwixt Maestricht and Visel, a small Fort of four Bastions, but of great consequence, it being the only Fort and Pass we have upon that River for keeping our Correspondency with Limbourgh. The French have rais'd three Batteries against it of twelve Pieces each; and I heard the Rhinegrave this Day say, that unless it were relieved in fix Days it would be yielded.

His Highness the Prince of Orange is gone from his Quarters at Duffle, near Malines, this Morning, to confer with his Excellency at Brussels, that their Armies may be put in some better Posture than they are at present, the Country suffering extreme∣ly by them, and no Order nor Discipline amongst them, which makes the most sober People much doubt the Success of our Campaign: And 'tis more than whisper'd that there are great Discon∣tents and Divisions amongst our great Officers at Brussels, which has taken wind amongst the Dutch Officers, who speak of it with much regret.

Before the French laid Siege to Navagne they took the Castle of Argenteau, betwixt Visel and Leige, a small Castle, but thought impregnable, being upon a high Rock and a deep Graff round, and the coming to it almost inaccessible; there were taken in it a Company of Foot, and the French are now undermining of it with intentions to blow it up. It's believ'd that when Navagne is taken they will besiege Limburgh: This unexpected
Action of the French does much surprize us; for we thought they durst not have attempted any thing, but only stood upon their Defence: But we are like to find the contrary, for the Prince of Conde is said to be at Binch attending our Motion, that if we stir that way he is ready to follow us with a considerable Army; and the truth is we are not as yet in a condition to march, our Army not being yet modelled as it should be, and the Holland Army are so unruly and ill govern'd that we know not what to do with them, most of the Officers coming into this Place and other Towns neglecting the Care of their Companies and Troops. His Highness returns again this Night to his Quarters, and 'tis thought the Army will draw to a general rendezvous on Thursday, in order to attempt something upon the Enemy.
My Lord Castlehaven is sent to Ruremond to command there, and to take care that considerable Place be put into a good Posture, there being in it near Two thousand Men Horse and Foot.

By the next I shall be able from Brussels to give your Lordship a more particular Account: In the interim I humbly beg leave to throw my self at your Lordship's Feet, and to subscribe my self with all imaginable Zeal and Duty,

CLOSER.SIGNED: Your Lordship's most obedient, most humble, and most entirely devoted Servant, R. B.

DIV2.HEAD: To Sir ROBERT SOUTHWELL.
DIV2.P: I Have had so bad a Passage from Rotterdam hi∣ther, that Sir Thomas Sandys and my self have been four Days in coming hither, and arri∣ved last Night but a quarter of an Hour before so dreadful a Tempest happen'd, that had we been in it we had been in great danger of being lost. I was so ill and weary with my Voyage, that I could not possibly reach Brussels this Day time e∣nough to write by the Post, and therefore have given his Lordship a short Account from hence; and to morrow Morning I intend early for Brus∣sels, from whence you shall hear from me more at large by the next.

The French have taken Argenteau, a small Castle standing upon an inaccessible Place in the Spanish Territories on the other side the Maese, betwixt Visel and Liege, wherein were a, Company of Foot; the French are undermining it to blow it up.

The Fort of Navagne standing upon the same River, which was the only Bridle to Maestricht is besieged, and by some said to be taken; but if it be not reliev'd within six Days, of which we yet see no likelihood, 'twill certainly be lost:
The Prince of Conde is with a considerable Army about Binch waiting our Motions, that if we stir towards raising the Siege of Navagne he will be ready to follow us.

This Day the Prince of Orange is gone to Brus∣sels to confer with his Excellency about drawing the Army to a general rendezvous, but it is veri∣ly believ'd Navagne will be lost before we can be
in Condition to relieve it, which will be an ill Beginning of the Campaign, and a great disheart∣ning to the Army. I must beg your Patience till the next, and then I shall give you a better Ac∣count. I am with much Respect, and great Truth,

CLOSER.SIGNED: Your most obedient humble Servant, R. B.

DIV2.P:
SINCE the taking Navagne, we have this Ac∣count from Leige, That there was but one Man killed within the Fort, and but thirty French without; that Preparations are making for blow∣ing it up, which is not yet done; that the Prince is march'd back towards Charleroy; that on Friday his Army encamped between Tongres and Leige, and on Saturday the Van Guard of his Army came to Perwy, not far from Gemblours, taking the way of the Grand Chaussey. 'Tis thought his Inten∣tions are to cover his Garrisons in Flanders, and to be ready upon the Defensive, either to march towards the Sea-Coast if the Dutch Fleet attempt any thing on that Side, or else to oppose any Design we may have upon the conquer'd Places; and we talk as if we should attempt Courtray, and by that means secure the River Lis, and so
proceed to Armentiers and Lisle. But these are only Conjectures.

Sunday Night we had News from the Duke de Bournouile, that some of the Imperial Recruits were come to him, that the Munster Troops were upon their March with all Diligence, that the 24th in∣stant General Souches was expected at Bonn, and that by the 26th it was hoped he would be with the Army near Limbourg, that upon his Arrival the Duke de Bournouile goes back to command the imperial Army in the Palatinate; in the interim, his Excellency has sent Orders to the Duke de Bournouile to advance this way with his Troops, and that the Recruits should follow; and ac∣ordingly we hear that the Van of his Army ar∣rived the last Night not far from Namur.

On Sunday Morning Monsieur Louvignies was sent by his Excellency to the Prince of Orange to see in what forwardness the Prince's Army was, and with him went the Quarter-master General to give them an Enlargement of Quarters. At their Return 'twas told his Excellency, That there was more English than Dutch spoken at his Highness's Table, and that they fear the English Court has too great an Influence upon his Highness's Coun∣cils, and a small Matter is enough to raise a great Jealousy amongst us here. All Persons admire our flow Progress, and our Military Men begin to speak loud against it, being generally much discontented; neither does the Prince escape their Censure, believing him not to be so throughly stanch in our Concerns as we expected. We com∣plain that his Army is not yet ready, and he re∣torts the same upon us, and that not without Cause, since in Truth we are neither of us ready; all our Forces not being yet come together, nei∣ther
are the Friezeland Troops come up to the Prince; besides, his Train of Artillery, consisting of thirty six Pieces, were but disembarked on Sun∣day at Malines, and are not yet mounted, neither has he as yet Horses sufficient for his Train of Ar∣tillery and Carriages. Yesterday his Highness changed his Quarters, and advanced nearer Lou∣vain, having fourteen or fifteen fresh Villages ap∣pointed for his Army, those he hath hitherto had be∣ing quite eaten up. His Army commits so great Disorders, that the Boors are feign to quit their Habitations, and come hither to complain; and notwithstanding his Highness has publish'd strict Orders for the better Regulation of his Army, yet it is altogether ineffectual, the Soldiers saying in their Defence, they do not so much Harm here, as our Auxiliaries did to them in Holland; which cau∣ses many to say, They come rather to revenge than help. I wish we may find good Success by their Assistance, but I much fear the Continuance of our good Correspondence, and that we shall eve∣ry Day see greater Differences than other.

The Duke de Villa Hermosa, with four thousand Horse and Dragoons, has been for three or four Days in the Campaign, betwixt this and Vilvord, along the Rivage; the rest of our Army are up∣on their March from several Places; and part of our Train of Artillery, consisting of twelve Field-pieces, and near an hundred Waggons, are drawn up in the Park under the Court, ready to be spann'd at an Hours warning; and we say that our own particular Army, which shall march into the Cam∣paign, will be about eighteen thousand Men, of which seven thousand are Horse, one thousand five hundred Dragoons, and betwixt nine and ten thou∣sand Foot; and we are told the Prince of Orange's
Army will be thirty five thousand effective Men, and the Imperial Army near as many. But with all these Armies there is nothing yet done but ruining the Country; and we now too late see the fatal oversight we committed in suffering the Conjunction of the Prince and Bellefond, which will put us to the playing an After-Game, where∣in we are like to run great Hazard; whereas we might easily have ruined both those Armies apart, with whom we shall now find enough to do. Yesternight we had News from the Prince of Con∣de's Camp, which was then not far from Perwy, towards Charleroy, that they gave several Vollies of Shot throughout their Army, and three Peal of Ordnance; the Cause of which we knew not, 'till early this Morning that we have received the surprizing News of the Loss of the Citadel of Besançon, and consequently of that whole Pro∣vince; that the King of France is marching this way with his Houshold, and Court, and Body of his Army, having nothing more to do in Burgun∣dy but the reducing some Forts and Castles, which a small Force will easily do. This Account his Excellency received in the Night, and in the Mor∣ning about five went in Person to visit the Princess of Vaudemont, who had also several Letters. 'Tis said the Prince de Vaudemont was used with great Civility by the King, who sent an Escort to con∣vey him and his Followers to his Father's Army. This News has made so great an Alteration in our Councils, that we scarce know what Measures to take, and now find to our Cost the ill Consequen∣ces of not granting a Neutrality to Burgundy.

Before these Letters came we were puffed up with the Thoughts of what great things we would do upon our Conjunction with the German Troops,
and now we are all so out of Countenance that we know not how to look upon each other; nei∣ther has his Excellency appear'd in publick this Day, though the Rhinegrave, and many Holland Officers were at Court; and now we speak not a Word of Marching, which before we were full of.

My Lord Castlehaven is gotten into Stevenswert with five hundred Germans, for the Security of that Place, being a Fort upon the Meuse, betwixt Ruremond and Maseyk, which he did by Com∣mand from his Excellency; but now the Prince of Conde is marched this way 'tis said he will be recalled from thence.

I was Yesterday to wait upon Count Egmond with whom our Master de Camp General had been two Hours in private. After his Departure, I found the Count much discontented, who told me in Confidence, that his Excellency would feign engage him to stay here this Campaign, and to undertake the Care of this Place, by reason of his great Interest with the Nobility, Gentry, and Citizens, and with the Country in general; to which the Count has given an absolute Refusal, unless he may have such a considerable Body of Horse and Foot with him, that he may not lose his Reputation by a seeming Defence, when he is not in a Condition to make it good. He also told the Master de Camp General how he had often represented his Condition to the Court of Spain, and also to his Excellency, that all his E∣state was confiscated in the French Dominions, his Woods to a hundred thousand Guilders cut down and sold, that he was unable longer to subsist, or bear up that Port that became his Quality, that no Care had been hitherto taken of him, nor the
least Compensation given him, that at present he was resolved to go into this Campaign with two Valets de Chambres, two Grooms, and two Foot∣men, not having Horses to draw his Waggons, nor Money to provide them; that however he would serve the King of Spain in Condition of a private Trooper, rather than stay here in the Condition his Excellency proposed. This Passage I thought fit to relate to your Lordship, having it from the Count's own Mouth, which I heard with much Sorrow and Regret, to see a Person of that great Nobility, Honour and Merit, reduced to such Extremities, whilst other inconsiderable Per∣sons have what they please.
I have no farther Trouble to give your Lord∣ship, but humbly to throw my self at your Ho∣nour's Feet, being with all Zeal and Duty ima∣ginable,

CLOSER.SIGNED: Your Lordship's most obedient, most humble, and most intirely devoted Servant, R. B.

DIV2.P:
ON Wednesday Night arrived here the Prince de Vaudemont; he came post from Besançon with the King of France's Passeport, whose Civi∣lity to him he much extolls. He was received
very kindly by his Excellency, whom he has ass∣ur'd, that the whole Franche County may now be gi∣ven for lost. He says the Governor of the Coun∣try, Don Alvedo, has put himself into the Castle of St. Anne, expecting only honourable Conditi∣ons; and 'tis thought by this time Dole is surren∣dred, and that the several Castles and Forts yet remaining, will be soon reduced, since there is no Hopes of Relief. He says that never such Exe∣cution was done with Canon as against that Cit∣tadel, it being made quite level, four hundred and odd kill'd in seven Days time with Cannon-Shot, eighteen thousand and odd hundred great Shot being made against it; that the Dexterity of their Canoneers was such, that no Musqueteer could shoot with greater Exactness, five several Centinels being kill'd upon the same Ground suc∣cessively in an Hours Time with the same piece of Canon. We have lost several Persons of Quality, besides Soldiers; the Prince has a slight Wound in his Face by a Stone struck up with a Canon Ball, and when he found the desperate Condition they were in, he caused all the Horse that were there to be turn'd out into the Counterscarp, that they might be useless to the French, being most of them kill'd between both Parties; they had no other Conditions but to come out with white Sticks in their Hands. His Majesty has put into it a Garrison of Switzers, with a Swiss Gover∣nor, which gives the Cantens great Satisfaction; his Majesty having thereby assur'd them, That he only seeks the Defence of his own Territories, and no Increachment upon theirs.

The Prince says the Duke d'Enguien is march∣ing hither with ten thousand Men, four thousand Horse, and six thousand Foot, to join his Father's
Army; that His Majesty, he believes, is gone back to Paris, having left a sufficient Army to reduce the rest of those Places, and to secure his Conquest there; which is look'd upon here to be more con∣siderable than all the Conquests he made in Hol∣land, this being a real Security to his own Country, which before lay open that way.

We have now given over all Discourse of the D. of Lorrain, his Army being very inconsiderable, and Marshal Turene so posted, that if the Duke were stronger he could do nothing. We are much in∣raged against the Switzers, at whose Door we lay the Loss of Burgundy, and threaten more Revenge against them than we shall be ever able to take.

Captain Mackully, a Captain in the Scotch Re∣giment here, who put himself voluntarily into Navagne with thirty Men, just as it was besieged, came hither Yesterday by his Excellency's Order, to give him an Account of the Condition and Rendition of that who says there was but fo uned in it, and the most of those free Coans who signifie very little; that there was not ms sufficient for the Soldiers, being in great want of Musquets, and so ill provided for a Siege in relation to Provision, that the Soldiers were forced to drink Water those few Days they were besieged; which was such a Negligence as is scarce to be credited, since they have been in daily Expectation of a Siege ever since the War was declared. He says farther, That if they had not surrendered when they did they must have lost it upon the Attack, and that it was a Batallion of my Lord Douglas's Regiment that were entred the Trenches to have attacked them, who first entred and took Possession of the Fort. He says Argntau is razed, and that the Soldiers had been
two Hours at work in demolishing Navagne; but then came fresh Orders from the Prince to hold up, and repair the Breaches, which they are now doing, and have plac'd a considerable Garrison in it.

Yesterday his Excellency accompanied with Marquis d' Assenlaer and Prince de Vaudemont went to meet the Prince of Orange at Dinner at Foun∣tain, near Vilvord, and return'd in the Evening. 'Tis said, and that by good Hands, that the Prince of Orange expresses great Dissatisfaction at our Pro∣ceedings, and taxes his Excellency not to have per∣form'd his Promise in having Twenty five thousand Men ready to take the Field when his Highness's Army should be ready; instead whereof, he says, he knows well his Excellency cannot draw above Ten thousand into the Field▪ and leave his Garri∣sons provided; whereas his Highness says he has over perform'd his Promise, having at this instant within these Territories Thirty thousand effective Foot, Eight thousand Horse, and Two thousand Drag ons: And this I heard Monsieur Fario affirm Yesterday t Dinner. To this 'tis said his Excel∣lency answers▪ that he intended a considerable Bo∣dy of the Hllanders to be put into our Garrisons, and the Spaniards and Germans to be drawn out; and that he likewise reckon'd upon the German Recruits who are not yet come up. How these Differences will he reconciled I cannot say; but this is certain that there is great Confusion in our Councils. All this Morning his Excellency has been in Council with the General Officers of his Army; but what Resolutions are taken as to the Campaign are not yet publick. In all appearance we shall not take the Field so soon as was expected, for our Troops that were come with Lieutenan
General Agourto from Cambray as far as Valenci∣ennes in order to join our Army here, are com∣manded back again; and our Troops that were coming from Flanders hither are also counterman∣ded. The Horses for our Train of Artillery and Carriages being very numerous, having eaten up all the Grass on that side the Town towards Vilvord, are now remov'd on the other side betwixt the Hall and the Flanders Ports; and when those Mea∣dows are destroy'd, I know no other remove but into the French Quarters. The truth is, all sober People are amazed at our Conduct, and cannot imagine what end we propose; for 'tis not to be believ'd that the Prince of Conde will fit still, when the Duke of Enguien is join'd, and in the interim we ruin our Country and do nothing. The Prince at present lies encamped with his Army a League on this side Charleroy, where they have plenty of all sorts of Provisions, having amassed a vast quan∣tity at Binch and those Quarters, that their Army cannot want. From Bouchain Letters say, that in Kenway and Landrecy great store of Provisions is made, and vast quantities of Ammunition-bread baked, that all the Mills in the Towns and Coun∣try round have Orders to grind Corn incessantly, which makes them judge the Prince will draw that way.

We know no more as yet of the Imperialists than what I wrote in my last, only this, we hear they begin already to demand Pay, without which they will not only plunder the Country, which they do already sufficiently, but they will quick∣ly moulder away; and however we flatter our selves, yet we are told, they will not advance much farther from their Borders than they are al∣ready, being not at all desirous of a conjunction
with us; so that upon the whole matter, the Opi∣nion of the most prudent Men is, that we shall be necessitated in few Months to make a Peace, and that not upon so good Terms as we might have done before the Campaign. For the Prince of Orange (finding he is principally engaged in this War for our Assistance, and that we are in no condition of doing what he expected and we promised) seems not so eagerly to press it as we imagin'd; and unless some extraordinary Success at Sea should give him farther Encouragement, we believe he will proceed but very coldly; for some of his principal Officers say, if any Advan∣tage be gotten at Land, the Spaniards or Imperia∣lists will have it, and that their Army is like only to be weaken'd; and therefore we begin to be ap∣prehensive that when our Country is wasted, and no more Subsistance for his Army, he will then retire as he did the Winter-Campaign.

'Tis said that Orders are sent after de Ruiter to proceed very warily and not hazard much; but we are here so confident of his Success, that it was hotly reported on Tuesday-night late, that Dunkirk was besieg'd and no Men in it to make Defence, and on Wednesday Calais was taken; and so every Day a Sea-Port is taken with us.

My Lord Castlehaven writes from Stevenswert of the 30th past, that he was there with Count Mansfe and Five hundred Germans believing the French would have attack'd that Place; that accor∣dingly he was putting all things there in the best Posture he could for their Defence, which his Ex∣cellency had order'd him to make to the utmost, assuring him of Relief in case it should be besie∣ged; but that Fear being now over. I presume his Lordship will be suddenly recall'd from that hole.
I have nothing else to add, but humbly to throw my self at your Honour's Feet, in the Quality of,

CLOSER.SIGNED: Your Lordship's most obedient, most humble, and most intirely devoted Servant, R. B.

DIV2.P: I Am forced to write with great Uncertainty to your Honour, since our Councils here are so ill founded, that what is resolved one day is set aside the next; for notwithstanding the Resolution taken on Friday last for the Prince of Orange's Ar∣my to pass the Canal, and to incamp on this side, as I then told your Lordship, yet the Prince, upon farther Consultation with his General Officers, and upon the Account the French Marquis gave him of the Place, that it lay very open to be attack'd, thought it not convenient to remove his Army, unless ours was also ready to march with him; and so his Highness still continues his Quarters, and has only changed some Towns for Refreshment of his Army.

On Sunday the Duke of Holstein being out with his Regiment brought in near thirty Prisoners, and One hundred and twenty Horses belonging to Carriages and Baggage, which he took about three Leagues from Charleroy. The same Night a Party
of fifty Horse went out again, expecting another Booty, but had the Misfortune to fall in with a Party of Five hundred French Horse, by whom they were all taken Prisoners or kill'd; the same time the French pillaged and burnt the Village of Borche three Leagues from hence.

On Sunday at Noon a Peasant of Burgundy came hither with an Express to his Excellency from the Governour there; he passed both the French Ar∣mies, and yet escap'd searching: The Contents of his Letters were kept very private, and none suf∣fer'd to discourse with him, whereby we judge his News was not very pleasing.

His Excellency is in daily expectation of an ex∣traordinary Currier from Spain, with a Commis∣sion for the Prince Vaudemont to be General of the Strangers here, and command all the Horse as Lieutenant-General under the Duke de Villa Her∣mosa, and that all other Lieutenant-Generals and Serjeant-Generals of Battel shall obey him; and it is intended that he shall command our Army of Horse this Campaign, if the Duke de Villa Her∣mosa can be prevail'd with to stay and command here, which his Excellency much labours in. However, 'tis thought this new Command will make great Divisions in the Army, and that the two Lieutenant-Generals Agourto and de Velasco will quit their Employments upon it, though 'tis cer∣tain there is no Man here so fit for that Employ∣ment as the Prince.

The Disgusts between his Highness and Excellen∣cy rather increase than lessen, and are like to be∣get greater Difficulties in our Army, than any Op∣position from the French, his Highness continuing much dissatisfied with the Weakness of our Army, and is resolv'd, as 'tis said, not to divide his.
The Nobility in general seem extremely sensible of our ill Condition, and of the imprudent Manage∣ment of Affairs, it being impossible for us to draw together any more of our Spanish Forces, than what we have here already, neither will the Prince of Orange put his Army to any hazard, till ours be in condition to march with him.

The Prince of Conde's Army still continues en∣camp'd near Charleroy, and he is in Person diver∣ting himself at the pleasant Seat of the Count Buc∣quoy's at Farcine. All our Hopes are, that he will lay Siege to some Place, whereby we may draw our Forces together out of the several Garrisons, wherein our Army at Present lies dispersed; or else, that part of his Army will be commanded away, and then we shall be strong enough to take the Field, and march into his Quarters: But the Prince so well knowing the present strait we are in, will scarce be induc'd to give us that Advan∣tage we desire.

His Excellency has sent a very considerable Sum of Money to the German Troops; and we are told that Three thousand which have been raised in Germany by the Spanish Ambassador, are marching this way towards our Army, and are to pass by Ruremond, where my Lord Castlehaven, 'tis said, shall stay till their Arrival, and then march hither with them. His Lordship being again comman∣ded from Stevenswert to Ruremond.

Last Night at Six his Excellency, accompanied with Monsieur Louvignies, went to his Highness's Quarters at Duffle to confer about taking some pre∣sent Resolution concerning the Armies, and this Morning at two he return'd, and immediately af∣ter dispatched an Express in great Diligence to General Souches, directed to him at Duitz over a∣gainst
Cologne. This Day likewise several of ou Train-Horses are gone to Malines to fetch some great Pieces of Artillery from the Magazine there.

From Limburg we hear that the Imperial Army is marching back towards Treves to besiege that Place, hoping by that means to divert the Prince of Conde to look that way, that so we may draw our Army together; which as yet we cannot do without endangering the Places they are in, and likewise endangering the Troops being cut off in their Passage.

We say that the Prince of Conde has already sent away Four thousand Horse to join Marshal Turene; and that the Imperial Army in the Palati∣nate being join'd with the Duke of Lorrain have besieg'd Philipsburg, which will cause the King to send his Forces from Burgundy thither, before he has quite compleated his Conquest there.

This Day at Court it was hotly reported, that the Prince de Vaudemont has this Post receiv'd Ad∣vertisement from Paris that the Duke de St. Ger∣mans has obtain'd a considerable Victory against the French in Catalonia; but this, we presume, is invented to divert the common Discourses of our Affairs here, the Management of which is sharply inveigh'd against, and such bitter Comments made of it, that his Excellency by a severe Placaert has strictly forbidden all Discourses of News, or of the Armies, or their Actions, or Generals, under a very great Penalty, so that no Man dares ask publickly any News.

I am told this Day from a good Hand, that his Excellency by this last Post from England receiv'd a Letter from the Marquis de Fresnoe, wherein he roundly told his Excellency how much his Repu∣tation
was lessen'd abroad, by suffering Navagne to be so pitifully lost, and very smartly taxed the ill reported Conduct of his Affairs; and that he for his own part was out of Countenance at these unexpected Proceedings, having been all along blown up by his Excellency with a Belief in what good Posture things were here, and what great Actions would be done, which were all come to nothing.
I have nothing more to trouble your Lordship with, but to lay my self low at your Honour's Feet, being with greatest Zeal and Duty,

CLOSER.SIGNED: Your Honour's most obedient, most humble, and most intirely devoted Servant, R. B.

DIV2.P:
ON Tuesday Evening Lieutenant-General Don Marco de Valasco receiv'd Orders from the Duke de Villa Hermosa to draw out the Troops for his Excellency's View, which the Lieutenant Ge∣neral did; but understanding his Excellency's In∣tention was to give the Command of the Horse to Prince Vaudemont, he absented himself. His Ex∣cellency coming to the Head of the Troops, and missing the Lieutenant-General, sent two several Adjutants for him; but he having no mind to ap∣pear,
would not be found. Whereupon his Ex∣cellency in great Anger declar'd to all the Officers (since he had not found the Lieutenant-General at the Head of the Troops according to his Duty) that they should no more own him as Lieutenant-General, nor give any Obedience to him: And then farther signified his Pleasure, That Prince Vaude∣mont (whom he stiled General of the Horse in Burgundy) should be own'd and obey'd by them as Governour of all the Cavalry, and to command them in chief next to the Duke de Villa Hermosa, and his Excellency did then put him in Possession of that Charge.

The next Morning the Lieutenant-General came to the Duke de Villa Hermosa, and declar'd his Rea∣sons why he did not attend. And that as to the Affront his Excellency had put upon him, by en∣deavouring to take away his Charge, he expected no better from him; but that it was given him by the King of Spain, and was not in his Excellency's Power to take from him. And that it might appear he would not retard his Majesty's Service in this Conjuncture, he was resolv'd still to continue his Charge, and obey Prince Vaudemont till his Com∣plaint should be heard at the Court of Spain.

He farther told the Duke that his Excellency had put a double Injury upon him, first in not putting the King of Spain's Orders in Execution, wherein all Serjeant-Generals of Battel were com∣manded to obey the two Lieutenant-Generals, and now in imposing a General to command them, who had been a private Colonel only under them; and this not only without any Orders from Spain, but directly contrary to the Tenor of the King's Patent to them, wherein they are ordered to obey no General but the Duke de Villa Hermosa.

The same Morning the Prince de Salm wrote to his Excellency, taking notice that his Excellency having made a new General of the Cavalry, who had lately in this Service (as being a younger Col∣lonel) been under his Command, he thereupon thought fit to acquaint his Excellency, that it was not for a Person of his Post and Quality to be commanded by him who was so lately under his Command; and that therefore his Excellency might dispose of his Regiment, for he would serve no longer in that Quality, but would accompany the Army this Campaign as a Voluntier. His Ex∣cellency has hereupon sent to the Prince de Salm, and employ'd all that have Interest in him to ac∣cept of his Charge again, and that he will ingage to have him made a Serjeant-General of Battel; but the Prince absolutely refused, and last Night sent to his Excellency for his Discharge, which was this Day given him.

This has occasion'd various Discourses in Court, and no small murmuring in the Army, which is like to be more increased by the Disposal of the Regiment to a Reformed Major of Horse, (which 'tis said his Excellency has promised) for then four of the best Lieutenant-Colonels in the Army will quit their Employments (viz.) the Duke of Hol∣stein, the Prince de Salm, the Marquis Morebeck, and Baron Cunier; the Marquis de Leda likewise pretends for the Regiment, but his Excellency has not yet declar'd himself therein.

On Wednesday Morning at Three the Marquis d' Assenlart went privately from hence to the Prince of Orange's Quarters, where the Generals were most part of that Day in Council; and Yesterday the Marquis and Count Waldeck went together to meet with General Souches about Juliers, his Ar∣my
being at present quarter'd about Duren, and with him they are to adjust all Matters relating to this Campaign; and till their Return all things here are at a stand, which makes all People talk at random, the very Holland Pamphlets not for∣bearing to jeer us. It's verily believ'd the Impe∣rialists will march directly for Lorrain after taking of Treves, which they think will not hold them many Days when once besieg'd; and from Lor∣rain they make account of entring into Burgundy, and recovering all our Losses before this Campaign be ended; but according as we proceed there is lit∣tle sign of doing what we pretend.

It is whisper'd here that there are some bad In∣struments about the Prince of Orange, who do very ill Offices in hindring, at least weak'ning that intire good Correspondence, which ought to be betwixt his Highness and his Excellency, and we are not like∣wise without Disgusts amongst our great Officers. And though this be ill News, yet I fear I shall send your Lordship more of it; for I confess I can∣not foresee in this Constitution of Things, but tha we shall grow worse and worse, till we arrive a the worst of all: For having stumbled so grossly in the very Entrance of the Campaign, we expect nothing but a Fall in the End; and the Impres¦sions which that Miscarriage has made amongst u will scarce be remov'd; for what before was only whisper'd▪ is now loudly spoken every where many Letters having been lately receiv'd from th Imperial Army, wherein all the Fault of not be¦ting Mareschal Bellfond's Army, and relievin Nvgne, is laid at his Excellency's door. Fo when the Duke de Bournovile had sent back h Carages and Baggage to fit his Army for an E¦gagement and that his Vanguard were withi
sight of the French Camp, the Prince of Conde not being then come up: At that instant the Duke re∣ceiv'd positive Orders from his Excellency here, that he should not upon any occasion engage or hazard his Army, when in all proability he had destroy'd the French Army, at least rais'd that Siege.

On Tuesday Night Two thousand French Horse came towards this Place as far as Waterloo, and from thence sent Four hundred Horse very near the Town, who sent a Party of thirty Horse to a little Village without Namur-Port, adjoining to our Counterscarp; it being Seven in the Morning our Horse Guards were gone, and so they took away some Gentlemen's Horses in the Village, and some Forragers, and return'd before our Horse could follow them. In their Retreat the Peasants in∣trapped a Lieutenant and two Troopers; but the French in Revenge plunder'd that Village, and carried away two or three of their Peasants, whom as we hear since) they hang'd in the Highway.

Wednesday in the Morning Captain Palermo of the Marquis Wargnie's Regiment (who was Com∣mandant of the Castle of Argenteau, and surren∣der'd it) was seiz'd at the Court-Gate, disarm'd, and put in Irons, and then sent to the Steen-Port, and Orders presently sent to the Surintendant to make his Process; and 'tis thought he will lose his Life for yielding a Place so inaccessible, that after Agreement to surrender (the Draw-bridge being by Accident burn'd) the French without and they within, were Twenty four Hours after all Diligence used on both sides before the French could get in or they out. The Governour of Na∣vagne being also in Arrest at Ruremond, the Cap∣tain of Master de Camp Scot's Regiment that went
into it after it was besieg'd, was by Order from his Excellency Yesterday examin'd by the Sur∣intendant, to give an Account of that Siege and the Rendition of it, that the Governour may be either farther question'd or clear'd.

On Wednesday the Duke d' Enguien arriv'd at Charleroy; some say with Five thousand Horse, others more, and some less; the certain Number we know not, having but slender Intelligence from those Quarters notwithstanding they are so near us. But this Morning we are told that Yester-Evening the Prince of Conde decamped, and is mar∣ched betwixt Binch and Mons, upon what Design we are yet to seek.
And what was said in the last of the Prince's sending Four thousand Horse towards Mareschal Turene is now contradicted.

Letters came this Day from Burgundy of the last of May, which say the King invested Dole the 26th; that the 27th a Battery was rais'd on that side towards the River, being the weakest Part: That the King had sent the Duke of Luxemburgh with Four thousand Horse to invest Salines, to prevent their making Excursions whilst he was en∣gag'd in the Siege of Dole.

Our Spanish Letters came this Morning, but bring nothing extraordinary; but we are much raised with an Express come from Paris, as 'tis said, wherein is a Confirmation, with the Parti∣culars of the Victory of the Duke de St. Germans against Mareschal Schonberg, who is said to be wounded and taken Prisoner, and all his Cannon and Baggage lost.

The News of the Election of the Crown-Ge∣neral to be King of Poland sounds very harsh in our Ears, the Confirmation of which is this Day
come in several Letters from Germany much to the Regret of the Emperor, and House of Austria; but it's written also that the Lithuanians are so highly dissatisfied, that it's believ'd this Election will cause intestine Wars amongst themselves.

We are told that Four thousand Germans which were raised upon the King of Spain's Account, and embarked at Hamburgh, are arrived in Holland, and from thence are coming to Antwerp; which if true, will be a good Recruit to our Army.
It's said here that Don Pedro Ronquillos our late Surintendant now in Poland, is to come Ambas∣sador in Ordinary into England, after the Ceremo∣nies of the Coronation are there over.

We have now no Talk of fighting here, but what we have in the Streets by the Unruliness of the Hollanders, who are so drunken and disorderly, that no Day passes without Hurt done amongst them, and no Night without a Murder or two in the Streets, where we have had this Week three or four Burghers kill'd. I pray God ei∣ther send us Peace, or more engaged in War; for betwixt both this Country will be quickly ruin'd.
I have nothing else to add, but laying my self low at your Lordship's Feet humbly to beg Pardon for this long Trouble, and leave to subscribe my self with infinite Devotion,

CLOSER.SIGNED: Your Honour's most obedient, most humble, and most entirely devoted Servant, R. B.

DIV2.P:
ON Saturday, being betwixt the two Posts, I took a Turn to Antwerp through the Holland Quarters to see in what Condition they were, and found them as likely Men to fight as I ever saw, both Horse and Foot. The Country betwixt this and Antwerp is miserably wasted, all Provisions both for Horse and Man destroy'd. In my Passage I saw thirty, forty, and fifty Soldiers in a poor Boor's House, and all upon free Quarter both for Horse and Man; so that most of the Boors being quite ruin'd have lest their Habitations. Yesterday the Prince began to march with his Army: All those Troops that were quarter'd near Antwerp, are pas∣sed over the Scheld to Willtbrook, and the Villages thereabout along the Canal, but some Regiments of Horse something higher into the Country, His Highness quarter'd the last Night at the Castle of Monsieur Vandernott at Sems, half an Hour from Malines towards Wellbrook. This Day the Army did not march; and in my Return hither this Mor∣ning on Horse-back, I saw several of their Regi∣ments exercising as I came along, his Highness not permitting any Days intermission without exerci∣sing, but when they are upon their March. The Ertezland Troops are coming up to his Highness▪ Army, being three Regiments of Horse, but what Foot I know not. 'Tis said his Highness will pass the Canal to morrow; and indeed it is time, for those Quarters will not longer maintain them. Hi Ecellency has at to the Magistrates of Am∣ to ppare all Materials ready for making:
Bridge over the Scheld at Antwerp, and Boats and Timber are preparing accordingly.

Yesterday, the Nephew to the Conde de Molina who is design'd Ambassador from Spain to the Crown of Denmark, parted hence with his Lady and Family for Holland, from whence he is to imbark in a States Man of War.

On Sunday about Two in the Morning Marquis d' Assenlaer return'd hither, having first been with Count Waldeck to give his Highness the Prince of Orange an Account of their Negotiation with Ge∣neral Souches at Ruremond, where they met him on Friday last, and all three sign'd a Paper, wherein all things relating to this Campaign were unani∣mously concluded between them, for the carrying on the War with their several Armies as being all but one in Interest. The Imperialists are to pass the Meuse, and march this way, and Orders were given for making the Bridge before the Generals parted, and Yesterday General Souches intended to begin his March. Great Preparations are making about Diest and Louvain, and all those Quarters, for baking Bread for that Army, who 'tis said will be about Diest in few Days, and from thence are design'd to pass towards Namur, and so on towards Guise being all an open Cam∣paign, and that way to enter France, and give a Diversion to the French Armies, whilst we come on upon this side.

His Excellency having notice on Sunday-night, that the Prince of Conde had sen away Six thou∣sand Horse towards Lille, in order as 'twas thought to march towards Ypre; he thereupon commanded Yesterday-morning the Duke de Villa Hermosa with Two thousand Horse to Gaunt, and to march on with all Diligence towards Ypre for Security of
that Garrison. His Excellency likewise sent Mon∣sieur Richards the Burgoignian Collonel, being an old experienc'd Soldier, to go into Ypre for the Assistance of the Baron de Rock the Governour. But last Night his Excellency was assur'd, that those Six thousand Horse were not gone that way, but wheel'd about on the other side of Mons, and that the Prince of Conde is with his whole Army very near it, and has taken up Posts at Roelx, and Chatteau d' Havre, and all round the Town; and has commanded all the Peasants both of Artois and Hannau to bring in Faggots to his Camp, as tho' he intended to besiege it, which much amazes us; because we cannot imagine he designs the besieging of that important Place, so strongly fortified, so well mann'd and victuall'd, that there is want of nothing. There is in it the Regiments of Vaude∣ment, Belle-Rose, Sermiento, Wargnies, and the Irish, besides many free Companies of Foot, with six Companies of Dragoons, and two Regiments of Horse; and therefore cannot conceive he intends to besiege it, but only hovers there upon some other Design, unless the King himself should come in Person. I believe our Armies will now sud∣denly move, and watch the Motions of the French; and if they attack any Place, we are resolved to relieve it, or hazard a Battel.

Our News from Burgundy of the 2d instant, is, that Dole was then much streighten'd, and mi∣serably batter'd with their Canon, and great hurt done with their Mortar-pieces, and that it was then believed it would be surrender'd within fews Days, if not Hours.

His Excellency has disposed of the Prince d Sam's Regiment to the Prince's Lieutenant-Col∣lonel, whereby he has quieted all Parties that
pretended to it, it being his Right to have it.

A Vessel coming from Scotland with One hun∣dred Men, being a part of the Recruits for Mar∣quis Douglas's Regiment, was taken by a Priva∣teer of Ostend, and brought in thither; but ano∣ther Vessel with treble her number got safe into Dunkirk. His Excellency having notice of this, and that the Men were willing to serve here, has sent down Collonel Scot to Ostend with Orders to receive such as are willing to take Service, and to march with them hither, where they shall be muster'd in his Regiment. But his Excellency and Court talk very loud of his Majesty's sending, or at least permitting Recruits to go to the French.
I have nothing else to add, but to lay my self low at your Lordship's Feet, and humbly to sub∣scribe my self with infinite Zeal and Duty,

CLOSER.SIGNED: Your Honour's most obedient, most humble, and entirely devoted Servant, R. B.

DIV2.P:
ON Saturday the Duke of Holstein was dis∣patched by his Excellency to General Souches to hasten his March, and to advertise him where the Prince of Conde's Army was. The same Day our
Master de Camp General, Prince Vaudemont, Count Waldec, Marquess Mompelian, and Monsieur Louvignies went with an Escorte of two thousand Horse to find a convenient Place for incamping our Armies, where they unfortunately missed of surprizing seven hundred Horse who were on the other side of Hall, as our Generals were on this side; and by their Scouts having timely discover'd our Body of Horse, they retired too soon to be engaged, their Retreat being through an inclosed Country, and towards their Army, where they might have Ambuscades laid. Our Generals all agreed to incamp our Armies at Tubise, a Vil∣lage a League from Hall towards Mons, as being very advantageous for the Security of our Camp. On Sunday Morning a thousand French Horse, with some principal Officers, came to view the same Place where we had been the Day before, having, it seems, receiv'd notice of our Intentions, which may now he probably alter'd, since his Ex∣cellency was this Day advertiz'd, that the Prince of Conde decamped this Morning at two a Clock, and is march'd with his Array towards Tournay, and a great Body of Horse towards Aeth, to co∣ver his March; and if this prove true, 'tis like∣ly our Motion will follow his.

Yesterday his Excellency received an Express from General Suches that he began his March from Duren on Friday, and the same Night in∣camped near Aix la Chapelle, with Intentions to march on with all Diligence, by the way of Condrot towards Namur▪ to which Place his Excellency has sent Commissaries to provide fifty thousand Rations of Bread tor that Army, and has also sent Orders for great Quantities of Bread to be baked in all the adjacent Parts. It's designed the Impe∣rial
Army shall pass the Meuse betwixt Namur and Huy at Anden, where a Bridge is preparing; and 'tis believ'd the Army will pass there to mor∣row, or on Thursday at farthest. The Discourse still holds that they shall march betwixt the Sam∣bre and Meuse, and that way enter France, whilst our Army and the Prince of Orange's shall advance towards the new Conquests in Flanders; but this as yet is only surmize. Yesterday after Dinner his Excellency accompanyed with the Master de Camp General, Prince de Vaudemont, and Mon∣sieur Louvignies went to Fountain to meet his High∣ness and his Generals, where they were in Coun∣cil till nine at Night, and have finally agreed, as we hear, without any more Conferences, for the marching of both Armies. Our Train of Artille∣ry, with our Ammunition Waggons, and twenty Waggons loaded with Pontoons, are all ready; and to morrow we expect four hundred Waggons, with three Horses in each, which are summon'd in from Alost, Dermond, and the Pais de Waes; so soon as they are all come we judge our Army will move; the Prince Vaudemont assuring an Of∣ficer of Quality this Morning, that before the end of this Week our Armies would be marched from hence, expecting before our March the Arrival of the Irialist at Namur, and an Interview be∣twix, Excellency and General Souches. It is not certainly known whether his Excellency goes i Person into the Campaign; we see yet no sible Preparations made for his own Train, which makes us judge that he will stay here. The Duke de Villa Hermosa is still in Flanders with two thousand Horse, at present betwixt Gaunt and Derod for the Refreshment of his Troops, from whence no can quickly join our Army upon its lch.

His Excellency has sent into Guelderland for our old Troops that are there to march hither in all Diligence, which are a Regiment of Croats, the Regiment that was the Prince de Salm's, and Baron de Yong's Regiment of German Foot. 'Tis thought my Lord Castlehaven will have Or∣ders to come with them, which his Lordship much desires, being of no use where he is; and if he continues there, it may be concluded he is kept out of the way that he may not be privy to their Councils here.

The Prince of Orange has taken lately a Review of his Army, which are said to be thirty two Re∣giments of Foot, besides the two Marine Regi∣ments which are here at Brussels, and those in Flanders, and an hundred forty four Troops of Horse, and two thousand Dragoons; so that he will be in the Field effectively between thirty and thirty five thousand Men. What our own Army will be, we cannot yet make any Judgment of, because they are dispersed, and 'tis not yet decla∣red publickly what Regiments shall march.

The Boors in those Parts where the Hollanders are quartered (being infinitely oppressed by them) have taken their Opportunities of killing several of them, who have been found murdred in the Woods; whereupon great search has been made, and Soldiers Cloaths found in some Boors Hou∣ses, upon which his Highness has caused four or five Boors to be executed.

We hear that all the Prisons of Mons are full of French Soldiers, that the Duke d' Arschott caus'd a general Muster to be taken within the Town or all Persons able to bear Arms, which amount∣ed to near thirty thousand Men. We cannot learn the certainty of what Force the French Ar∣my
is; all the Prisoners we take, and Deserters which come from them, report them sixty thou∣sand, which is more than a third part greater than we will give Credit to. But a Lieutenant of Horse of ours that was taken near Mons, and is sent back hither, who saw their Army all drawn up, judges them about forty thousand Men, and those as good Troops as he ever saw

It has been whispered here since our last Or∣der from Spain, that his Excellency had recei∣ved some Check for permitting Monsieur la Motte and Samur (being only Pen-Men) to intermeddle in the Councils of War, and for intrusting them more particularly in those Affairs than his Gene∣rals and great Officers, much to their Dissatisfa∣ction. And that which gives more Occasion to believe it, is, that Monsieur la Motte since that time has not been so frequent in Councils as be∣fore; and that his Excellency, to take him off from martial Affairs, has made him President of the Chamner of Commerce, and has sent Monsieur Samur to Gaunt, to be an Assistant to Count Rhe∣nenburg, who commands there in chief.
Letters from Ruremond of the 16th say, That the Cologn Troops which lately revolted, after ha∣ving killed most of their Officers, and broken fifteen Standards, have dispersed themselves.

Last Night Master de Camp Scot came hither with the sixty Scotch Men that were taken at Sea by the Ostend Caper. They were immediately mustred, and his Excellency gave Orders for cloathing them, and giving them a Months Pay, and so the Collonel to march with them to his Quarters at Leuwe. There are two Lieutenants and an Ensign, one of them Mr. Maiteland▪ but they would not take Service, and will, I
think, be sent to the French Army to morrow▪
I have nothing more of Trouble to give your Lordship, but humbly to throw my self at your Honour's Feet, in the Quality of,

CLOSER.SIGNED: Your Honour's most obedient, most humble, and most entirely devoted Servant, R. B.

DIV2.P:
WE continue here in the same Posture we . The Imperialists are not yet advan∣ced any rther than they were, being still about Liege, and have been endeavouring to induce that Government to receive an imperial Garrison into their Citadel, which we would fain persuade our selves here that they are inclinable to. It seems General Souches is resolv'd not to come much farther into these Quarters, till he is assu∣red his Army shall want no Provisions; and we now say they will not advance till the Corn is nearer ripe, it being otherwise impossible to find sufficient Subsistence for all our Armies▪ In the mean time the Prince of Conde continues still a∣bout Mons, so miserably harassing all that Coun∣try, that there will be nothing left either for Man or Horse. He has sent Orders to the Chattel∣lany f Cry to send to his Camp eight hun∣dred
Waggon-Horses, and three hundred Cows for his Army, and all other Places are to provide proportionably. It is scarce credible how much his Army deserts; not a Day passes here without considerable Numbers coming in; so that we have it from good Hands, that his Army is lessened four thousand Men since his encamping about Mons.

The Prince of Orange's Army continues still where it was, and daily increases by taking in all Deserters, which his Excellency here will not permit. On Saturday I was at his Highness's Quarters at Semps, where there was no Appear∣ance of marching, but an hourly Expectation for his Highness and Excellency to go personally to confer with General Souches, which upon some Consideration is as yet delay'd. I had a long Discourse with Sir Walter Vane, who seems of the same Opinion with General Souches, that there is not here a sufficient Store of Provisions for their Armies, and that it would be ruinous for them to make any great Advance 'till the Corn be ripe. He was very inquisitive to know really what Force his Excellency could spare to join with them, as∣suring me that his Highness would part with none of his Men to put into our Garrisons; and that if his Excellency could send four thousand Horse, six thousand Foot, and two thousand Dragoons, they would expect no more; and doubted not, but with that Addition to do great things before the end of the Campaign. And we shall now cer∣tainly be able to draw into the Field ten or twelve thousand Men, our Troops being come from Guel∣derland, and our Recruits from Germany being upon their March. I have understood from very good Hands, that his Excellency has a great in∣clination
to besiege Arras, as a Place of the grea∣test Consequence towards regaining our lost Towns in these Provinces, and it is not unlikely but that may be the first Design we go upon.

On Sunday Night the Marquess Mortaign, late Governour of Dole, came hither, who was very kindly receiv'd by his Excellency for so well de∣fending that Place. He gave his Excellency an Account that one of our Regiments that was there, consisting of six hundred Men, had all taken Ser∣vice with the French, both Lieutenant Collonel, Major, and six Captains, with their Officers and entire Companies.

Yesterday Morning our German Letters gave us an Account of a long and sharp Engagement be∣twixt Marshal Turene and the Duke of Lorrain, who had with him Count Caprara, with some Saxon Troops. The Relation is differently repor∣ted, but by a Letter of the 17th from the Duke of Bournovile to his Secretary here, which I had the Favour to see. It is thus written in general Terms, That the Duke of Lorrain being inform'd that Marshal Turene's Army and his were much about an equal Number, was resolved to pass the Neckar, and to fight him if he oppos'd his Pas∣sage. That he had passed the River before the French came up, and being posted upon an advan∣tageous Ground endured several Attacks, and could not be forced from it; but Marshall Turenne having fourteen thousand Men, and the Duke but eight thousand, the French having Canon, and the Duke none, he was after many Charges, and four Hours dispute, forced to quit that Post; but retreated in so good Order, still bringing up the Rear himself, that he saved all his Bag∣gage, and still fought as he retired; the French
pressing very hard upon him, insomuch that there was no Regiment there that charged not twice or thrice that Day; that towards the Evening he re∣treated to a great Wood, where the Marshal Tu∣renne thought best to leave him for fear of an Ambuscade: And so concludes, that the Engage∣ment ceased more favourably to the French than the Duke, that many Officers of Quality were kill'd on the Duke's Side, and so he believ'd on the French, and that the Loss was judged near e∣qual, and that then he had no farther Particulars but that he was then drawing his Troops toge∣ther, and going in Person to Heidelberg, and that being joined with the Duke, and the Palatine Troops, he doubted not of being quickly even with Marshal Turenne; which was the whole Substance of his Letter. There is another relation from Co∣logn, dated the 18th instant, which is more parti∣cular and long, and much to the Honour of the Duke of Lorrain in making so brave a Retreat, being over-powered by a much greater Number, and says there was about two thousand kill'd on both Sides. The Particulars will be at large in the Brussels Gazette, and therefore I forbear repeating them to your Lordship. But notwithstanding both these Accounts, the Prince de Vaudemont is said to have receiv'd an Express of a later Date, wherein the Duke is said to be victorious, and to have gained fifteen Standards, which is here re∣ported with great Confidence; and last Night were great Fire-Works at the Prince's House, for y of the Victory, and his Excellency was there imself, with the Prince. Whether this be true r not, your Lordship knows better from France an we can here. But the most sober People ere judge these Fire-Works to be in Imitation of
their Neighbours, who were used to give Thank for being no more beaten.

We are in great Expectation to hear what th Fleet has done for these two or three Days; an have had a warm Report that they have take Blaye upon the River of Bourdeaux; but finding no Confirmation of it, that Report begins to cool.

When I was at the Prince of Orange's Quarters Sir Gabriel Silvius told me of a sad Accident th hapned the Day before to Captain Mazine's So who lately come from England, being sitting up on a Bank upon the River side to wash his Fee the Ground sail'd, and he fell in, where he w most unhappily drown'd. There was an Engli Man with him, who leapt in to save him, b was very near being drown'd himself, and ha much ado to get off from him; his Body w brought to the Camp while I was there, and h Loss much regretted.
I have nought else to add, but, after laying m self low at your Lordship's Feet, humbly to su¦scribe my self with all imaginable Zeal a Duty,

CLOSER.SIGNED: Your Honour's most obedient, most humble, and most intirely devoted Servan R.

DIV2.P: YEsterday the Prince of Conde decamp'd from near Mons, and is march'd with his Army towards Tournay and Aeth. The last Night his own Quarters were at the Abbey of Cambron near Cheiure. 'Tis believ'd he will spread his Army betwixt Tournay, Oudenard and Aeth, to be ready upon the first notice of the Prince of Orange's and our Army's advancing towards the new Conquests of Flanders.

Lieutenant General Agourto is come to Valenchien∣nes, with 1500 Horse and Dragoons to be near the Rear of the Prince of Conde's Army. Gene∣ral Souches is also moving with his Army towards Namur, though it be rather to enlarge Quarters than to go upon any present Action. His Army is about Chenay, where they pass the River Ourt, and 'tis said the General himself is now at Mo∣deff, the House of the late Count Marcin. It seems his Army is much encreased since their co∣ming into the Pay de Leige by the Addition of the Munster Troops; and they have so many hundreds of Carriages, and so much Baggage, that they can move but very slowly, and find no small Difficulty in getting Provisions for so vast a Num∣ber, and therefore the General says plainly, 'tis mpracticable to march into the Enemy's Quar∣ters 'till Corn be rpe, and that if they advance ooner into their Territories they must starve, nd that his Army will not live like Spaniards.

The General had great Hopes to have frightned the States of Leige to have receiv'd an imperia Garrison by telling them, that their City being a Member of the Empire, his Imperial Majesty expected they should have received his Army a Friends, and if they did not he must look upon them as Enemies: That he could not but take notce of their having three hundred Men upon the Guard in every Port, when they had but te or twelve Men whilst the French Army wer there, which sufficiently testified their Inclina¦tions; but he had as small Success with his Arm as Brn d' Issola had with his Rhetorik, exceptin only, that the States open'd their Purse-strings which gave his Excellency some present Satisfa¦ction. And he has now likewise touched ou Spanish Money, his Excellency the Count Mont¦rey having consigned a large Sum towards Pay¦ment of his Army, some of the Imperial Off¦cers being here at this time about it; for till th be done, there is no hopes of their making an great Advance. The two Bridges at Anten a ready for their Passage, and we now expect the should pass within few Days, all their Difficu¦ties being remov'd.

Baron de Yong with his Regiment, and o Guelderland Troops, is come to Diest, where the are quartered, and at Tirlemont and those Part and we hear that two thousand of our new Ge¦man Recruits are come as far as Guelderlan and that many more are embark'd at Hambrough.

On Wednesday Morning early a Party of Fren bravely mounted, (as we understand, most Of¦cers) came very near our Horse Guards upon t Hills, about Scarbeck and Diggam, to view h
our Troops lay, which were indeed very loosely quartered, but upon that Alarm they draw each Night into the Field.

The same Day there came hither near an hun∣dred Deserters from the Prince of Conde's Army, of their Catalonian and Italian Regiments, who were immediaely receiv'd into Service here by his Excellency's Command, being all Spaniards and Italians.

The Duke de Villa Hermosa with two thousand Horse still continues about Dermond, ready to observe the Motions of the French that way, and to be in the Van of the Prince of Orange's Troops, many of which are quartered on this side the Canal up into the Country; and on the other side of them, for their Security, lies the Baron de Brlow with his Regiment of Dragoons near Hall.

The Prince of Croyé, who was taken some time since by the French at Erkelens, is now re∣turn'd hither upon his Ransom eing paid; and his Excellency has given him Money for raising his German Regiments, and he returns to morrow in all hast towards Cologn to raise them.

The Duke de Bournovile has written to his Bro∣ther Viscount Berlyn, by this last Order, that unless the Grmans had been all drunk or mad, they would never have attempted so hazardous an Encounter as they did with Marshal Turenne, and that it was little less than a Miracle they were not all cut off, fighting upon so great a Disadvantage that it was contrary to the Sense of the Duke of Lorrain, whose Advice, if they had followed, they had joyned with him without ha∣zarding an Engagement.

This Afternoon his Excellency the Count Mon∣terey, accompanyed with all his great Officers▪ went out of the Scarbeck Port, to see the two Holland Marine Regiments of de Wey and Palm who lie in our Counterscarp, drawn out into the Fields to exercise, which they did with grea Dexterity, and much to his Excellency's Satis¦faction.
We are now prepared to march so soon as the Germans come up, and shall be able to draw to¦gether ten or twelve thousand Men.
The Present for General Souches is ready, bu his Excellency will not send it till he is nearer and that he and the Prince of Orange have had Conference with him, which will be within few Days.
Here is at present nothing else worth you Lordship's notice, and therefore I shall humbl beg leave to subscribe my self, with all imagina¦ble Zeal and Duty,

CLOSER.SIGNED: Your Honour's most obedient, most humble, and most intirely devoted Servant, R. B

DIV2.P: BY Letters from Cologn of the 29th past, we are told, that after Marshal Turene had reti∣red to Philipsburgh, to refresh his Army after the late Battle, he there crossed the Rhyne, and un∣derstanding the Elector Palatine had withdrawn most of the Garrison from Newstad, he march'd thither, took it, and put a Garrison of four hun∣dred Men into it; and took also another small Place, which he burnt to the Ground, there be∣ing a Castle which had a Garrison in it, which he could not force. It's written also, that his Army is much increased since the Battle, by a Recruit of two thousand five hundred Dragoons, besides Monsieur Vaubrun's Troops who are joyn'd with him; that the Duke of Lorrain's Army was about eight thousand, besides the Forces of the Circle of Franconia, and the Palatinate, and in the whole would be about twenty thousand Men; that he was marching from Ladenburgh towards Manheim, where he intended passing the Rhine, bng resolv'd to provoke Monsieur Turene to a Battle if he would accept it. The same Letter says, that the 28th past, one thousand five hun∣dred Foot, five hundred Horse, and five hundred Dragoons of the Munster Troops passed the Rhine near Mulheim, in order to their marching after the Imperial Army in these Parts.

General Souches, with the Body of the Imperial Army, lies encamped on the other side o the Muse near Arden, where they are to ps which he forbears till his whole Army be com up
having been forced to file off several ways to pass through the rugged Country of Condrot; besides, all the Munster Troops are not yet come up to him, which, 'tis thought, he will expect there, before the Body of his Army passes the River. His Army consists of six Regiments and an half of Infantry, sixteen Companies in each Regiment, and one hundred and fifty Men in each Company▪ The Right Wing of their Infantry is commanded by the Prince Pio, the Left Wing by Vertmultez, who was General in Candia. They have ten Re∣giments of Cavalry, twelve Troops in each Re∣giment▪ and eighty Soldiers in each Troop, which are commanded by the Prince of Lorrain and Ge∣neral Spark, as Lieutenant Generals. Marquess of Bade is General of the Ordnance, and they have fifty eight Pieces in their Train of Artillery; they have also the Munster Troops which they reckon at six thousand Men, and in the whole they esteem their Army thirty thousand effective Men. But I shall have a most exact Account of their Army, and all their principal Officers, from their Adjutant General, which I hope to send your Lordship by the next Order.

We are told by some of their Officers, that the Army is very unruly, and notwithstanding the General uses great Severity of Discipline, not a Day passing without some Execution, yet it is impossible to keep them in order, they declaring▪ That if every Tree in the Country were a Gibbet it should not hinder them from taking whatever they find, which is Man's Meat, whether dead o aive. And therefore the General sent to his Ex∣cellency her, that notice might be given to the Counry, tht Cattle might be brought in for hi Army, withut which it would be impossible t
keep them from ravaging the Country. And 'tis much feared, the Liberty which this German Army takes will quite spoil the Discipline of ours and the Prince's Army, if they shall be near each other; to prevent which, his Excellency is publishing more strict Placaerts than have been formerly for governing the Army. And his Highness the Prince of Orange uses very strict Discipline in his Army, the least Fault not escaping Punishment, which makes them begin to live more regularly.

On Saturday Night his Excellency's Guards of Horse marched hence, having Orders to carry with them four Days Provisions for themselves and Horses, and with them went his Excellency's Led Horses, his Servants and Retinue, with his Waggons of Provisions, and went that Night to Louvain, whither on Sunday Morning his Excel∣lency follow'd, with Marquess Assenlaet and Prince de Vaudemont, and arrived at the Cloyster of St. Gertrude in Louvain. About two in the Afternoon the Prince of Orange, accompanied with Count Waldec, and many other principal Officers, pas∣sed through Louvain with his Guards of Horse, and made no stay, but marched on to Tirlemont, where his Excellency overtook him, and that Night, it was said, they were to meet Gene∣ral Souches at a small Village not far from Tit∣lemont, in the way to Namur. His Excel∣lency had caused all manner of Provisions to be carried for their Entertainment, and had two thousand of his Horse, besides his Guards and the Prince of Orange's for their Security, and One thousand Curiassiers were to come with Gene∣ral Souches. Their Intentions were to return this Night, for so I was told on Sunday at the Prince of Orange's Quarters by Sir Gab. Silvius, who
went with his Highness, and likewise by Sir Wal∣ter Vane, who stay'd behind by the Prince's Com∣mand to take care of the Army. But we hear this Day, that they are gone forward to the Imperial Army to see it encamped, so that we believe that neither his Highness nor Excellency will return till to morrow. Sir Walter Vane told me, after this Conference they should suddenly enter upon A∣ction, and their Army would march so soon as his Highness return'd; so that I hope by the next I may give your Lordship an Account what Resolu∣tions were taken in this Conference.

On Saturday also went away from hence all the Duke de Villa Hermosa's Equipage for this Cam¦paign, he being resolv'd not to come hither til the Campaign be ended. All the Hand-mills tha can be found or made, are order'd to be bough up to carry with the Army for grinding Corn and all imaginable Preparations are making fo Provisions and Forrage for the Army, and it is th general Belief it will not be many Days before ou Armies shall move.

We are assur'd the Prince of Conde's Army con¦tinues still about Chure and those Parts, and tha he has had considerable Recruits come to him but to what number we cannot, at least are no willing to say; for we still continue that Humou of undervaluing our Enemies, and will not believ them half the number that general Report make them. There is a Convoy of Three thousand an odd hundred Waggons (of which the Country o Arra furnished Two thousand two hundred) com all safe to the Army, and the Garrisons near i The whole Cuntry has been charged to send i great Quantities of Cattel for the Army; and w are told the Contribution Land of Kennaway h
given Two thousand Cows in Specie, which is to be rebated out of their Contribution, according to the Value set upon the Cattel by Persons ap∣pointed at the Delivery of them; so that now they have plenty of all sorts of Provisions, and we do not find that the Deserters come so fast to us as they did.

His Excellency the Count Monterey has lately a∣greed with the Elector of Brandenburgh for Eight thousand Men, who are to come hither for a Sup∣ply of our Army, his Excellency having now sent Money and all necessary Orders for them; and we are assured they are already upon their March, and will be here in six Weeks time at farthest; and though a good part of the Summer is past, yet we reckon we shall keep the Campaign for four Months intirely to come.

On Friday last there having passed some angry Words between Count Egmond and Count Me∣rode, which came to his Excellency's Knowledge, he thereupon commanded them both in Arrest, the first to his House, the other to his Chamber, till they are reconciled.

The Bridge which his Excellency ordered to be made over the Scheld at Antwerp is finished, the principal Occasion of it being for the more spee∣dy and safe Passage of Convoys with Provisions from the Pay de Waes, and thse Parts of Flan∣ders for the Subsistence of the Army.
I have nothing else to add, but humbly to lay my self low at your Lordship's Fe, in the Qua∣lity of,

CLOSER.SIGNED: Your Honour's most obedient mot humble, and most intirely dved Servant, R. B.

DIV2.P: SInce my last the Troops of the Prince of Orange's Army that were quarter'd about Diest and Arschot, are advanced towards Malines in order to their going to a general rendezvous, which is now every Dy expected, their Army as well as our having Orders to be in readiness to march with Bag and Baggage at the first notice.
