On Saturday Morning his Excellency went to confer with his Highness the Prince of Orange and after his Return at Nine the same Night Monsieur Luvignies was dispatched in great Di¦ligence to General Souches, to whom Yesterday hi Excellency sent four Curriers with Expresses be¦tween Eight in the Morning and Three in the Af¦ternoon; and about Five in the Evening a Gentle¦man of his Excellency's Chamber went Express t eral Souches, and this Morning about Fiv Monsieur Louvignies return'd. It seems Genera Souches (notwithstanding his Present of Diamonds before he passes the Meuse with his Army expects Monta's Pay for them, which is to be paid jointl by the Prince of Orange and his Excellency: Th Prince has deposited his Proportion, and his Ex¦cellency s given Orders for paying his Part, As¦sgnations being given upon Antwerp for it; at till the Army be paid, they will not pass th Meuse. They are at present betwixt Namur an Gvt▪ where they intend to throw over a Brida for Passage of their Army Some Talk there i as if the Imerialists should pass directly nt France by the way of Rcroy, whilst our Armi
attend the Prince of Conde. But I am told by a great Confident of Monsieur Louvignie's, that his Excellency with Six thousand Horse and Dragoons, four Regiments of Spanish Infantry, two of Ger∣mans, and two of Walloons, will march to join General Souches before he makes any farther Ad∣vance, and so endeavour jointly to give Battel to the Prince of Conde, whilst the Prince of Orange with his Army shall besiege Charleroy; and that General Souches makes a Halt with his Army till the Corn be nearer ripe, and that our Army draws to him. Whether this be our real Design I can∣not yet say, but a few Days will give us more light; in the interim this is the best Account I am able to give. The Prince of Orange's Army is pre∣paring to march, and will certainly decamp on Thursday or Friday at farthest, if for no other Design, yet (as I am inform'd by some of their principal Officers) Necessity will force them, for they have no Forage left, their Horses for five or six Days past eating green Oats and Barley; and when that is done, they must turn their Horses in∣to the Rye, which-will kill them all: Their new Quarters are appointed towards Alost; his High∣ness's Quarters will be in that Town, or near it. I intend to see them at their general rendezvous; but as yet we know not where it will be.

The Prince of Conde continues still his Quarters near Aeth, and his Army is encamp'd thereabouts, which we much wonder at, since he cannot but know the Strength of our Armies here, especially ree we are told that his most Christian Majesty s coming in Person to his Army, which is look'd pon here as a Romance, believing he will come where he is sure to conquer, as in Burgundy, not in Flanders, where we make sure he is to
be beaten; of which we are so confident, tha great Wagers are offer'd to be laid that the Spa∣nish Army shall pass Pontneufe near Paris before the middle of August; and we make full Account that all our Armies here shall take up their Win¦ter-Quarters in France: This would be a great Al∣teration in the Face of our Affairs, if it should happen according to our Expectation.

We are very confident also that the Dutch Flee have made a Descent about Nantz, having first ta∣ken Bell-Isle, of which the Prince of Orange has no Particulars; however we believe it, upon some Letters we have had from France: But the more sober People expect a Confirmation of it from England, before they give Credit to the Report.

From Guelderland we hear that Grave is neithe blocked up nor besieged, but that they are very strong in Garrison, and make daily Incursions: and that Maestricht and Maseyk do the like, ha∣ving in those three Garrisons, with those that were at Navagne which is now demolished, at leas Ten thousand Men, and that the Garrison o Ruremond is not without Apprehension of thei attempting something upon them, unless Grave b suddenly besieged by the Hollanders.
This is all the Account I am at present able to give your Lordship, being with all imaginable Zeal and Duty,

CLOSER.SIGNED: Your Lordship's most humble, most obedient, and most intirely devoted Servant, R. B

DIV2.P: OUR last Letters from Germany tell us, that Mareschal Turenne being reinforced with a considerable number of old Troops from Alsace and Lorrain, had advanced upon the Army in the Palatinate, and forced them to retire from Laden∣burgh, which he had possess'd; and that he was marched with his Army, consisting of above Twen∣ty thousand effective Men of old Troops towards Manheim, in order, as 'twas thought, to besiege it. Which Account does well agree with what the Duke of Bournovile has lately written hither to a private Friend, wherein he complains of his ill Usage in being sent from the Imperial Army, which he had modelled with great Care and Difficulty, to command the Fragments of an Army composed of many Parts, which cannot be got together; and much blames the Management of Affairs a∣mongst the Confederate Princes, in not sending their allotted Supplies, whereby he is inforced to retire with the loss of his Reputation, and with Danger to the Palatinate. This Account gives the Assurance of Monsieur Turenne's Victory in the late Battel, which we would by no means believe, ha∣ving from time to time been deluded by the suc∣cessive Relations we have received of the flourish∣ing Condition of the Confederate Armies, magni∣fying the Imperialists Power there, and vilifying that of Mareschal Turenne's; which has so fill'd our gravest Heads here with vain and impertinent Hopes, that we will not yet believe what the Con∣sequences make evident.

After Monsieur Louvignie's Return from Gene∣ral Souches, and that he had given his Excellency an Account of the Advance of the Imperial Army near Dinant, and of their present Posture and Re∣solutions, he went to give his Highness the like, and return'd the same Night with this Account from his Highness, that there was an indispensible Necessity for his Army suddenly to leave those Quarters, since the whole Country was eaten up▪ and that all their Horse were forced to feed upon green Corn which would destroy them.

Yesterday Monsieur Louvignie was again sent to the Prince of Orange with Resolutions, as 'twas thought, concerning their March towards Alost▪ which Quarters have been some Days past allot¦ted for them, and the Castle of Grimberg appoin∣ted for his Highness's own Quarters, but upon what account it has been deferred is not said▪ but the Conjectures are, because Monsieur Prince still continues his Quarters about Aeth, from whence we expected he should have retired upon the Advance of the Imperialists for the Defence o their own Territories; and if the Prince of Orange's Army should advance on this side the River, they would lie so loose and open, that they would ru a great risk of being beaten up in their Quarter by the French Troops. Besides, the Troops that ar to form our Army are not come up hither, nor th General Officers yet arriv'd which his Excellency has sent for.

Several Reflections are made here upon thes our reiterated Delays, and all the World wonder at our backwardness, that nothing is done eithe by Sea or Land before this time; whereas th Dutch Fleet might have given them a strong an considerable Diversion on the other side, whill
the Imperial Army had made a vigorous Inroad up∣on this, and the Prince of Orange's and our Army at the same time advanced into their new Con∣quests of Flanders; and if we shall still let slip all these Advantages which we might have made by so happy a Conjuncture, it will make our Weak∣ness more than ordinarily conspicuous. But the real Truth of our not moving sooner, is, that all our Generals have declared it absolutely impracti∣cable to march with such powerful Armies into an Enemy's Country till the Corn be ripe; which now drawing on apace, the Imperialists are advan∣cing, having decamped on Wednesday Morning at Three a clock; but whether they will pass the Maese at Givet, is not publickly known; the more received Opinion here is, that they will march by the way of Bastoign, and so to Treves, or else by Arton, and so towards Lorrain; and it's believ'd one of these two last is their Intention: By the next I shall be able to give your Lordship a more particular Account, of what at present we only speak by Conjectures.

Those of greatest Judgment amongst our Gene∣rals have propos'd, as I hear, to fall upon some f the King of France's most considerable Towns, y the Benefit of which we may be able to pass n, and upon a solid Foundation maintain the War afterwards, and not to put our selves into he Enemies Country, without first taking some ace for Retreat in case of Disaster. But others e rather for making an Incursion, and over-run∣ng the Country, upon Presumption that at our st appearance there will be a Revolt, persua∣ng our selves that with these powerful Armies e shall do whatsoever we desire, believing nothing t what agrees with our own Imaginitions, and
concluding before the end of this Campaign we shall have a great Part of France in our Hands, which I am afraid will prove but a false Re∣flection, and that we shall be mistaken in the Opinion we conceive of this Juncture to ruin France.

Before the Imperialists marched, there was Mo∣ney allotted them by his Highness and his Excel∣lency together for a Month's Pay, which was ve∣ry welcome to those that had the good Fortune to receive it, who, 'tis thought, will convert most of it to their own use. For their Infantry had but a Rix-dollar a Man given them for a Succour▪ and they generally murmur not only for want o Pay, but of Provisions, the whole Army bein four Days without Bread the last Week.

The Duke de Villa Hermosa came hither early or Wednesday Morning, and continues here still having left his Troops in their Quarters abou Dendermond, who are ready to march at an Hous warning. These two last Days have been spe in private Consultations by his Excellency with his General Officers, he not having appear'd i publick since Tuesday last till this Day; neithe is there yet any more appearance of our marchin than there was before. The Prince of Orange Army begins to diminish by Diseases, many dy dl, and great numbers sick, occasion'd by the sreting upon Cherries, being quarter'd in th midst of the Cherry-Country.

His Excellency caused Yesterday a strict P¦cert to be published▪ prohibiting all Officers▪ our Army, during this Campaign, to take eith the Tenhs▪ or any Share of Prizes which shall take any of their Soldiers, but commands th it is whlly divided amongst the Soldiers
their greater Encouragement; and has order'd ano∣ther Liberance to be prepar'd for this Month's Pay, which will be the fifth Payment they have had this Year.

Whilst I am writing this, and was ready to end your Lordship's Trouble, Collonel Brandt, a Col∣lonel of Dragoons under the Prince of Orange came to see me, being come in great haste to Town to provide some Necessaries for his March, assuring me that Count Nassau General of their Cavalry, did Yesterday give him a private Item, that if he had any thing to do here, he should come this Day and dispatch it, for that to mor∣row the Army would certainly march towards Alost. And I am also privately told, that our Army will march on Monday, his Excellency be∣ing resolv'd to pay his Devotions on Sunday at the great Anniversary Solemnity of the Holy Sacra∣ment, which is that Day kept here.
I have nothing else to add, but, after laying my self low at your Lordship's Feet, to beg leave to subscribe my self with all imaginable Zeal and Duty,

CLOSER.SIGNED: Your Honour's most humble, most obedient, and most entirely devoted Servant, R. B.

DIV2.P: SInce my last, Monsieur le Prince decamped with his Army from about Aeth, and marched with it by Mus on Friday in the Afternoon, bending his Course towards the Meuse to watch the Mo∣tions of the Imperialists. His Head-Quarters at present is at the Abby of Bonne Esperance, near the Sambre, and the Rere-guard of his Army is posted at Mauvaige not far from Binch. We have an Account from those who are well able to judge, who saw his Army at the rendezvous, and upon their march, that there are sixty Battallions of Foot, and One hundred and twenty Squadrons of Horse, which we reckon about Forty thousand. But on Friday Night he sent away seven or eight thousand Men towards Rocroy, and those Parts, for Reinforcement of such Garrisons he suspects may be in most danger.

Upon the first notice of his March that way, we were much alarm'd, fearing lest he might get some Advantage of the Imperialists, having so per∣fect Knowledge of that Country; and therefore his Excellency dispatched three several Expresses on Saturday Morning in great Diligence to give General Souches notice of it, and afterwards his Excellency went to confer with the Prince of Orange; and after a Consultation had there, the Rnegrave was sent to General Souches to let him know what new Resolutions were taken. It seems this sudden Motion of Monsieur le Prince, and the unexpected Success of Mareschal Turenne has much lter'd our Measures. For General Souhes (as we
hear) is necessitated to send the third Part of his Troops to assist the Confederate Armies in the Pa∣lumate, and has thereupon made a Halt with his Army about Dinant and Chiney, till he is reinfor∣ced by a Conjunction with, or a large Supply from the Prince of Orange's and our Army, who are w designed that way, we beginning to be settled in point of Reputation; which being much lessen'd already by our so long lying still, will be absolutely lost, if with so much Preparation and with so great Forces we should consume unprofi∣tably a whole Campaign, which at first did seem to promise so much Advantage and Glory to Spain, and threaten so much Destruction and Ruin to France. And therefore after various Consultations, it is resolved that all ways shall be tried to force the Prince of Conde to a Battel, and according to the Event of that to proceed afterwards to other Resolutions; and with this Design both the Prince of Oange's and our Army are advancing directly towards the Prince of Conde, not doubting but to engage the Prince in a Battel in six Day's time; the Success whereof is s little dubted, that this Morning at the rendezvous of the Prince of Orange's Army, nt Waldeck told the Prince, he made no qst in five Days time they should hav that his Highness should see that rmy lost Reputation of the Hol∣landers, and uld lose his right Arm, if that Army wee orious over the France. But 'tis thought since Msour le Prince will be o much inferiour in number, will be more ry nd circumspect than to run the f a Battel, hich would be more dangerous, in t Cons∣nces than in the present Loss, since not oly
the new Conquests, but the Fortune of France de∣pends much upon this Army.

Yesterday the two Dutch Marine Regiments that were here marched towards Louvain, near which Place the rendezvous was this Day, his Highness having decamped this Morning very ear∣ly, and is this Night quarter'd at the Abby of Bethelem near Louvain, the whole Army being in∣camped there. To morrow his Highness marches forwards towards Charleroy, and has this Day sent a considerable Party of Horse and Dragoons to se∣cure two Passes upon the River of Dyle, over which he passes to morrow; one Part of his Army will pass at Hever, and the other at a Bridge betwixt that and Wavre.

To morrow Morning Marquis Assenlaer, the Duke de Villa Hermosa, and Prince Vaudemont march with what Forces his Excellency can spare: The Ammunition-Waggons and Train of Artillery are drawn up to the Park Gate near the Louvain Port, to pass out early in the Morning; what the num∣ber of our Troops will be is not yet said. His Excellency stays here, not having a sufficient Ar∣my for his personal Presence; but all the Forces he can get together are now about this City, and will certainly march to morrow Morning towards Namur, and will be to morrow Night near th Prince of Orange.

I intend early to morrow Morning to go to the rendezvous of the Prince's Army, and hope after∣wards to see ours, and so shall be able to give your Lordship a particular Account by the next very we shall not be many Days without csiable Action upon one Quarter or o¦ther of our Armies, for though tis not probable the Prince of Conde will hazard a Battel upon such
unequal Terms, yet his generous Spirit will scarce be restrain'd from giving us some Side-blows upon the Skirts of our Armies; and whatsoever shall happen, your Lordship shall not fail of having a particular and exact Account of it.

Monsieur Odyke is this Day marched with the Prince; and now having seen the Army together o the rendezvous, he takes his leave to morrow, and returns to Zealand with his Lady, and Mon∣sieur de Lecks, who are both with the Army; and from thence he will hasten into England upon his extraordinary Embassy. We are told also from the Prince's Camp, that my Lord Ambassador Temple arriv'd at the Briel on Friday Night last.

His Excellency and all the Court are much a∣mazed at the Relation they have from France con∣cerning the Descent the Dutch Fleet made upon Bell-Isle, and upon that Account hope but for little good from their Army here, notwitstanding all the Commendations that are given of it; neither will the Officers of the Prince's Army believe the Relation, though the Truth of it be confirm'd se∣veral ways.

We hear from Ruremond of the 14th instant, that Grave was then neither besieged nor blocked up; that the Garrison consists of Three thousand Foot and Six hundred Horse incamped without the Town, only Guards kept at the Gates, and re∣lieved from their Camp.

It is written from Frankfort, that the Confede∣rate Army in their Retreat thither lost a great Part of their Baggage, and that Mareschal Turenne has taken several small Places since their Retreat, and that they do expect he should besiege Fran∣ndale.
I have nothing else to add, but humbly to throw my self at your Lordship's Feet, in the Quality of,

CLOSER.SIGNED: Your Honour's most obedient, most humble, and most entirely devoted Servant, R. B.

DIV2.P:
HAving Notice on Sunday that my Lord Am∣bassador Temple was coming hither in his way to the Prince of Orange's Camp, I went to Fontaine to wait upon his Excellency, who came in a Yatch from Holland. From Fontaine he sent his Secretary to make a Compliment to his Excel∣lency, and to desire an Escorte for his safe Passage to his Highness's Camp, intending to make no stay in Brussels, if Coaches could by any means be gotten. His Excellency return'd Answer, that he was much m Lord Ambassador's Servant, and would return his Compliment upon his Arrival: But that for his going to the Camp, the Prince would be marched before he could arrive there, ither uld tell where his Highness could be t that my Lord Ambassador's best way would be return back to Malmes, and from thne to mont, which he might do without
an Escorte, and that there he might likely hear of the Prince. This dry Answer much surpriz'd his Excellency, since his rerurn to Malines was to lose a Days time, that being farmer from Tirle∣mont than Brussels, and that which added to his Trouble, was, that no Coaches were to be had till the next Day; whereupon I proposed to his Excellency, that notwithstanding it was late, and the ways insecure, I would adventure to the Prince's Camp by the way of Louvain, and would the next Mornn meet his Lordship at Louvain, and bring his Highness's Answer. And accordingly I went, but his Highness being marched in the beginning of the Night, I follow'd him, and not without Difficulty overtook and found his Highness about twelve at Night, two Leagues from Louvain, up∣on a very hasty March; where his Highness ha∣ving no means to read the Letter, demanded whe∣ther I knew any of the Contents; to which I re∣ply'd, My coming was to intimate to his High∣ness my Lord Ambassador's Arrival, and that he would be the next Morning at Louvain, to re∣ceive his Highness's Directions when and where he might attend him. To this his Highness told me, He knew not but that he might be twelve or fourteen Hours on Horseback, and perhaps many Miles from that Place, and that therefore it was not possible for him to say where his Excellency might find him. And when I pressed to know whether Tirlemont was not a convenient Place, his Highness told me that was the likeliest Place to hear of him; but I found by his Discourse that he had no great mind to speak at this jun∣cture of time with his Excellency, lest perhaps it might create a Jealousie in the Spaniards, who tick not to say that his Excellency's coming must
needs be in Order to Proposals of Peace, which they seem unwilling now to hearken to. His Highness told me farther, that if I would return to his Quarters at Park, in my way back, there I should find Sir Gabriel Silvius who was to march after him the next Day, and that I might dis∣course the Business farther with him, and his Ex∣cellency take his Measures accordingly. And so from thence I went to Park, and wakened Sir Ga∣briel, and gave him an Account of the Ambassa∣dor's coming, but could find no Encouragement from him for his Excellency's going forward; for he told me his Highness was marching with great Secrecy and Diligence, with all his own and the Spanish Cavalry, towards Namur, there to join with five thousand Horse of General Souches's Ar∣my, who had receiv'd Orders to pass the Meuse that Night at Namur, and that the Spanish Ca∣valry were marched the nearest way, in order to their speedy Conjunction with them, lest the Prince of Conde being but four Leagues from them should fall upon them before the Body of the Army could come up, and that therefore the De∣sign had been carryed with all imaginable Secre∣cy; and that his Highness, with all his Cavalry, was hastening that way, to be ready to second them upon any Occasion, and that the Foot were to march Yesterday Morning at three, which ac∣cordingly they did, and that it was hop'd Yester∣day by Noon the Spanish and Imperial Cavalry were join'd, and that his Highness with his Army hoped as this Day to be up with them, and so jointly to advance towards the Prince of Conde; and that being united they should be eighteen thousand Horse, and twenty two thousand Foot effective. What General Souches will do with the
rest of his Army, I cannot say, but I hear from good Hands that he is ordred to attend near Na∣mur on the other side of the Meuse the Motions of the French, and accordingly to govern him∣self; and in case the Prince of Conde should re∣tire betwixt the Sambre and the Meuse, and so march back that way, that then the Imperialists should move as fast on the other Side, and pass over at Givet, whilst the Prince of Orange with our Army presses upon them on this Side; it be∣ing now finally resolved to advance with all our Armies towards France; being impossible to find Subsistence any longer for such Armies in our Territories. And it is verily believed, wherever they march they will be put to great Exigencies for Provisions, not having any Stock to carry with them, nor sufficient Conveniencies for grinding of Corn when it is ripe.

Last Night at twelve his Excellency parted hence after the Army; his going was carry'd with such Secrecy that it was not known till Night, and then Orders were sent to the Nobili∣ty and Officers about the Town to accompany his Excellency. He took with him only his Guards, and Monsieur de Fue's Regiment of Horse, and three or four Waggons with his own Ne∣cessaries and Provisions. The Troops had Orders to march without any Baggage, carrying only each of them a Sack of Oats. His Excellency left strict Orders that all the Ports of the Town should this Day be kept shut 'till twelve at Noon, and no Boat, Messenger, Post, or other Person, to go out before that time upon Pain of Death.

This Afternoon I was inform'd, by an Officer who came this Morning from Mom, that the
Prince of Conde was retiring with his Army, and was Yesterday in the Afternoon at Maubeux upon the Sambre, which is a great way before our Troops, and it is believ'd that he will sufficiently rein∣force Philipvil, Rocroy, and all the Garrisons of those Parts, and then retire toward Doway, where he will encamp himself about those Rivers, and lie securely, and want no Provision.

His Excellency has sent for all the Troops that can be spared from Flanders. The Regiment of Velasco is come already, that of Aldadoe, and the Regiments of Duke d' Avery, Baron de Yong, and Marquess Bournovile are upon their March, and will be here in a Day or two with some Spa∣nish Troops also, and all the Troops that can be spared from Cambray, Valenciennes, and Conde, are sent to draw out and join our Army. All which Forces together will so far exceed the French, that we make no question of making a quick De∣cision in this great Business. Our Letters Yester∣day from Germany, seem to intimate, as though Martial Turenne should be bending this Way with his Army to succour the Prince of Conde.

Yesterday, when we came from Louvain, I sent my Man back with Letters from his Excellen∣cy to the Prince of Orange's Army, who is just now return'd, having left his Highness last Night encamp'd with his Army near Heylessem Abby, two Leagues on the right Hand of Tirlemont; He says, Sir Walter Vane told him that they intended this Day to march forwards towards Charleroy, and by the way join the Imperialists, which they hop'd to do this Afternoon. In his Return this Day from Tirlemont, he met his Excellency the Count de Monterey about Twelve at Noon, passing
through Louvain, having stay'd some Hours to refresh himself and Troops in the Fields on this side Louvain, and so made no Stay in the Town, but passed directly towards the Prince of Orange's Army.
Yesterday, about Noon, Monsieur Odyke par∣ted from Louvain to Malines, and so for Zealand; having first given a Complement to my Lord Am∣bassador Temple at his Inn.
I have nothing else to add, but humbly to throw my self at your Lordship's Feet, and beg leave to subscribe my self with all imaginable Zeal and Observance,

CLOSER.SIGNED: Your Honour's most humble, most obedient, and most entirely devoted Servant, R. B.

DIV2.P: ON Wednesday Morning his Excellency my Lord Ambassador Temple parted hence for Antwerp, where he intended yesterday to rest, and this Day to go forwards towards the Hague in his Yatch.

On Sunday Night and Munday Morning five thousand of General Souches Cavalry passed the
Meuse at Namur, with the General, and many of his principal Officers in the Head of them, and advanced that Day between Judoign and Gem∣blours, the General's Quarters being at Bosset Ab∣bey. The four thousand Spanish Cavalry, under Marquess Assenlaer, encamped between Judoign and Wavre.

On Tuesday General Souches and the Spanish Cavalry join'd; the same Night his Excellency the Count Monterey arriv'd at his Highness's Camp, between Hylessem and Huygard. On Wednesday Morning his Highness, his Excellency, General Souches, and all the other Generals met at Janch, where they held a long Council of War; imme∣diately after which, Orders were sent by General Souches for his whole Army to pass the Meuse at Namur, which they did accordingly; the Rear of their Army passing yesterday Morning, and they are now all united, being about seventy thou∣sand Men.

On Wednesday, after the Council of War was ended, his Highness and Excellency, with all the Generals, dined together at Wastin; his High∣ness's Army that Night encamping betwixt Ju∣doign and Gemblours, the Spanish Cavalry about Peruez, and General Souches's Army betwixt Gem∣blours and Fleura, his own Quarters being at Som∣bret Abbey.
Yesterday the Army settled, and great Con∣sultations were had what farther Measures should be taken, after which Prince Vaudemon entertain'd his Highness and Excellency, &c. a Peruez.

It's thought his Excellency will not return sinc there is so great likelihood of speedy Action, ma¦ny
believing there will be a Battle fought to morrow or Sunday, both Armies being now with∣in three or four Leagues of each other, and that in a great Campaign, where several Rencounters have passed already betwixt flying Parties, with various Success.

By a particular Friend, come this Day from Nivelle, I am assured that Monsieur le Prince was last Night encamped with his Army between Fountain l'Evesque, Tresny, and Herimont, that his Guards were kept in several Places towards Senef, Revez, Brunshove, and that the Guards of Gene∣ral Souches were kept not far from them.

The Duke d' Arschott, with Lieutenant General Agourto, and all the Spanish Forces in those Parts amounting to seven thousand are posted near Mons, betwixt that and St. Gislain, with Inten∣tion to impede the Retreat of the Prince of Conde if he should stir that way; and 'tis be∣liev'd that by this time the Imperialists have en∣deavour'd to possess themselves of Pontlow upon the Sambre near Chastelet, thereby to pass over, and prevent the Prince's passing at Marchienne au Pont; so that he must then be necessitated either to give Battle or to retire towards Maubeux, and pass there, having (as 'tis said) thrown over se∣veral Bridges between that and Marchienne au Pont. But by his so long stay in the Place where he is, being a Race Campaign, 'tis thought impossible for him to retire without fighting, our Armies being drawn so near him. The general Discourse here is, that if he does retire, one part of the Army will besiege Charleroy, whilst the other fol∣lows Monsieur le Prince, they being so numerous, and so much overpowering him, besides the Spanish
Troops about Mons, and those here, and that are coming from Flanders; but where to find Subsi∣stence for all these Armies, I cannot imagine, the Corn being destroy'd in all Places they pass, with their Horses and making their Barracks, so that there is none left to make Bread. And we hear that the imperial Army was the last Week three Days without Bread.

Marquess d' Ossera General of the Ordnance is left Commander in chief here, and Viscount Ber∣lin Governour. We have at present Montalto's, Spinosa's, Belcreiter's, and Mendrise's Spanish Regi∣ments, with Baron de Yong's of Germans, and half Marquess Wargnie's, besides the Regiments of Al∣dadoe, Duke d' Avery, and Marquess Bournovile, that are marching hither from Flanders with some Troops of Horse, which being joined with the three Regiments at Namur, of Rado, the Italian Regiment, and Count Boumont, will make a con∣siderable Body; his Excellency being resolved to drain all his Garrisons, having no Enemy to trou∣ble them.

A Company of Dragoons under Captain de Waunie, in Garrison at Bouchain, having receiv'd Orders to march towards Mons to join Lieutenant General Agourto, fell all into a Mutiny, and gene∣rally refused to march, upon Pretence of some Money their Captain had stopped from them by Order from his Collonel, for their Subsistence in the Campaign. The Captain kill'd one that re∣fus'd, and wounded many, so that they all fled to the Church, from whence they were taken out, and by the Governor forced to march; and so soon as they joined Lieutenant General Agourto, he caus'd ten of the principal Muti∣neers
to draw Straws, and two were harquebu∣shier'd.
I have nothing else to add, but to throw my self low at your Lordship's Feet, being with all imaginable Zeal and Duty,

CLOSER.SIGNED: Your Honour's most humble, most obedient, and most entirely devoted Servant, R. B.

DIV2.P: SInce Saturday Noon all our Armies have been encamped near Nivelle, within a League and half of the Enemy; the Imperialists betwixt Re∣ez and Rosigny, the Spaniards and Prince of O∣ange's Army betwixt Archenne and Rosigny. His Highness, with his Excellency, and all the Ge∣erals, have had several Consultations in the Su∣urbs of Rivelle, where they are quartered. All Mens Eyes and Ears are taken up with Expecta∣on of the great Results of their Councils, which e hear have been very unconcurring.

Monsieur le Prince still continues in his old Post tween Peyton and Tresignie, where he is strongly rtified with a great Trench round his Camp, d pallisadoed round; he lies at a close Guard, ering our Army no Play except in small Par∣ties,
which frequently skirmish between both Camps.

On Sunday Morning early General Spark went out with four thousand Horse to take a view of the Enemies Camp, and taking his way near Charle∣roy, he fell in with a Party of three hundred French Horse, whom he attacked under the Ca∣non of Charleroy, whilst they shot violently at him, and cut them all to pieces, not giving Quarter to the Collonel though earnestly begged This Relation came this Afternoon from the Camp, by some Officers who affirm'd they were present.

The Duke of Luxenburgh is quartered with two thousand five hundred Horse and Dragoon at the Bridge of Marchienne au Pont upon th Sambre, to secure that Passage, by which th greatest part of Provisions come to the Camp Most part of Sunday Monsieur le Prince was a Charleroy, in Council with his principal Officers and we expected the Result would have been hi retiring Yesterday with his Army, but we fin no Inclination in him to leave so advantageous Post.

Yesterday Lieutenant General Agourto join'd ou Army with two thousand five hundred Horse an Dragoons, and the like Number of Infantry which came from Mons and those Parts; and was believ'd upon return of the great Convoy our Camp, which went hence Yesterday, that o Armies would have decamped this Day, b do not; another great Convoy being this Afte¦noon come hither, and Monsieur Samur the ¦tendant of the Artillery is come with Orders all our great Guns to go to Morrow to the Camp

Our Armies have suffered some Scarcity through our own Disorders, the whole Country being un∣inhabited that should supply them, whilst the French by their good Government want nothing, having constant and orderly Markets in their Camp. This has occasion'd many of our Men to desert, especially the Hollanders; on Saturday twenty five Grenadeers deserted in one Company, and great Numbers go away daily unseen, be∣ing so near the Enemies Camp. On Sunday six were taken in their way between both Camps, and immediately executed. It seems the Hollan∣ders entertain'd all French Deserters, which now being near their Armies run back again, drawing many more with them, which makes us judge their former deserting was a Trick. Great Con∣voys are daily sent to our Camp, but 'tis not ea∣sy to provide Victuals for so many Mouths, one Convoy serving them but a Meal; however, they want not so much for their Belly as for Drink, Moisture being as necessary as Meat, and hirst to an Army in this Weather is less suppor∣able than Famine; and there is not only a want of Beer, but good Water is said to be more scarce the Camp than Wine here. The Disorders nd Insolencies committed by the Germans are carce credible. His Excellency has had sharp Words with General Souches concerning them, hose Answer was, That if his Excellency plea∣d, he would that Day hang one hundred, the xt two hundred, and so double each Day 'till ey come to a thousand, but when all that was e, his Army would continue the same Disor∣rs; at which Answer his Excellency was much led, it justifying in Effect his Soldiers Inso∣cies. However, his Excellency carries fair
Weather in his Face, though he have a Storm in his Heart, and caresses our Auxiliaries rather out of Fear than Love.

There is nothing to be heard in our Streets here but crying and complaining against the barba∣rous Insolence of the Germans; and indeed the sad Spectacle of this Countries devastation, so much disheartens the Minds of the most sober People, that they begin to say, They had rather be conquer'd by the French than conquer with the Germans; though as yet we are far enough from this last Point; for though our Armies are very numerous, yet the well disciplin'd and smaller Forces of the French, under such an experienc'd General as Monsieur le Prince, will be as effe∣ctual in Proof as our great Armies, which being composed of a medly of Nations, are not like to agree well amongst themselves. A pregnan Instance of which hapned the other Day: A Par¦ty of German Horse watching a Booty about▪ League from hence, encountred with a smalle Party of Spanish Cavalry, with Intentions to a¦tack and pillage them, but understanding by thei Officer that they were Spaniards, they swore b their usual German Oath, That it was well the were good Friends, for had they been the Sk¦lus. (Hlanders) they should have been all cut of The Truth is they spare none, no Safeguard willing where they are able to master; and so th Boors make as short work with them, shooti them wherever they pass. On Saturday twel of them were killed by the Boors not far fro hence▪ with a German Count, much to the reg of General Souches, who affirms that he had ¦ther have lost a thousand Men in his Army.

What farther Measures our Armies will take is as yet impossible to say, but by the next I shall be able to give your Lordship a very par∣ticular Account, having this Day sent an Express to Sir Walter Vane, who stays with him 'till the Army decamp, which will be on Thursday next.

We hear from Guelderland that the Siege of Grave goes on very slowly. We hear from se∣veral Hands that Monsieur Turenne is marching with his Army from the Palatinate towards France, but we are not willing to believe it without more Confirmation.
I have nothing else to add, but to lay my self low at your Lordship's Feet in the Quality of,

CLOSER.SIGNED: Your Honour's most humble, most obedient, and most intirely devoted Servant, R. B.

DIV2.P:
ON Satuday Noon came hither the Count of Oldenburgh in his way for the Hague, with an Escorte from the Prince of Orange's Camp, ha∣ving that Morning early left his Highness mar∣hing with his whole Army towards Marimont,
where they intended that Night to encamp. He told us publickly in Discourse at Dinner, that there was no good Correspondence in the Camp between the Spaniards and Hollanders, nor indeed between any of them: That he fear'd the great Disagreement in their Councils, would much pre∣judice their publick Concerns. He said in those few Days they had been incamped near Nivelle, Seven hundred of their Army had been taken Pri∣soners, Spaniards as well as Hollanders and Germans. That on Thursday the French took Three hundred German Foragers, and that our Army had not ta∣ken twenty French since their coming thither, ex∣cepting Spies, which they took daily, and the Day before a very remarkable one, being a young German Gentleman of a very good Family and Quality in Prussia, who was of the Dauphin's Re∣giment; and having (as he said) lost a conside∣rable Sum at Play, was induced upon Promise of great Reward to undertake that hazardous Em∣ployment. He came very confidently with his Boors on into the Prince of Orange's Quarters, like an Officer of the Army, where he was presently known, seized upon, put to the Question, con∣fessed his being sent, and in two Hours after was hanged before his Higness's Quarters. The Count told us that many of our Soldiers deserted, and that thirty of his Highness's Guards of Grenadeers deserting in one Company, who were all French, his Highness thereupon caused all the French to be stripped, and chased out of his Army.

He said, it was a sight would move Pity in Turks, to see so brave a Country as this so mise∣rably ruin'd by their Armies, sparing no Place but pillaging and razing all in their way: Tha hs Highness was very severe in punishing Disor¦ders,
having given strict Command for the hang∣ing any Soldier that should be found stragling without Passeport, and that accordingly no Day passed without many Executions. He told us it was generally resolved to attack some Place, and it was thought Quesnoy; that it was very proba∣ble we might hear of some sudden Action, our Armies marching so near the Enemy, and that be∣twixt three and four thousand Horse were drawn out that Morning for Security of the Army whilst they march'd so near the Enemies Plank. We had no sooner dined, than word was brought us that great shooting was heard without the Town towards Nivelle; which continuing till ten that Night, made us conclude the Armies were en∣gaged.

The Count told us, that on Friday his Excellen∣cy being desirous to see some of his Guards skir∣mish with the Enemy; thereupon Monsieur de Gaure and Don Domingo de Saisel, the two Cap∣tains of his Guards, took out some other Officers well mounted with Intention to shew his Excel∣lency some Divertisement. But the Nimble∣ness of the French surpassing their Spanish Gra∣vity, Don Domingo with two more was presently taken Prisoners, and one kill'd, and Monsieur de Gaue had been certainly kill'd or taken, but that he was rescued by a brisk Lieutenant, who told him when he came back before his Excellency, That thre was much difference beween skirmish∣ng before an Enemies Camp, and in a Carowsel efore Ladies.

On Sunday Morning early many Dutch Waggo∣ers were at our Ports, with some hundred of Waggon-Horses cut from their Waggons, affir∣ing that the French had fallen upon the Ree-guard
of their Army upon Saturday about Eleven at Noon, had defeated them; and in the mean time another Party had seized the Carriages of the Prince of Orange's Army, and that they had escaped with great Difficulty. This Relation put us here in much Disorder, especially a continued number of People coming from the Army in a great Confusion, and giving such imperfect Relations, that we know not what Credit to give to them, since no Express was come from the Army, nor one Spaniard or German seen a∣mongst them, which made us hope our Armies were intire and fighting. The same Day after Dinner came several Dutch Waggons, and a∣mongst them one of Sir Walter Vane's, and two of my Lord Clare's, whose Servants came to me to get Admittance into the Town, Orders being given to refuse Entrance. After I had them a my Lodging, they gave me the same Relation w had before, but with this farther, That befor they escap'd the French were got up to thei Carriages, and were pillaging them: That S Walter Vane had ten Waggons, and this was onl saved: That my Lord Clare's were both here They told me when they were got some distanc from the Army upon a rising Ground, they sa the Prince's Canon deserted, and nine Ensig running away with their Colours, without o Soldier following them, and that never suc Confusion was seen; some Waggoners cutti their Ropes, and running away with their Ho¦ses; some endeavouring to drive their Waggo over Hedges, where they were overturn'd a broken: That in this Disorder they got away far as Nvelle, where they lay under the Wa that Night, the Town not permitting any to ∣ter:
That the shooting continued till Eleven at Night, the Heavens seeming all on Fire: That on Monday Morning early they came from Ni∣velle, and heard shooting till they came within a League of this Place, but not so violent as on Sa∣turday. These dismal Relations one after the other gave the whole Town no small Perplexity, all People thronging to the Namur and Hall Port to hear News. At last about Ten at Night came an Express from his Excellency, being one of the Under-Secretaries, who brought an Account to her Excellency, that our Armies had gained a great Victory, kept the Field, and beaten the French with great Loss into their Camp, pursuing them to their Trenches: That this Victory had cost dear, many brave Officers lost, and some thousands of Soldiers on both sides; but that the French had much the greater Loss.

The manner his Excellency's Letter related the Battel was thus: That the French in a very advan∣tageous Place had from a Wood attacked our Rear∣guard, cut in pieces some Squadrons of Horse, and Battallions of Foot, and had pillaged most of the Prince of Orange's Carriages; but that our Army turning Head upon them as fast as the Ground would permit, they were presently re∣pulsed: That Monsieur le Prince having sent Six thousand Horse to second this Body, they were so far engaged by our Cavalry, that fresh Troops were sent to succour them; and so in fine, one Supply was sent after another till the whole Ar∣mies became engaged, and that in so bloody a Battel, that the like has not been known in these Countries: That some thousands are kill'd on our part, but more of the Enemies: That many Offi∣cers of Quality were kill'd, and many missing,
and amongst them our Master de Camp General Marquis Assenlaer, and Prince de Salm: That the Regiment of Holstein was cut in pieces, having endured the first Shock of the French Fury: That we were intirely Masters of the Field; and in case the Prince of Conde did not retire from his Camp, they intended to attack him, and force it. This was the Substance of so much of his Excel∣lency's Letter, as the Marquis d' Ossra (who commands in his Absence) was pleas'd to commu∣nicate to some principal Officers for their general Satisfaction; but I am told, there were other Par∣ticulars not so satisfactory, which were conceal'd. This News was that Night carried to the Magi∣strates, who were assembled in the Town-House, and all the City rung of the Victory. Yesterday there was great Rejoicing, and the Victory was magnified to that degree, according to Men's se∣veral Inclinations and Inventions, that I have ne∣ver heard such Romantick Stories told: That af∣ter the Germans had made a prodigious Slaugh∣ter of the French without their Camp, in the Night in great Fury they attack'd the Line, sur∣mounted all Difficulties, and gain'd the Enemies Camp, Cannon and Baggage: That Monsieur le Prince with some poor Fragments were escaped to Chr, where he was besieged; and that Eight th usd German Cavalry were following the French, who fl over the Sambre towards Ro∣oy: That the Duke of Enguien was mortally wounded, and taken Prisoner, the Duke of Lux∣emugh and M. Rheford (and Bellefond that ne∣ver was thre, kill'd; and these Stories related at Court, and in all Places by Officers and others, and counterfeit Letters written from the Camp produced of it, that I presume by the last Night's
Post for Germany and Holland, the News is car∣ried into most Parts of Christendom of the greatest Victory that ever was obtained against the French; for we talk of no less than Ten thousand kill'd on our side, and Fifteen on theirs.

Our great Counsellors and Politicians were al∣ready concluding the Peace, and that nothing less than reducing the French King to the Peace of Worms would be accepted, that of the Pyrenneans to be set aside as well as that of Aix. These Things I do affirm seriously to your Lordship were spoken in my hearing Yesterday at Dinner, by some of the great Council of Brabant. Yester∣day in the Afternoon about Three came another Express from his Excellency, which being in Cy∣pher took up so much time, that we knew no∣thing of it but in general Terms that it was a Confirmation of the Victory, but something more moderated than before: By this time our Heat began a little to cool; and at Night there came to my Lodging a Gentleman of Nivelle, of the House of Launoy, a sober Person, and always well affected to the Spanish Interest; and he assur'd us, that whatever Relations we had of the greatness of the Victory, the Prince of Conde still continued in his Camp, had taken many Prisoners, much Booty, many Colours, and as some said Cannon: That our Armies were gone towards Mons, his Excellency retiring that way when the Battel be∣gan, where he might hear it, and have an Ac∣ount given him without Danger: That he was present in or near Mons, and his Highness the rince of Orange's and General Souches's Armies camped about Mons, and betwixt that and nch. That if it were acknowledged a drawn attel, it was much in our Favour; for that by
all Circumstances the Victory rather inclin'd to the French, since they continued in the same Post they were before the Battel, having perform'd what they attempted, and more than they ex∣pected. He says farther, that Yesterday in the Afternoon the Prince of Conde sent a Trumpet to the Prince of Orange to give notice of what Pri∣soners of Quality he had; amongst which was our Master de Camp General wounded, but not dangerously, and many more of great Qua∣lity.

What farther Measures our Armies will take is not known; but 'tis much fear'd the loss and want of so many principal Officers who are wounded, may something retard, if not change the Resolutions they had taken.

There are no Particulars of the Battel come yet to any Hand that we can give Credit to, A Letter came last Night to the Princess of Vaudemont, being written on Sunday Night at Mons, and by the Favour of a special Friend, I here send your Lordship a Copy of it, which is the only Account I have yet seen, and I be∣lieve much of Truth in it. I have this Mor∣ning sent a Trumpet Express to Sir Walter Van and my Lord Clare, to acquaint them of their Waggons being here; and at his Return, I ex¦pect to have the true and full Particulars which your Lordship shall receive by the next In the interim, your Honour will be pleas to accept of this broken and imperfect Rela¦tion; which if it should pass through you Lordship's Hands, to those of his most Sacre Majesty, and that any Weakness or Error shoul be found in what I have written, I must the humbly implore your Honour will please to ex¦ercise
that part of your accustomed Goodness, as to plead my Excuse for the Imperfections of,

CLOSER.SIGNED: Your Honour's most humhle, most obedient, and most intirely devoted Servant, R. B.

POSTSCRIPT.P: Since the Writing hereof we had certain News that our Master de Camp General is dead of his Wounds in the French Camp, and that Count Merode is Prisoner there, and woun∣ded; the Prince de Salm is Prisoner, but not wounded.

DIV2.P:
WE are as yet every Day more than other in the dark as to our great Victory, which is related so many ways that sober Men begin much to doubt the Truth of it. I have spoken with seve∣ral Officers of Quality of our Side, prudent, well-temper'd Men, that were in the Battle, these say they believe we had a Victory, because our Ge∣nerals tell them so, otherwise they see no Foun∣dation for it. That if we had a Victory, it was
managed to our eternal Dishonour, because, the Battel continuing 'till Midnight, we did not stay 'till the Morning, but marched off from the Place of Battel before Day, without Sound of Trum∣pet or Drum beating, leaving not only our dead and wounded Men upon the Field, but the Pil∣lage of the Field to the French, who came early again on Sunday Morning upon the Place of Bat∣tel, had the Pillage of the Field, and continued there to carry off their dead and wounded Men, wherein two hundred Waggons were employed all that Day; whilst our Men were left wounded and dying without Assistance, to the great Scan∣dal of our old Generals, it being not only an O∣mission of Consequence in point of Conduct and Reputation, but also in point of Humanity, to leave such Numbers of poor wounded Creatures to the Mercy of our Enemies, whilst we cry'd up our selves victorious. But the truth is, our Ge∣nerals (being most wounded, or perfectly tired out with that Days Action) considered not what was fit to be done till they had marched a League from the Place of Battel, and then it was not thought Prudence to march back to hazard our Armies. The Fault of this, and some other Mis∣carriages that Day, are said to be laid to Mon∣sieur Louvignies Charge, against whom his High∣ness the Prince of Orange was so much inraged, that we are informed he told him, That the King of France was more obliged to him in this Battle than the King of Spain. And that which makes us the more credit this Relation, is, that Mon∣sieur Louvignies is come hither two Days since, in great Trouble ana Discontent. It is acknowledg∣ed by all Persons, that the Courage and Conduct of the Prince of Orange was that day to be ad∣mir'd,
who flew from one part of the Field to another, not only to encourage his Men, but from the first to the last of the several Engagements, and in the Heat of every Attack, was the fore∣most, and has thereby gain'd immortal Honour. It's said also, that Monsieur le Prince never de∣signed any Battle with greater Skill, nor managed it with more Conduct; and that when all Parti∣culars shall be fully known, this will be esteem'd one of the greatest and bravest Actions of his Life.

The Relations which I herewith send, are the best and most pertinent of any come to my Hands, and the truest to so much as they relate; it being impossible for any (though upon the Place) to give an exact Relation of all Particu∣lars, because they were attacked in so many se∣veral Places. By the next Post I hope to send your Lordship a very particular Account as to the Loss of the Spanish Side, though I presume your Honour will receive a much better by the inclosed from Sir Gabriel Sylvius, being upon the Place, than any other can give. I have understood by several Holland Officers, who came hither to recruit them∣selves after their Loss, that they really believe their Army is lessened ten thousand Men by this Engagement, in those that are killed, wounded, taken, and run away; thirty five or six kill'd in some Companies, besides the wounded, and twenty four or five in the least, which made them very angry last Night when the Guns went off for the Victory, and said they did really believe the Prince of Orange would hardly give the States an Account of so great a Victory as we made it here.

Our Armies are at present encamped near Mons, his Excellency with our Spanish Troops at St. Symphosion, the Imperialists nearer to Binch, and the Prince of Orange's near him on the other Hand. All our Armies being now together en∣camped in Battalia, in open Campaign, upon the Plains near Binch, ready upon the first Allarm to draw to Battel. All our Spanish Troops that can be spared are drawn out of our several Gar∣risons in Hainault, and we have now a conside∣rable Body of our own Foot together. On Wednesday Night Lieutenant General Agourto went out with three thousand Horse and two thousand Foot, but upon what Design is not known. It is most certain that our Armies will suddenly attempt something of Moment; and as I was told, by a considerable Hand in great Con∣fidence, Douay is the Place designed to be besie∣ged, both in regard of the great Consequence of the Place, of the great Supplies we shall have of Provisions from Valenchiennes and those Parts, and that the French will find but one way to relieve it by the way of Arras, where they must come in an open Campaign, whereby we may have a fair Battel, which is the only thing we desire. For if they should come by Valenchiennes, they will leave all our Garrisons behind them, and will be embarassed between the Rivers; if by Lisle they must defile with their Army. Our only Fe is, lest Monsieur le Prince should march directly hither, or relieve Grave, which Siege goes o bur slowly, notwithstanding the Arrival of th Confederate Troops; their Attacks not being much advanced, as my Letters of the 15 Instan speak. It seems Marquess Chamilli would yiel up the Place, as the Prince of Orange is inform'd
upon honourable Terms, but those will not be granted, but only to yield at Discretion; and thus it may prove a long Work, the Governor being resolved to have honourable Conditions, or to sell it at a dear rate.

This Morning early the Body of Sir Walter Vane was brought hither with a Convoy, accompany∣ed by his Nephew and some other English Gentle∣men, and is at present in my Lodging, to be conveyed to the Hague and there interred. The Body of de Palm, Collonel of the Marine Regi∣ment, is also here, to go to the same Place. Their Deaths are both much lamented, and his High∣ness was pleas'd to express a very lively Sense of the Loss of so worthy and experienced a Com∣mander as he was; and when he was carry'd off the Field, the Prince came to the Waggon to comfort him.

It's said, the Prince of Orange, by an Officer Express, has sent an Account to the States Ge∣neral of the Numbers and Qualities of the Per∣ons kill'd and wounded in his Army, which will or be made publick here 'till the States have re∣ard it. Sir Walter Vane made his last Request Prince that his Lieutenant Collonel Lil∣ might have the Regiment, which is will be granted.

The Loss amongst our Spaniards is very consi∣: our Cavalry did not answer Expectati∣, nor indeed any of the Horse in our Armies, was the Loss of so many of our Officers, were forced to stand the Shock themselves tead of their Soldiers, who never made one Charge all Day. It's said that Count de will execute the Place of Master de Camp
General, till his Majesty's Pleasure be farther known; neither could there be a better Choice, he being esteemed the best Foot Commander in our Armies, and the best beloved. The Body of Marquess Assenlaer was sent by the Prince of Conde to his Excellency, and was Yesterday inter∣red with great Solemnity at Mons. Young Prince Maurice was wounded and taken Prisoner in the Head of his Regiment, but sent back by the Prince of Conde, as was also the Prince de Salm released, upon his Promise not to bear Arms a¦gainst France this Campaign.

General Souches's Son, with great Secrecy, an in Disguise like a Postillion, passed through her on Wednesday Night for Germany, making n stay, but changing Horses, and went for Louvai and so by the way of Ruremond.

This is the best Account I can give your Lor¦ship at present, and wherein I am defective, hope these inclosed Relations will supply▪ have nothing else to add, but to lay my sellf o a your Excellency's Feet, in the Quality of,

CLOSER.SIGNED: Your Honour's most humble, most obedient, and most intirely devoted Servan R.

POSTSCRIPT.P:
We have News here that three thousand H more are joind with Againt, and that he ¦bout
Tournay, and some say he has invested it, there being very few Men in it; but others think he only hovers there to put them in Apprehensi∣on, that they may send some Forces from Douay thither, and so clap before that Place.

'Tis said the Prince of Orange is highly incen∣sed against Louvignie, and that more especially, for being the Cause of the Loss of his Baggage, which it seems was particularly left under his Care; having sent his Excellency's a safe Way, and left the Prince's uncover'd from the Army; so that he is like to be quite out of Play, and disgrac'd.

DIV2.P:
SInce my last there has not much of Moment occur'd. We hear our Armies are removed hither from Mons. The Imperialists who have he Van were Yesterday encamped about Kieuraing, tween St. Ghislain and Conde, having laid a Bridge wr the Heyne, between Vaurelle and the Abbey t Crespin. The Prince of Orange, with his Ar∣, is encamped near St. Ghislain, and his Excel∣ with our Spanish Troops in the Rear, are arpd betwixt Mons and St. Ghislain, where stay in Expectation of a Convoy that is preparing, which must go very well guar∣d it may run a great Risk; for we hear is a considerable Body of French lying in o intercept it, and therefore two of the
Spanish Regiments here have Orders to march with it, and some Hollanders are coming hither in their Place, but are not yet arrived. Whe∣ther the Spanish Regiments of Spinoza and Mon∣talto shall march directly to the Camp, or return hither after their meeting with the Convoy that comes from the Army, I cannot say.

'Tis said the Prince of Conde being much an∣noy'd in his Camp, with the ill Scent occasion'd by the Number of dead Bodies and Horses, ha removed his Camp farther on that side Charlero toward Fleurus, being at present encamped betwee Gily and Chattelneau, upon the Sambre. Fou thousand of his Horse were Yesterday forragin towards Nivelle, and three Days since a Party French Horse came very near the Namur Port this Town, where they killed a Spanish Corp¦ral in the Suburbs, and took six Spaniards Pr¦soners.

We see daily the sad Effects of the late Batte but no Trophies of our Victory, many wound Officers of our Armies being brought hither fro Charleroy. On Saturday the young Count Doug of Sweden, a Captain in his Highness's Fo Guards, was brought from thence in a Litter, ¦ing dangerously wounded in his Thigh with Musket-Shot; there was then little Hopes of Life, but the great swelling in his Thigh be since assuaged, there is some Hopes he may cover.

Yesterday the Countess of Waldec came hi from Holland, in her way to Mons, to visit Husband, who is in a fair way of recovery of Wounds, which are three, in his Hand, in Thigh and Arm. The Prince of Conde sent then a Passeport for the Courtess, her Tra
Baggage, and for an Escorte of forty Horse, who went forward with her Yesterday after Dinner.

Lieutenant General Agourto continues still in his Post about St. Amand, to cut off all Communi∣cation betwixt Douay and Tournay; one of which Places, 'tis confidently said, we shall besiege, and the first most likely, because Tournay is surroun∣ded with so many French Garrisons, that we should be much incommoded as to our Convoys to the Camp. If we besiege Douay, we are not without Apprehensions that the Prince of Conde may take a Turn into these Parts, and if he should attack Malines and Vilvord, and take them, and pillage Louvain, which he may easily do, he would put us to a great Trouble in these Coun∣tries. There are some Thoughts that he may look towards Grave, but being so far off we can∣not believe he will abandon France whilst our Armies are so near it. We are told, how true I know not, that the King of France is very angry at the Prince's coming to a Battle, believing he might easily have retreated with the Baggage, af∣ter he had defeated the Rear of our Army, with∣out coming to any farther Engagement.

We hear from our Camp that the French ac∣knowledge to have lost eight thousand Men in the Battel, and that ours is inconsiderable to it; much undervaluing our own, but very dextrous n magfying our Enemies Losses; and though efre the Battl we would not acknowledge the Frnh aove thirty five thousand, yet now we ffirm them orty five thousand I was told a Majr the Holland Army, that Highness's Regimnt of Foo-Guards, the egments of Pince Maurice, the Duke of de Pal, , Lrdf and Vers
were very severely handled, that most of the Captains in his Highness's Guards were killed or taken Prisoners.

We are told also by some Officers, that are Prisoners in the Prince of Conde's Camp, that he highly complains against the barbarous Cruelty of the Germans, not only killing many Persons of Quality that begged their Lives, but several Officers after they were Prisoners, which was a Cruelty beyond that of Turks; that the Prince of Conde had written to General Souches concerning it, and bad no other Answer, but that his Men had been used to fight with Turks, and so could not leave that Custom.

We talk here, as if the greatest part of those Ger∣man Troops that are at the Siege of Grave should be ordered to march hither; but hearing nothing of that from Ruremond, I know not how to give credit to it. My Lord Castlehaven is still a Ruremond to his great Regret, being there altoge¦ther useless; and notwithstanding he has ofte sollicited to be drawn into the Campaign, a least to have leave to see the Siege of Grave yet neither will be allow'd him. His Lordship by his last of the 18th Instant, tells me tha Siege goes on but very slowly, their Attack not being much advanced, and that the Garriso makes many Sallies.

By an Officer of Quality come this Day fro our Army, we are told, That the greatest Di¦course in our Camp is concerning a Peace, a that the King of France will yield to the Pea of the Pyreneans, restoring all his Conque here to Spain, and the imperial Cities in Als to the Emperor, retaining only to himself t Franche Comte of Burgundy. And this Discou
is very warm both in Court and City, but I be∣lieve without any Foundation.

I have nothing else to add but what comes from Ratisbone to me, which I send here inclosed, and therefore shall end your Lordship's present Trouble, by laying my self low at your Honour's Feet, in the Quality of,

CLOSER.SIGNED: Your Honour's most humble, most obedient, and most entirely devoted Servant, R. B.

DIV2.P:
ON Monday in the Afternoon a Council of War was held by his Highness, with the se∣eral Generals of our Armies, at Mons, in the Lodgings of Count Waldec, whose Wounds will not permit him so suddenly to take the Field as was hoped; but the Prince of Lorrain was so well as o be at the Council, and begins to walk abroad. The Result of this great Council is not made ublick, but our Armies still continue their Posts bout St. Ghislain and Kieuraing, without attempt¦g any thing, and are not like to advance till his ighness's Army be recruited with several Neces∣ries they want, which were lost in the late Bat∣l, and particularly with a great Sum of Mo∣ney
coming from the States, which is not yet arrived here; neither durst our Convoy stir from hence, being advertised that Six thousand French Horse were roving about Nivelle, waiting to in∣tercept it: And Yesterday Morning about Two our Scouts brought word that a great Body of French Horse were marching within three Leagues of this Place; which gave us so hot an Allarm, that in great Confusion we drew all our Waggons and Carriages, with our Horse-guard also within the Barriers of Andernech Port, where they still continue.

On Wednesday Night three Regiments of Dutch Infantry came from Ypres to Gaunt in their way hither, and 'tis said more are following; but we are not yet certain whether they shall march to the Army with the Convoy, or stay here, and the three Spanish Regiments go in their stead, who have receiv'd Orders to be ready to march upon the first notice. In the mean time our Armies lie still, do nothing but harrass the Country, and diminish daily more and more, the Flux raging much amongst them; of which yet there is not s much danger, as of the disagreeing Humours o our Generals, and of the particular Factions a¦mongst them, which increase more than the Diseases; and this was seen most evidently i their late Council of War, where, 'tis said, the broke up in Confusion, without coming to an Resolution, our late Victory having much incre¦sed our Differences amongst our Generals; an the Imperialists are now much blam'd for the Mi¦fortune that happen'd to us in the beginning of t Battel, because they march'd so far before t rest of the Army, without making any Halt, a took up their Quarters, and sent out their For¦gers
as being unconcern'd, whilst the other part of our Army was engag'd many Hours before they came to our Assistance. We hear this Day that great means have been used to reconcile Monsieur Louvigny to the Prince of Orange; and 'tis said that his Highness has forgiven all past Mis∣carriages, sed manet alta mente repostum.

This we have from very good Hands, with this farther, that his Highness and General Souches will not attempt any thing against the Enemy, whilst his Excellency continues in the Camp, who, if he had studied to promote the King of France's Interest, he could not have done it more effectu∣ally than by going into this Campaign; and the more he finds his Presence distastful to the Ge∣nerals, the more resolv'd he seems to stay; by which your Lordship may easily judge in how ill a Posture our Affairs stand; it being the Opinion of the most sober and unbiass'd Persons, that we shall do as little by Land, as the Dutch Fleet have done by Sea, for the Season of the Year changes apace; and whatever we pretend as to besieging any Place, there is little appearance of it, whilst Monsieur le Prince has so considerable an Army in the Field; who, if he be not able to raise the Siege, will at least hinder all Convoys to our Armies, and by that means put us in a worse Condition than the Besieged: And for our making a Winter War, which we say is the Ger∣mans Trade, there is less Appearance how that can be done, since our Armies can scarce find Subsistence in the Summer; neither can I ima∣gine, as far as I am able to judge, where our Armies can take up their Winter-Quarters; I am sure these Provinces are not able to maintain them: And if we cannot carry the War so far
from hence, as to take some such considerable Posts within the French Territories, as may se∣cure a Subsistence to our Armies in those Parts this Winter, I believe the disinteressed Part of the World will then conclude, that the great Charges we and our Allies have been at to carry on this War, will hardly quit Costs; and that his Excel∣lency, the Primum mobile of this War, and his Ministers who advised it, have taken very wrong Measures.

Since the Arrival of our last Orders from Spain, our Discourses are all for Peace, which that Court, as we are told, seems much inclin'd to, by the urgent Interposition of his Majesty, as also by the present Posture of their own Affairs, which succeed not so prosperously as they ex∣pected: And we hear from the Camp, that Peace is more their Discourse than War, our Confede∣rates beginning to be weary of it, foreseeing the Difficulties that will daily grow upon them; and these Advertisements come from the best Hands in the Army.

I was this Day assured from Monsieur la Vil∣lette, one of the four Members of Flanders who came Yesterday from our Camp, and is a Man much intrusted and privy to their closest Coun∣cils, that we should make a Peace before this Winter's ended, there being no likelihood of our making any Advantage by the War; that the only Difficulty is their great Jealousie that the King of France will break it so soon as he finds Occasion. But their great Confidence in his Majesty's Care for the Preservation of these Pro∣vinces to the Crown of Spain; and his continual good Inclination towards them, do induce all the Members of these Provinces to submit to his
Majesty's Mediation with all imaginable Alacri∣ty, not doubting of a good, firm and lasting Peace thereby. I presume to give your Lordship this Account, because I find at this time private Deputies are come hither from all the Provinces, who cry out much for Peace, and labour to in∣duce all People to be of the same Sentiment, foreseeing nothing but an inevitable Ruin to their Country without it.

I have this Afternoon seen a Letter from the Duke of Bournovile, dated the 18th instant at Gersheim, near Mayence upon the Rhine, to the Deputy of the Province of Artois, wherein he says, That if the Victory against the French be so great as related, 'tis like to make a great change of Affairs: That the Marquis of Bade who was marching towards him with the Imperialists and Munster Troops, having receiv'd Orders to return and join again with General Souches, has there∣upon made a Halt, and will neither advance towards him, nor return hither till he receives new Orders, whereby he is wholly useless to him: That the Forces of Lunenburgh and the Con∣federate Princes were not then come up to him, but daily expected; so that he was then altoge∣ther without Infantry, which might encourage Monsieur Turenne to advance against him; and that if he should receive any Foil, it was not his Fault, he having done all he could to be ser∣viceable to the Empire; and that whatever ill Accident should happen in this Conjuncture, could not be imputed to him, who had so long waited the Conjunction of the Confederates: This I saw under his own Hand, and therefore I pre∣sume to give your Lordship this particular Rela∣tion it.

Several Parties of French Horse have been two Days since near Louvain, and have passed between that and Mechlyn, inforcing great Sums from the Villages to prevent their being burnt, and have likewise had their Engagements to send in Provi∣sions to Charleroy.

The Marquis Bergomeny that came from Bur∣gundy is for the present made Master de Camp General, till her Majesty's Pleasure be farther known. The Prince of Conde is marched Yester∣day with his Army on the other side of the Sambre, and is at present incamped at Anseureusse, waiting the Motions of our Armies, being ready either to pass the Sambre again at Manleux, to follow us if we bend towards Douay or Tournay, or else to march on the other side of the Sambre by us, in case we intend for France. The Duke of Holstein is kept Prisoner by the Prince of Conde, and will not be released upon his Parole, or any other Terms, being designed an Exchange for the Prince de Furstemburgh, they being both equal as Princes of the Empire and Colonels.

A Trumpet of the Prince of Conde's came this Day from Charleroy, with a Passport for the Countess Bucquoy to go to Namur, who assures us, that Monsieur Montall is past all danger of his Wounds, and that the Duke of Luxenburgh is not wounded: That the Prince of Conde conceives he had a great Victory against us, and that his most Christian Majesty has sent him particular Thanks for it.

I am this Day told from Ruremond, that the Letters from the Camp at Grave of the 21st in∣stant say, That there is no great Advance made in their Attacks; but that they had taken by Assault a Redoubt near the Meuse, and afterwards were
beaten out of it with small Resistance, pretending for their Excuse that they feared it was under∣mined.
I have nothing else to add, but laying my self low at your Honour's Feet, to subscribe my self with all imaginable Zeal and Duty,

CLOSER.SIGNED: Your Honour's most humble, most obedient, and most entirely devoted Servant, R. B.

DIV2.P: MOnsieur Beaumont Secretary to the States of Holland arrived here two Days since with a considerable um of Money for his Highness's Army; 'tis said One thousand Guilders will be given at present to each Company of Foot, and Two thousand to each Troop of Horse.

On Sunday Morning fifty Bylanders arrived here with five Dutch Regiments of Foot from Flanders; Yesterday came also the Regiment of l' Avergne from Malines, they are in the whole about Five thousand Men: This Day the Convoy is marched with them out of the Andernech Port, commanded by Major General Fario, who came hither early on Sunday Morning disguised as a common Troo∣per
in the Escort that came under the Prince of Conde's Pass with Sir Gabriel Sylvius and Monsieur Geldermaes (who was Deputy from the States-General with the Prince of Orange) both which departed Yesterday for Antwerp on their way to the Hague, from whence Sir Gabriel will hasten to your Lordship.

On Sunday Evening his Excellency very unex∣pectedly return'd hither, with all our Nobility that attended him this Campaign, with a Safe∣guard of Three thousand Spanish Horse comman∣ded by the Prince Vaudemont. 'Tis confidently said at Court, that his Excellency after he hath settled some Affairs of the Country, intends to return again to the Camp within a short time; and I am told in confidence, that either to mor∣row in the Evening, or on Thursday Morning, he goes for Antwerp, and from thence to Gaunt, which is kept very secret; and by the marching of some of our Troops that way which came with his Excellency, it's thought that either Oude∣nard or Courtray will be besieged.

Yesterday his Excellency caused the Horses of all the Waggons that could be found here to be arrested, and not suffer'd to depart, till the Con∣voy was sufficiently provided with Horses; neither is the Arrest as yet taken off. How far the Con∣voy goes this Night is not declared; but I presume they are only to draw together not far from the Town, and so put in order ready to march early in the Morning. All our Spanish Infantry, with the Horse that were here, have Orders to march, and some hundreds of Pioneers, and great quan∣tity of Ammunition; but upon what Design I am not yet able to say, farther than that we shall at∣tempt some Siege; for so I am inform'd from the
Camp, and from several good Hands here. The Prince of Curland came hither last Night in his way towards our Camp attended with a very handsom Train and Equipage, and is this Day gone with Major General Fario under the Con∣voy: His Regiment is at the Siege of Grave, which has only the Name of being besieged, very little or no Progress being made in it, as I under∣stood from one of his Gentlemen that came from thence.

Our Confederate Armies are at present incam∣ped between Kieuraing, Conde, and Valenciennes; and 'tis written from thence, that so soon as this Convoy arises, they will go upon some considera∣ble Action; the Money for his Highness's Army is also gone with this Convoy, under the Care of Monsieur Beaumont.

There is so great Scarcity of Forrage near our Camp, that the Forragers are fain to go every Day between three and four Leagues, where they are taken in great numbers by the French, besides those who take that Opportunity of deserting, which they do very much for want of Provisions, no Week passing without our Armies wanting Bread a Day or two, and Beer as thick as Puddle, at eight Stivers a Quart throughout the Camp, and very scarce to be had. Great Complaint is made by our Confederates, that since we have been so long preparing for this Campaign, there was not sufficient Magazines of Ammunition and Stores of Provisions laid up in the several Garrisons of Hainault, which we knew would be the Seat of War. But that to the hazard of our Convoys, to the unsufferable Fatigue of our Ca∣valry, and to the great Loss of Time, we are ne∣cessitated to have all our Convoys both for Am∣munition
and Provision from hence, never any War being laid upon so weak and tottering a Foundation. These and many other Particulars, wherein 'tis loudly said, his Excellency has fail'd, are the cause that he is very sharply censur'd by the Dutch Officers in general, (and also by our own) who stick not to make it their Table Discourse here, even within the Smell of the Court, affir∣ming, that if his Excellency returns again to the Army, there will be an end of the Campaign as to any Action; not one Day having pass'd whilst his Excellency was there, without some visible distaste or other betwixt his Excellency and some of the Generals: And that his Highness is resolv'd to attempt nothing, until his Excellency make good his Word, so far at least as to send Fifteen thousand Men into the Field.

Whilst his Excellency was in the Camp he pre∣tended to give the Counter-sign each Night, be∣cause the Prince gave the Word, which his High∣ness would by no means permit, to the great di∣staste of his Excellency; neither indeed is there any much better Correspondence between his High∣ness and General Souches, who seems unsatisfied that his Highness should carry all the Honour of this War; which certainly is far less than he me∣rit, it being an undoubted Truth, that if in the late Battel his Highness had not shew'd a most ex∣traordinary Courage and Conduct, our Armies had been all destroy'd And if a German Collo∣nel, who commanded some Battallions of Foot, ha not disensed with General Souhes's Orders, and immediately obey'd his Highness it would have been a faal Day to our Army: But the Col∣lonel seeing the Necessity of it, told his Highness though General Souches had given him Orders no
to quit that Station, yet he would for once diso∣bey him, and follow his Highness's Orders, who led them on so vigorously, that they repulsed the Switzers from that advantageous Post with great Loss, and thereby became Masters of our Artille∣ry, which otherwise had been lost. As to the gi∣ving your Lordship a true and exact Account of the Battel in all Particulars, I find it impossible to be done; the Relation in French which I sent by the last Orders as to the manner of the En∣gagement, is said to be the exactest we are like to see on this side.
