On Sunday Night I made it my business by way of Discourse to get the truest and amplest In∣formation I could from Monsieur Geldersmaes and Monsieur Wassenaer, as well as from Sir Gabriel Syl∣vius, of the present State and Condition of our Armies, both as to their Numbers, and Method taken in their Affairs, and of the Factions and Differences so prevalent amongst them; and they all agreed in this, that there was so ill a Cor∣respondence betwixt his Highness, and indeed all the Generals, and his Excellency, that there was a necessity for his Return. They told me farther, that Souches was not that great General he was esteemed; that he was no Observer of Martial Discipline, whereby his Army was like a Herd of wild Beasts; that he was old and doting, nd wholly lost his Memory; that he presently orgets what Orders he hath either given or re∣eived from his Highness. That General Spark a mere Brute without common Civility, almost umanity: That he may be a good Commander two or three thousand Horse for a Flying rmy; but that he has neither Temper nor Parts any degree proper for so great a Charge; and
they agreed in general that our whole Armies are in want of good Officers. That for the Germans, setting aside the Prince of Lorrain, Prince Pio, Count Lesley▪ Marquis Grana, and Monsieur Cha∣vigniack, there is not a good Officer amongst them; of which the last is the best in Esteem. That their Army is now between sixteen and seventeen thousand, the Prince of Orange's more than twenty thousand, the Spaniards between se∣ven and eight thousand; but now these Recruits going to the Prince's Army, and our Spanish Troops from hence, will make a good Addition. That his Highness was extremely mortified, to see Matters in general so ill managed, and so little Probability, through our own Faults, to to do any great Things this Campaign. That never any General more endeavour'd to put an Army in good Order, or took more Pains, or was more diligent in that great Station than his Highness, being so indefatigable in his Person, of so excellent a Temper, so valiant against his Enemies, and so obliging to his whole Army, that he is in general cried up for the most hopeful Prince living, and that he is like to be a greater General than any of his Ancestors.

The Prince of Conde with his Army lies en∣camped on the other side the Sambre, between Marchienne au Pont, Ham sur Hause, and Wal∣court, and so towards Philipville, the Van of his Army being near that Place. At Marchienne au Pont he has left a considerable Body of Horse and Foot for the Security of that Passage: That his Army has Plenty of all Provisions, lying at their Ease, and out of Danger, secured by the River and Woods, and is ready upon Occasio to follow our Motions, which he watches ver
diligently, having Parties continually skirting upon our Camp. He has released several of our Officers that were Prisoners, upon their Pa∣role not to bear Arms this Campaign; and has now no Prisoner of Quality of our Spanish Army, but the Duke of Holstein, the Count Me∣rode being two Days since dead of his Wounds, after his left Arm was cut off, to the great Re∣gret of his Excellency, as well as of his private Friends.

I send your Lordship here inclosed a particu∣lar Account, as precise as I can yet get it, of the Losses in the Prince of Orange's Army; but I expect to have it more large and exact: This I only send your Honour as a Taste till it comes more fully; but what is in this your Lordship may rely upon as Truth, for so I received it from Monsieur Geldermaes, Monsieur Wassenaer, and Sir Gabriel Sylvius together, and had it con∣firm'd to me also from the Camp.
I have nothing else to add, but throwing my self low at your Honour's Feet, to subscribe my self with all Zeal and Duty,

CLOSER.SIGNED: Your Honour's most humble, most obedient, and most entirely devoted Servant, R. B.

DIV2.P: I Suppose I can now give a particular Account of the Cause of the ill Correspondency which hath happen'd from the beginning of this Campaign between his Highness, General Souches, and his Excellency; which being related to me in Confi∣dence by a prime Minister here, I think it my Duty to represent to your Lordship, as I had it by way of Discourse; the Source of which Diffe∣rence began thus:

General Souches, at his Arrival with his Army upon the Borders of our Territories, made a great Demur upon passing the Meuse, hovering from one Place to another, occasion'd principally by his Instructions from the Emperor, that he should march to the Meuse for the Assistance of these Countries, acting what he thought convenient for the Advantage of the League, but not pass the Meuse without a pressing Necessity, which was lest to his own Discretion to judge of; howeve if the publick Exigency of Affairs required hi Passage, he was from that time of his Passag to govern himself and Army according to the Or¦ders he should receive from his Excellency. Th occasion'd General Souches to halt on the othe side of the River, and to keep himself there proposing to besiege Mazieris and Charleville that side the River, whilst his Highness and E¦cellency, with their Armies, should act on the side▪ and this was one great Point of th rence at their Interview at Landen. But ne was marching that way, and had made a H
with his Army to take in Dinant, News came from the Palatinate of the Defeat and Retreat of the Duke of Lorrain's and Bournovile's Troops, with Letters at the same time from the Elector to General Souches, to have part of his Troops sent immediately for the Succour of his Coun∣try, which the General refused without express Orders from the Emperor, which the Elector pressed home at Vienna, affirming, that in case part of those Troops did not return for his Suc∣cour, he should be inforced to make his Peace with France. On the other Hand, his Excellency by the Spanish Ambassador, used all imaginable Arts to hinder the dividing General Souches's Ar∣my, assuring his Imperial Majesty, and his Ele∣ctoral Highness, that the Luxenburgh Troops, to the Number of nine thousand Men, that were designed for these Low Countries, should march directly to the Palatinate, and would be there much sooner than the imperial Troops from hence. In fine, General Souches receiv'd Orders from his Imperial Majesty to send back part of his Troops under the Command of the Prince of Baden for Succour of the Palatinate, which he did accor∣dingly. Immediately whereupon his Excellency arther pressed General Souches to pass the Meuse, since there could be no thought of his doing a∣y good upon Mazieris and Charleville with his ingle Army, and withal that there was a Neces∣sity of a speedy Conjunction of their Armies. ut General Souches still held off upon his Reso∣ution of not being commanded by his Excellency, nd finding in his Instructions that he was equal∣ obliged to obey his Highness the Prince of O∣nge, he thereupon sent his Son to his Highness's uarters at Park near Louvain, to adjust that
Matter so, as if it could be agreed that his Ex∣cellency would promise not to come to the Ar∣my, nor pretend to command it, but leave the sole Disposition of it to his Highness and Gene∣ral Souches, that then he, the General, would be contented to pass the Meuse, and according to his Instructions obey the Prince of Orange. Upon this there was an Assurance given by his Excel∣lency that he would not come to the Army, whereby his Highness and General Souches were fully satisfyed, and a Probability of a very good Correspondence between them, and in order to it, General Souches resolv'd and prepar'd to pass the Meuse, and his Highness marched from Park to join his Army, which was no sooner done, but unexpectedly comes his Excellency from Brussels to Janch, where the Armies were, which so sur∣prized General Souches, that for some time he would not see him, making great Complaint of his coming to the Prince of Orange. Hereupon his Excellency sent the Marquess Burgomenie to General Souches, to let him know his coming was to hasten the advancing of their Armies, being now joined, having lost so much time already; with this farther, That his Excellency had notice from the Spanish Ambassador at Vienna, that Ge∣neral Souches had Orders to obey his Excellency. To this General Souches reply'd, That he would not have passed the Meuse but that his Excellency had promised not to come to the Army, nor pre¦tend to the Command of it; that for his part he had not spent so many Years in the War, an brought a veteran Army of that Strength int those Countries, to receive Orders from two suc young Generals as the Prince of Orange and h Excellency, whose Orders were like to interfe
every Day, and so his Army be bandied from one Place to another; that it was not for a General of his Age and Experience to be thus used, and that he would act no farther upon such Terms; but that for his Highness, he had his Instructions to obey him as well as his Excellency, and that his Highness being in the Head of a more power∣ful Army than the Emperor's, he was contented, and resolved to obey his Highness solely; and that for his Excellency, who had only brought three thousand Horse and Dragoons instead of twenty five thousand Men, he would have nothing to do with him in point of Command.

This Difference continued for some Days, which was increased by some Disputes of the same Na∣ture between his Highness and Excellency, who finding his Highness and General Souches both a∣greeing in the main Point, of outing his Ex∣cellency from any Pretence of Command; his Ex∣cellency thereupon declared that he would only continue with the Army in quality of a Volunteer 'till he saw more of his Troops join'd with them, which he did accordingly, but in that unsoldier-like manner, that by his feasting and entertain∣ing the German Ladies, he put the Army much out of Order, many of the principal Officers in Complaisance being at his Balls, when they should have been at their Posts, being so near an Enemy, to the so great distaste both of his Highness and Ge∣neral Souches, that they resolved to attempt no∣thing whilst he continued with them.

In this Interval happen'd the late Bittel, whilst his Excellency was gone towards Mons with a ve∣ry considerable part of his own Troops, merely for his Guard, when there was no Danger; which Troops and Dragoons, had they been present,
might have made a great Alteration in that Days Service; and notwithstanding his Excellency was so near all the time of the Battel, that he might have cme in with all those Troops much to our Advantage, and much sooner than the Germans, yet he never did it, to our eternal Reproach in After Ages, when it shall be said so bloody a Bat∣tel was fought in the Heart of our Territories, by our Confederates engaged for our Interest, whilst the Governour of the Country, with a great part of the Spanish Troops, kept at a distance, and never came in to their Assistance, there being only some few Regiments of our Spanish Cavalry engaged, who deserted their Officers and refused to Chage; discouraged, we presume, by the Ab∣sence of their other Troops.

The Vader General, who was at that time with his Excellency, when he heard the first shooting, importun'd his Excellency to return to the Battel▪ affirming it to be an eternal Infamy to any Person that had Spanish Blood in his Veins to stand there discoursing of the Battel, whilst their Confederates were fighting for them, but Monsieur la Mtte was of another Opinion, to which his Excellency more willingly adhered.

I am also inform'd that the Duke de Villa Her∣msa publickly declared since the Battel, that he is in Honour engaged to serve this Campaign, but will never serve an Hour longer in the Qua∣lity he now is whilst this Governour continues And I am told from no ordinary Hands, Tha all these Circumstances, with many more too long fr a Letter, are represented with muc Sharpness, both to the Courts of Vienna and Ma¦drid, seconded by all the Generals of the Counts excepting only the Prince de Vademont. N
all these things considered, I presume your Lord∣ship will not much wonder at the ill Correspon∣dence amongst us, and that there is but small Appearance of our doing any great Matters this Campaign. And your Lordship will easily judge by the present State of things here, whether our Necessities will not urge us to a Peace, since little Redress is like to be by the Sword; for though at the first opening of the Campaign, by comparing our Forces with the Enemies, there was a seem∣ing Probability of doing great things, yet for ought I see hitherto the Remedy appears worse than he Disease, and our Necessities will be soon redoubled upon us; for we do not only want Treasure to maintain the Charges of the War, but even Subsistence for them that fight for us; so that those that assist us here, are growing so weary of it, that I am afraid they will hardly be drawn to continue it much longer.

We are in great Expectation of our next Let∣ters from Spain, it being the general Opinion a∣mongst the wisest sort here, that we shall sud∣denly see great Alterations in our Government, there having never been so universal a Dissatis∣faction amongst all our Officers Military and Civil, as well as amongst the People, many crying out, There can be no less than Treason in the ill Ma∣nagement of our Affairs; whilst the more Mode∣rate bewail the Miseries of our Country, occa∣sion'd (as they say) by the Weakness and Incapa∣cities of those that are at the Helm. Thus I have truly represented to your Lordship what has cme to me from a very good Hand, which I worthy your Honour's Knowledge, though the length of it might prove tedious.

I have nothing else to add, but humbly to desire your Lordship's favourable Assistance and Aid, that my Care how to subsist may not hinder the only Care I have how to be serviceable to your Lord∣ship in this kind; and I do most humbly assure your Lordship, that if Necessity forced me not, I should forbear moving this for many Respects, and therefore I hope your Lordship will par∣don this Rudeness of mine, who am by all man∣ner of Title obliged to be with all imaginable Zeal and Duty,

CLOSER.SIGNED: Your Honour's most humble, most obedient, and most intirely devoted Servant, R. B.

DIV2.P:
OUR Armies still continue in the same Post they were, with this only Difference, That the Imperialists are said to be fortifying their Cam, and particularly at the Abbey of Crespin, where they intend to continue to watch the Mo∣tion of the Prince of Conde, whilst the Prince of Oran with his Army shall besiege Journey, and his Excellency, as is said, with our Spanish Troops, shall at the same time besiege Odnard. These
are our general Discourses here, grounded upon the great Preparation his Excellency is making to draw his Troops together from all Parts, there being in the several Provinces at least fifteen thou∣sand Peasants summon'd in with their Arms, the greatest part of which are to be made use of as Pioneers. The most of our Forces are drawn from Air and St. Omer, and are gone for Ypre, whilst the Country Militia is drawn into those two Pla∣ces for their present Security, there being no E∣nemy like to attempt them.

On Saturday last all the Peasants from about Louvain, Tirtlemont, Diest, and those Parts, with their Proportions of Waggons, came in hither, and are marched from hence towards Gaunt, all their Waggons being filled with Ammunition, Spades, Pick Axes, and all other Materials for a Siege. Those from Malines and Antwerp are like∣wise gone to Dermond, as also those from the Pay de Waes; and by this means the poor Country is so drained of their Inhabitants, that there are not lest sufficient to till their Land; so that the greatest part will lie waste this Year. A Famine in all Appearance being like to succeed this War, as well as Sickness, which has begun already in many of our Garrisons.

Yesterday seven Companies of the Prince de Bde's Regiment of Germans arriv'd at Louvain, and marched from thence to Malines, where they are to be transported with a Dutch Regiment towards Gm; his Excellency using all Diligence to get fifteen or sixteen thousand Men together out of hi Garrisons, besides his Troops already in Hat∣na, that he may no longer lie under the Cen∣sure of the Prince of Orange and General Souches, not having his alotted Number of Men accor∣ding
to his Agreement, the want of which they seem much to regret.

We hear the Imperialists have made great In∣cursions into France, committing all the barbarous Cruelties that could be expected from the worst of Enemies, not only burning all Places they could master, but killing all Persons they could find, without Exception of Age or Sex. That this last Week they went as far as St. Quintin, near which Place they took a Castle, after some Resistance, where some Persons of Quality were retired for their Security, whom they killed, vio∣lating all the Women, and then set Fire to it, and burnt it to the Ground. That for ten Leagues together there is neither Man, Woman, or Child to be seen in those Parts. These and many o∣ther the like sad Relations we have from the Camp, there being nothing else done but ruining the whole Country; and because we yet think we have not enough to do it effectually, we are told that fifteen thousand more Germans are co∣ming towards us, who perhaps may come time e∣nough to make this poor Country their Winter Quarters, which will this Year be entirely ruin'd.

To behold our Nobility and Gentry here is now really a sad Spectacle, they being become heartless, seeing no Appearance of any thing but Desolation to their Country, and that by those from whom they expected Relief. And as to our talking of Sieges, it's look'd upon by many as a Romance, since either we do not really in∣tend it, or else defer it too long; and truly, I am inlined to believe we shall do little or nothing this Campaign, the best Officers the Prince of O∣range has being still useless by their Wounds.

I am certainly inform'd that the Imperial Ar∣my is not at this present above fifteen thousand Combatants, and yet they will have the Continu∣ance of sixty thousand Rations of Bread each Day, of which there is already so great want in the Camp, that though they are in the best Pro∣vince of the Country yet they must be supply'd by a Convoy from hence; by which it may ea∣sily be judged in what Condition we are to be∣gin a Campaign in an Enemies Country, when our Armies cannot find Subsistence in that plenti∣ful Country by our own Garrisons.

There is certainly some evil Angel supervises our Affairs here, or else it were impossible things should be so strangely managed; and with all this, his Excellency seems no more concern'd, than if this Country were in the greatest Pro∣sperity; and nothing is buzz'd into our Ears by the Court-Flies but the present besieging two Pla∣ces at once, one being too little for their victo∣rious Armies; but if we make no quicker Progress with these Sieges than our Confederates do with their Siege of Grave, I am afraid we shall then make but a sad end of this Campaign. From which Camp I am told, by Letters of the 1st instant, that their Attacks go on as slowly as ever, and the Holland Resident said Yesterday, That 'till they had five thousand more Foot, there was little Expectation of doing much good upon it.

We hear from Charleroy, that Monsieur Mon∣talt is past all Danger, and so well recovered as to walk in his Chamber; his Troops rove much about the Country, and take great Boo∣y. On Saturday last a Party from thence took
all the Baggage of Marquess Conflans, going from thence after him to Namur, where he com∣mands at present, the Governor of that Place be∣ing so indisposed that he is unable to take Care of it.

The Prince of Conde with his Army is in∣camped on the other side the Sambre near Maubeux, waiting the Motions of our Armies. Some say he is reinforced with fresh Troops; but we will as little believe that, as that his most Christian Majesty is like to do any great Matters with his Arrierban, who, we say, will not pass out of their own Territories. So that we and our Allies shall have the Pleasure to destroy our own Country without the Assistance of our Enemies.
And if we can take two or three Places before the end of this Campaign, we shall then assured∣ly have the Substance of the late Victory, though the French have it, as yet, in Appearance.
I have nought else to add, but to throw my self low at your Lordship's Feet, in the Qua∣lity of,

CLOSER.SIGNED: Your Honour's most obedient, most humble, and most entirely devoted Servant, R. B

DIV2.P: EVer since I had the Honour to be known to your Lordship, you have been pleas'd to look down upon me with a favourable Eye; but your Honour has lately made this appear by great Effects, by so far advancing me in his Majesty's good Opinion, as to protect me by his Royal Hand in appropriating me to his Service, there∣by to secure me from that Danger of which I had no great Apprehensions, being so wholly concern'd in doing that Service imposed upon me by your Lordship, that I had not time to think whether I was in danger or not. However by your Lordship's Interposition and Favour, I am not only secured from any thing of that kind, but am also thereby inabled to have more full and ample Relations from the Fountain head, than before I gathered sometimes from broken Ci∣sterns. And I shall now use such Diligence to understand all Affairs both Military and Civil, that I will continually write what is done, ma∣king a Journal of all remarkable Passages here, which I presume will not be unsatisfactory to your Lordship.

The Patent bearing Date two Months since, I was necessitated to make his Excellency acquain∣ed wih it Yesterday, and to make my Excuse hat I did it not sooner, having been out of the untry since his Excellency's coming from the mpaign: His Excellency seem'd very well sa∣sfied with it, and told me, that upon any occa∣n of Address to him, he would readily comply
with what should be desired; and said, when my Lord Castlehaven came to Town, whom he had sent for, he would talk farther with me.

I have little left to say to your Lordship, being absolutely astonish'd with your Honour's Favours, I shall only hope your Lordship will have no rea∣son to repent your own Act in favouring me; and that as your Lordship has laid a Foundation, so you will please by preferring me still in your Honour's good Opinion to build me up to such a Capacity, that I may be more fit for your Lord∣ship's Service, to which I will bring a faithful and intire Devotion, which I can safely promise, and wish I may shew it with as good Proof as I can say it with Truth, being with all imaginable Zeal and Duty,

CLOSER.SIGNED: Your Honour's most humble, most obedient, and most intirely devoted Servant, R. B.

DIV2.P:
ON Tuesday Night Lieutenant General Agour∣to came hither from the Camp with Two thousand Horse and Five hundred Dragoons, who were that Night encamped without the Fanders Port; three Horse were commanded
out of each Troop, Spaniards, Germans and Dutch. Agourto was all that Night with his Excellency and Monsieur la Motte, till Five in the Morning that he was sent to his Troops to march with them to Asch in the way to Alost, where he had Orders to stay till Midnight to refresh his Men, and then to pursue his March according to his Instructions. That Evening about Six came an Express from the Camp to advertise his Excel∣lency, that the Duke de Villa Hermosa with the Spanish Troops had pass'd the River at Pont al Hayn the Day before, and that the Prince and General Souches had that Morning decamped, and jointly pass'd the River upon Bridges laid over for that purpose, having alter'd it seems their former Re∣solutions of dividing their Armies. Hereupon his Excellency forthwith dispatched Monsieur la Motte after Lieutenant General Agourto to hasten his March, and that from thence he should go to Dermond and Gaunt to hasten those Regiments, and to see the Boors put in order, and the Dutch Ves∣sels, with the great Guns, &c. to be drawn up towards Gaunt.

It seems the Armies are marched betwixt Aeth nd Tournay directly in the way towards Oude∣ard; but their Armies being all united, and so reat Forces going from all Garrisons in these Parts, makes many believe their Design is more onsiderable than the attacking Oudenard and Cour∣ay: Various Conjectures are made according to Men's Fancies; and it's whisper'd amongst some s if they intended to march directly towards unkirk, where they are least expected, and the rench worst provided; but this is only Surmise, d your Lordship must be content to be in the ark as to the Certainty of their Designs till the
next Post; though many do not stick to say, that Oudenard was this Morning invested.

Last Night three of our Spanish Regiments that were here, (viz.) Montalto's, Spinosa's and Bel∣videre's, had four Day's Bread given them, and this Morning they march'd early to the rendez∣vous without the Flanders Port, about half a League from hence, I rode out to take a view of them, which I did very carefully. The Regiment of Spnosa was about Nine hundred, Montalto Six hundred, and Belvidere Five hundred. The Boors were drawn up in six Battallions, and were inten∣ded for Five hundred in each Battallion, but wan∣ted of that number. There was Four hundred Waggons upon the King's Account, besides those that march'd with the Regiments, and belong'd to the Officers, and two great Mortars, but no Cannon; great store of Granades, and all Mate∣rials for a Siege; they march'd directly towards Alost, and I believe will this Night encamp about . The Marquis d' Ossera march'd with them and cmmands all in chief: I am told that th Regiment of Aldade, the Duke d' Avery, Copeny Duffey and a German Regiment, with about Fou thousand Boors are to meet them to morrow a Alost, and the next Day some more from Gaunt There was not one Troop of Horse that march with them this Day.

By Letters from Valenchiennes of the 12th i¦stant I am told, that before the Armies decamp from hence the Regiment of Boumont consisti of Tee hundred effective Men was sent Ca upon the Arrival of which six Com m of the Regiment of Molambeck were fm thence to Boucham, and that six Compa of he Count de Sore's Regiment were sent
Valenchiennes to Conde for reinforcing their Garri∣sons, lest the Prince of Conde in the absence of the Armies should attack any of them: That the Prince of Conde was not then moved, but conti∣nued in his Station upon the Sambre: That the same Morning old Prince Maurice was brought in sick from the Camp to Valenchiennes, not being able to march with the Army.

Our German Letters say, that the Brandenburgh Troops are marching this way, bending their Course towards the Meuse; and that upon their arrival there, his Electoral Highness will consider what is fit to be farther done in order to the ge∣neral Interest of the Confederates; and 'tis said after the taking Grave, which 'tis suppos'd will be within few Days, that that Army shall attend about those Quarters to join the Electoral Troops, and either sit down before Maestricht, or march towards France on the other side the Maese. They seeming now on all sides resolv'd to attack France, and to make a Winter-War against them, with their numerous Armies; but which way they will get Provisions in Winter in an Enemy's Country, when they can scarce subsist in the Summer a∣mongst their Friends I do not well see. And to prevent their Subsistence in the French Conquests, strict Orders have been some time since sent from the French Garrisons to all the Towns and Villa∣ges round, to send in all their Provisions of Corn nd Forrage into the next adjacent French Garri∣sons, reserving only for their present Subsistence; upon Penalty of having all that remains burnt; prosecution of which the Marquis d' Ancre Governour of Aeth has caused the Towns of Les∣s and Chieure, with the rich Abby of Chambre, burnt to the Ground, because the Boors had
carried in great Stores of Corn thither, and not into his Garrison according to his Orders.

At Tournay they are very apprehensive of a Siege, and have therefore published strict Orders, requi∣ring all Burghers upon Pain of Death not to stir out of their Houses in case of a Siege; and that their Wives and Maid-Servants shall have liberty each Day to go out for two Hours to buy Provi∣sions and Necessaries for their Families, but not to be out any longer.

At Courtray, it's said, the Governour and In∣tendant have proffer'd to quit that Town, if the Burghers would give such a considerable Sum as they demanded, but that the Magistrates abso∣lutely refused to make any such Agreement. It's generally reported that Oudenard is very well mann'd, and wants nothing necessary for a Siege; but it's said here 'tis impossible to keep it, the Hill that is near it commanding it intirely on that side.

By a Gentleman come this Night hither from the Siege of Grave, which he left three Day since, I am inform'd, that he thought it not i any great likelihood of being so suddenly take as is here spoken. He left my Lord Castlehave upon his March with two Regiments of Spani Horse, and a German new raised Regiment Foot coming this way, and that he would be th Night at Malines in order to his coming hith that Regiment being design'd for Security of th Place, with Monsieur de Fue's Regiment of Hor It was whisper'd Yesterday and this Day at Cou that de Ruiter has been repulsed at Martinico the French with great Loss. Young Count H passed by here Yesterday in great haste from H¦land to the Camp.
I have nothing else to add, but humbly to subscribe my self with all imaginable Zeal and Duty,

CLOSER.SIGNED: Your Lordship's most humble, most obedient, and most entirely devoted Servant, R. B.

DIV2.P: WE are informed by my Lord Castlehaven, who came from the Camp before Grave on Wednesday last, that the Besiegers were then lodged at the Foot of the Glacis of the Counter∣scarp: That General Rabenhaut having but a small Army of Twelve thousand Men, thinks not fit to attack the Place by Force, to the hazard of his Army, the Place being very small, and many Men to defend it; and therefore he goes the surer though the longer way, and has now so closed it up, and has so strong a Line of Contravallation, that it is impossible either for Relief to enter, or the Besieged to sally.

That there are many Batteries against it, which play incessantly; and the Besieged have store or Cannon and Powder, are not backward in retur∣ing the Salutes of their Enemies, there being ore great Guns discharged daily than hath been
known in any Siege for these many Years. That the French are all lodged in their Works, but that the wet Weather will quickly force them in∣to the Town, and more prejudice them than the Dutch who are lodged upon drier Ground, and have abundance of all Provisions.

His Lordship says, there has been a great Over∣sight committed by the French, in not breaking down the great Dyke that was betwixt the Town and River, whereby the Besiegers could have made no Lodgment there without much Loss, who are now lodged there in much Security.

Sir Wliam Ballandine having lately brought over six Companies of Foot from Scotland to Bol∣duc, went on Tuesday last to pay his Respects to General Rabnhaut, and after that would in Cu∣riosity go down to the Meuse-side to see the Approaches and the Fort which the French had blown up and quitted, which he enter'd; and in his Return back he was kill'd with a Canon shot, which hit him in the back, took away the greatest Part of his Body▪ leaving his Head and Arms hanging by a little Skin; his Heart was sound intire some Paces from the Place; there was a Lieutenant also kiss'd with him; the remaining Part of his Body was taken up and convey'd to Blduc, and there interred.

This Afternoon another Gentleman is come from Gre, who lest it on Friday last, and says, the States had sent positive Orders to Gene∣ral Rbnhaut to make as quick a Dispatch of that Work as was possible; and that he should proeed with his Attacks more vigorously that he had done hitherto; and that the General was resolv'd to proceed accordingly, hoping to be Master of it in ten Days. But my Lord Castle¦haven
says, no Judgment can be made when the Town will be taken, it depending upon their Wants within, not the Force without; and that when he left it, the General himself thought he did a great Work, if he became Master of it in a Month's time; hoping by that time some one necessary thing would be wanting, which would enforce them to a Surrender.

The Prince of Orange, with the three Confede∣rate Armies, hath besieged Oudenard, and on Sun∣day opened their Trenches: The Duke de Villa Hermosa, with the Spaniards, is posted at the Abby of Enam, on that Side towards Gaunt; and 'tis said that Aldado, with the Spaniards, hath at∣tacked and taken a Redoubt: That the Prince of Orange's Army are posted on that side towards Courtray and Lille, and the Germans towards Aeth and Tournay, being encamped along the River from Potts to Oudenard. We are told, that it was resolv'd so soon as this Siege was form'd the Prince of Orange should with his Army besiege Courtray, the reducing of both which Places are esteem'd here to be only a Work of eight Days, and after that they would fall upon some more considera∣ble Siege: But the moving of the Prince of Conde has alter'd those Resolutions, and will cause their Armies to draw closer together, lest the Prince should take them again at the same Advantage. He pass'd the Sambre with his Army the 14th, and (as our Letters from Mons say) marched to Quesnoy, and from thence bended his March be∣twixt Bouchain and Valenciennes, passing the River at the Village of Denning, a League from Bou∣chain; that from thence he marched towards Doy, and pass'd that River at Pout de Rash▪ We will not believe here that he is above Twenty
five thousand Men, and those in very ill Condi∣tion; and that the Confederates will be able to keep their Siege, and fight him, their Armies being near Fifty thousand effective, besides the armed Peasants, and some Regiments of his Ex∣cellency's Infantry, who are sent to Ypre, Ayre, and St. Omer▪ to reinforce those Garrisons.

Ther an Express come this Afternoon from Monsieur de Motte to his Excellency, who left Gaunt at Ten this Morning: What News he has brought is kept very private, which makes us judge 'tis not very good. 'Tis said the French did Yesterday make a Sally, wherein they lost eighty Men, but no Loss named on our side. The Guns have play'd all Yesterday and this Day; but the great Guns from Gaunt were not arrived at the Camp▪ but will be there this Night. We are told the Prince of Conde is advancing apace towards the Confederates; and 'tis said, that this Night he will be encamped with his Army at Leure, betwixt Aeth and Tournay within five Leagues of Oudenard; but we expect a Confirmation of that by this Night's Post, before we give Credit to it; and if that prove true, his Army must be much stronger than we report it. We were in great Apprehensions of his taking a Turn this way▪ and have therefore kept two German Regiment: here, with one Spanish; and the new rais'd Regi¦ment of the Prince de Croye is at Malines, for Se¦curity of that Place; his Excellency was likewis prepar'd to go to Antwerp after his Lady, but no she is return'd hither.

I am told from a good Hand, that his Exce¦llency says, the Prince of Orange and Genera Souches do now as eagerly court him to come the Army, as they did before desire his Depa¦ture
That for his part, he will go no more to the Camp; that all his Employment is to be their Providore; that he has now sent them Bread and Meat for twenty Days for all their Armies; and that having furnished them with what they desi∣red both as to Men, Ammunition and Provisions, it shall be no more his Fault but theirs, if they proceed not vigorously, and make a great Ad∣vance into France, since he knows the Prince of Conde with all his Supplies will not be able to make Head against them. I am also told in con∣fidence from the same Person, that his Excellency talks much of his returning to Spain, and that he intends passing through England, and making a short stay there; and 'tis whisper'd that these last Letters from Spain have brought some Inti∣mation that he is like to be recalled.
The Queen Regent's Pleasure is not yet decla∣red as to a Master de Camp General; Marquis Burgomeny is much spoken of, and some say the Marquis d' Ossera General of the Artillery.

'Tis this Day said Count Megem is upon the Point of Death, and that the Prince Barbanson is preparing himself for that Government, the Re∣version whereof was given him by the Queen Re∣gent. Don Bernardo Salinas is made Serjeant Ge∣neral of Battel, and is to come hither this Winter in that Quality.
The young Count Douglas of Sweden that was brought hither from Charleroy, is dead of his Wounds, after having endured much Misery in their Endeavours to cure him.
We are told from Germany, that the Elector of Badenburgh is marching with his Troops towards Mz in Lorrain, by that way to enter France, and that Monsieur de Turenne is retreated towards Alaia.
I have nothing else to add, but laying my self low at your Lordship's Feet, do with all possible Humility assure your Honour that I am, and shall ever continue with all imaginable Zeal and Duty,

CLOSER.SIGNED: Your Honour's most humble, most obedient, and most intirely devoted Servant, R. B.

DIV2.P: IN pursuance of my Duty and your Commands, I am to give your Honour a particular Ac∣count concerning the Business of our Merchant's Ships at Ostend. On Saturday Monsieur Christine, whom his Excellency sent thither as Commissary to examine that Matter return'd, and on Sunday in the Evening gave his Excellency an Account. The Consul came with him, accompanied with two or three English Merchants in behalf of the rest. Yesterday I gave a Visit to Monsieur Chri∣stine to know from him how that Affair stood, which I judged necessary for the expediting of it, at least that I might have so much light from him, as might in able me to give your Honour a true State of that Business.

The Commissary told me he had examin'd the Matter, and taken full Information of it, but would not undertake of himself to judge it, there being so great Contests on both sides, those of Ostend pretending as much Right to detain the Ships, as the Merchants to have them releas'd. That he had given his Excellency a faithful Re∣lation of the whole, which his Excellency had again referred to the Council of State to adjust, and give their Opinions therein, and desir'd I would have Patience for some few Days, and the Business would be ended to his Majesty's Satisfa∣ction. I told him, that Delays herein would be the Ruin of his Majesty's Subjects that were con∣cern'd; and that if there were not a timely Sa∣tisfaction given, his Majesty would be necessita∣ted to take other Measures, and give his Subjects leave to right themselves; to which he reply'd, that I might rest confident there would be no such Occasion.

I then demanded what he had done concerning Bartelet and Johnson, those two insolent Privateers, who had committed that unheard of Outrage upon his Majesty's Ship the Wolwich Sloop; to which he told me, the first of them was Prisoner in Eng∣land, where his Majesty might do Justice upon him, and the other was Prisoner in France, which was all the Answer I had from him; and Mr. Lynch confirms to me, that they are both taken, and that he has given your Honour an Account of it.

Yesterday at Court the Burgomaster and Bai∣list of Ostend, with two more of their Magistrates came to me, and told me, they were impower'd from the Capers to hinder releasing the English Merchants Ships. We had a warm Discourse to∣gether, wherein they seem'd much incensed that
his Excellency had discharged the Flying Hare without their being heard, and said there was one thousand five hundred Seamen in Ostend ready to rise in Arms upon it, and to fall upon the En∣glish, but that they prevented them; that howe∣ver, one of them with a Knife had violently assaul∣ted one of that Ship, and had sorely wounded him in the Face, which they could not prevent. They told me farther, that in case his Excellency discharged the other English Vessels without their being heard, they would appeal to the Queen Regent; and enlarged very much what Certifica∣tions they had brought up to prove these Ships were lawful Prize, with many things of that kind. And I do find that they are highly recommended and seconded by the Governors of Ostend and Newport, who go Shares with them; and by this means have made many of the Great Ones here their Friends. And I understand from Antwerp, that they have Bills of Exchange there for twen∣ty thousand Guilders, to be disposed in Bribes, for making friends in this Business, which makes me doubt we shall find Delays, unless his Excel∣lency be farther quickened by Letters.

The Resident of Holland had this Day much Discourse with me concerning them, and shew'd me Copies of several sharp Letters written by the States to his Excellency upon the Detention of several of their Ships, and assures me that he has Orders from his Majesty to tell his Excellency, That if a timely Remedy be not put to their In∣solencies, they shall not only be necessitated to grant L of Reprizal, but to send four or five Men o War to block them up. If his Excel∣lency had appeared this Day we had both moved him in it, but to Morrow we intend to do it, o
which I shall give your Honour a farther Account by the next Orders.

Mr. Lynch has likewise promised me a Certifi∣cate of the Assault that was made upon the Ma∣ster of the Flying Hare, and of the Threats they have publish'd of cutting the Throat of the Con∣sul, and all the English that are there; insomuch that they are in Danger of their Lives for Pro∣secution of this Business, whereby your Honour may judge in what Condition his Majesty's Sub∣jects will be in, if these Violences be conniv'd at. I intend to morrow to give his Excellency a Memorial of it, and shall give your Honour an Account of what Answer I have.
Not having more at present to add, but hum∣bly to subscribe my self with all imaginable Duty,

CLOSER.SIGNED: Your Honour's most humble, most obedient, and most entirely devoted Servant, R.B.

POSTSCRIPT.P: I sent your Honour's Letters to Sir Thomas San∣dys by a Servant of mine, who has brought me back this inclosed Answer.

DIV2.P: HAving receiv'd Notice from my Brother, of your Honour's Voyage to Holland, and of your Commands that I should send your Lordship constant Advertisement of all Occurrences here; in Complyance of which, and of my Duty to your Honour, I presume to give this Trouble.

At present little can be expected from hence, the Prospect of this Theatre being much changed since the Armies removal from these Provinces. That which gives the most Occasion of Discourse here, is your Lordship's Journey into Holland, which his Excellency says he knows to be in or∣der to a Peace and Marriage, but he is well assu∣red their League is so firm and steady, that he presumes all Endeavours of that kind will be fruit∣less 'till after the next Campaign, and that he believes his Highness the Prince of Orange will not be induced to think of a Marriage 'till an honourable and lasting Peace be made, which cannot be reasonably expected in the broken Con∣dition their Affairs here now stand. However, the Grandees here are of Opinion they shall have a Peace, since they see the States inclined to it; and indeed, the Poverty which this Country is reduc'd to, join'd with the Experience of the ill Management of the War, has much mollified the Affections of the most warlike among them; so that there is great Hope this high and Christian Work of his Mediation may in due time have good Issue.

General Spork is still besieging Dinant, from whence we are every Hour in Expectation to hear of its surrender. The Burgomaster, with many of the principal Citizens, have sav'd themselves and are retired, some to Namur where they are imprisoned, some to Liege, and others to Philip∣ville. It is said here, that four hundred French are in the Castle, and that there is Plenty of both Provision and Ammunition, but that it is not for∣tifyed, depending only upon its Situation, which towards the Town is very strong, but on the Land side not. The Cannons shot very hard Monday and Tuesday, but not having been heard since Yesterday, many conclude it taken, and if so, it's said they intend in the next Place to reduce the Castle of Bouillon, and from thence, if they succeed, it's thought they will march towards Liege taking Advantage of their Commotion; and when they have taken these three Places, it will be near time to go to their Winter-Quarters, without advancing towards Triers as they say they will before they end their Campaign.

We hear that a Party sent out from the Gar∣risons of Ayre and St. Omer into Boulongnois, to raise Contribution, rencountred with four hun∣dred French belonging to Ardres, which the Spa∣nish Troops defeated, and brought in two hun∣dred Prisoners to St. Omer: This was warmly re∣ported here this Day at Court, but I think it needs a farther Confirmation.

The States of Flanders have not yet come to a Conclusion in Point of their Subsidies, two of the four Members are come hither to represent to his Excellency the Difficulties they find in it, and to take some farther Directions from his Excellency for adjusting that Matter; and 'till
that be finished, his Excellency will not go to Antwerp, nor press the States of this Province, 'till he sees a good Issue of that in Flanders.
Upon Sunday Morning Count d'Ursel, by his Excellency's Appointment, parted hence for Ma∣drid, attended with a handsom Train, and with twenty of his Excellency's Guards for a Convoy as far as Cambray.
Don Pedro Ronquillos is suddenly expected here, having receiv'd Orders to hasten his Journey, and be dispatched for England by his Excellency in a few Days after his Arrival here.

We are every Moment in Expectation of the Spanish Orders, by whom we shall know the Cer∣tainty either of his Excellency's Stay or Depar∣ture; many are of Opinion that he will sudden∣ly leave this Government, which he has much so∣licited, in hopes of being made one of the Great Council at Madrid. The Name of our new Ma∣ster de Camp General is also expected in these Letters, and who shall be Governor of the Pro∣vince of Namur, the Prince of Barbanson not be∣ing owned by his Excellency 'till he has receiv'd a new Confirmation from Spain.

This is all which is stirring as to the publick Affairs here, except the Business of our Ships at Ostend, which I likewise think my Duty to give your Lordship an Account of in this following Relation.

By a Letter of the 2d Instant, S. V. from Mr. Secretary Coventry, I receiv'd Commands to in∣form my self of his Excellency and chief Mini∣sters here, whether they made any Scruple of owning the Treaty of 67 at Madrid, which Com∣mand was occasion'd by an Advertisement I gave his Honour of what I heard the Audientiary say
concerning it, That it was a Peace never pub∣lished.

According to Mr. Secretary's Commands, on Sunday last, I address'd my self to his Excellen∣cy, and took Mr. Lynch the Consul with me to hear his Excellency's Answer. I told his Excel∣lency, that understanding the Papers and Process concerning the detaining our Ships being now come from Ostend hither, we had some Hopes of having an Issue of that Business which had been so long delayed, to the great Damage of His Ma∣jesty's Subjects, and consequently to his Majesty's no small Displeasure; that it was now seasona∣ble to have a Rule set by which all Parties were to govern themselves in this Affair, and that ac∣cordingly I had receiv'd Orders in His Majesty's Name to stick close to the Treaty of 67, which was to be the Rule in the Decision of this Busi∣ness. And that therefore I thought it necessary (for the gaining of Time, and preventing all Dis∣putes that might otherwise arise,) to desire his Excellency to send an Order to the High Court of Admiralty here, (who were to be Judges in this Business) to make that Treaty the Rule in the judging of these Ships, and that such Order from his Excellency might be registred, of which I might have an Authentick Copy to send to Mr. Secretary Coventry, for His Majesty's Satisfa∣ction, and for Discharge of my Duty. To this his Excellency answered, That the Papers were now me which he would transmit to the Admiralty, That he was very sorry the Business had been so long delayed, That he most confess those of O∣stend were the greatest Knaves in the World▪ and that he did verily believe, when he should have this Government, if they could catch him at Sea,
they would throw him over-board: And many more sharp Expressions he made against them. But, in fine, when he came to the Point of the Treaty, he told us, It was a Treaty they had ne∣ver seen or heard of, neither was it ever sent hi∣ther by the Queen, or any Orders about it; and that it was absolutely necessary that Letters should be forthwith written to our Ambassador at Ma∣drid, to procure the Queen's Order hither for their owning that Treaty, and governing themselves in all things accordingly, and said that he had al∣ready written to that purpose; that in the mean time the Business should go on, which was all he could do to put them in a way of Justice, and that if any Spanish Ships were taken in England they must be released by the ordinary Form of Justice. To this I reply'd, That I presum'd his Excellency was misinform'd in this Business, for that it would evidently appear that those of Ostend had taken notice of that Treaty of 67; for that most of the Ships that had been taken (as I was inform'd by the Consul there present) were taken by vertue of the fourteenth Article of that Trea∣ty, for want of Passeports as that Article direct∣ed; and if they made use of one Article for our Disadvantage, we had reason to expect Liberty to make use of the other Articles in our Favour; that if the Treaty was not sent hither, nor pub∣lished, it was the Fault of the Ministers at Ma¦drid, and could make nothing to the Prejudic of the Treaty which was ratifyed, nor to th Prejudice of his Majesty's Subjects who had tra¦ded to France under Security of that Treaty, an that therefore I was commanded to stick to the Treaty, and must pretend against all Proceeding in this Business that were contrary to it. Her
upon his Excellency told me, I had best to speak with those Ministers that were the proper Jud∣ges of this Matter, whereupon I went with Mr. Lynch the same Day to the President of the Coun∣cil, who was directly of the same Opinion as his Excellency, but said, he had not the proper Cognizance of it. But the President of the High Court of Admiralty, Monsieur Blondel, with whom we likewise discoursed the Matter, and desired to know by what Method he would pro∣ceed, and whether he would not make the Treaty of 67 the Rule? which he seem'd altogether in∣clin'd to, and said he knew of no other way to determine the Matter, and so soon as the Papers came to his Hands he would send them to two Counsellors to report, and when the Matter was ready we should have notice.

On Monday his Excellency sent the Papers to Monsieur Blondel, and he has chosen out four of the Process, and has given them to two Counsel∣lors to report; and upon their Report we shall know what farther Measures to take, and if I find they will not admit of the Treaty, I shall immediately dispatch an Express to Mr. Secreta∣ry to give him an Account of it, it being a Business of great Consequence, and that timely notice be given of it.

I knew not what Judgment to make of this as yet, but I am much afraid we shall meet with many Difficulties, the Capers having made great Interest by their Bribes, which they give out e Monies of his Majesty's Subjects, and are very free of other Mens Purses. I see them aily plying here several of the great Men and Favourites, and know they will leave no Stone nmov'd to carry away what they have gotten.
And I am assur'd by some of the Merchants here who are concern'd, that the Value of the several Ships and Lading, which they have now taken at Ostend, amount to sixteen hundred thou∣sand Guilders, and that they have sold the La∣ding of most of the Ships, and that the Charges the Merchants have been daily at, since their stopping at Ostend, comes to at least fifteen hun∣dred Guilders per Diem.

This is the full Account of what has passed, in relation to this Business, wherein I have per∣form'd my Duty with the greatest Care I could according to my weak Apprehensions, humbly submitting it to your Lordship's favourable Cen∣sure. And now having sufficiently wearied your Lordship with this tedious Relation, I shall end your present Trouble by throwing my self low at your Lordship's Feet, subscribing my self with all imaginable Zeal and Duty,

CLOSER.SIGNED: Your Honour's most humble, most obedient, and most intirely devoted Servant, R. B.

POSTSCRIPT.P: Since the writing of this the Spanish Courie is come, but the Letters not being yet delivered I am not able to give your Lordship any Account but I have desired Mr. Chaumont, who has alway an Account from thence, to send your Lordship an Account of what he has, which he has pro¦mis'd me to do.
Just now an Express is come from Dinant, who says they hold out very stiffly, which has so much enraged the Germans that it's believ'd they will give them no Quarter.

Since writing, and before closing my Letter, I have receiv'd this certain Advertisement, in Con∣fidence, from one that was this Day at the Coun∣cil of War, That his Excellency hears the Prince of Conde decamps to morrow; that it's believed he will march towards Tournay; that hereupon 'tis agreed the Van of the Prince of Orange's Ar∣my shall pass the Canal to morrow, betwixt Vilvord and Willibrook, and the whole Army to follow the next Day; that in Order hereunto, the Marquess d' Assenlaer, with Monsieur Louvig∣nies, and a French Marquess of the Prince of O∣range's Army, (I think Marquess Mompellie) have been out of Town two or three Leagues to find a convenient Place for incamping both Armies, his Highness's and ours, which they have done a∣bout three Leagues hence, about a League on the right Hand of Hall, between Aeth and Alost; that within three Days our Army shall likewise march, that we may both attend the Prince of Conde's Motion, whether it be towards Flanders or elsewhere. What Orders are gone to the Impe∣rialists I cannot learn, neither have we any cer∣tain Account where they are, or whether the Re∣cruits are all come to them, 'tis thought they at∣tend the Arrival of General Souches before they move farther.

DIV2.P: THE Spanish Ordinary which came on Thurs∣day Night brought nothing as to his Ex∣cellency's sudden leaving this Government, Don Juan of Austria being not yet resolv'd as to his coming. In the mean time, no Master de Camp General is named, as was expected, but it's said that if Don Juan come, the Duke de Villa Hermo∣sa shall have a Complement made him to be Go∣vernour of Arms, the better to induce his Stay, who has demanded his Conge of the Queen, but it is not yet granted. It's written privately, that the Queen has some Inclinations to make the Duke d' Arembergh Master de Camp General, whose Pulse has been felt therein, and 'tis said he will accept of the Charge, if offered. He is at present here, and that which gives much oc∣casion of Discourse, is his Excellency's making a very extraordinary Court to him, more than he has been seen to do to any Person whatsoever; and that which makes the more notice taken of it, is, because there was so very ill a Correspon∣dence lately between them. The Queen has not yet disposed of the Government of the Province of Namur, there being so many Pretenders to it that it is not known who will carry it.
It's said Count d'Ursel is in Election of be∣ing made Captain of the Guard of Archers, if the Place of the late Marquess Tirloon, and that that Charge will be confirm'd upon him a Madrid.

From the Confederate Armies near Strasburgh it's written, That Monsieur Turenne still conti∣nues his Camp, and that both Armies are watch∣ing each other, and that which can hold out lon∣gest is like to be Master of the Field.

On Friday his Excellency had notice, by Ex∣press, of the taking Dinant Town and Castle, which happen'd sooner than they could have i∣magined, and by an Accident they little expected. The Place being entred by fifty Spaniards who were only employ'd about taking a small part of the Suburbs, whilst the Germans were battering the Walls: And it seems those of the Garrison that were in the Suburbs being in some Disorder, two of the principal French Commanders came out of the Town to make good their Retreat into it, who being both killed in the Action, the French retired in great Disorder, and the Spaniards fol∣low'd so close, that immediately a Parley was sounded, and soon after both Town and Castle surrendred upon Capitulations that the French should march away with Bag and Baggage, &c. but all the Ligeois Prisoners of War, and the late Governor who surpriz'd it from the Germans.

It's said that General Spork has sent part of his Army towards Thuin, to try if he can reduce that strong Place, which would be of great Conse∣quence to the incommoding of Charleroy. 'Tis also said that he will next attempt Bouillon, and then advance towards Treves, unless the Commo∣tions at Liege may encourage his going that way. We do here confidently affirm that Treves is at least closely blocked up, if not formally besieged; though at the same time others say, That Mon∣sieur Turenne has sent thither two thousand five hundred Men, who are entred into it; which, if
true, the reducing that Place may prove a Work of Time; but if those Recruits are shut out, they make no question of reducing it suddenly. It is written also from Germany, that both Philipsburgh and ck are much streighten'd by the Post which the Confederates have taken round about them.

We talk here as if the French King had some Thoughts of coming e'er long to Nancy, to be near Alsace and Burgundy, and to be ready to assist Monsieur Turenne upon any Occasion; and that the Prince of Conde will at the same time come towards Douay, and those Parts; but we have no Cer∣tainty of this, but only Surmises.
Count de Rasch is by his Excellency appointed to go suddenly to Ypres to command there in the place of Baron de Rock, who comes hither, and shall command at Louvain.
Yesterday being his Excellency's Birth-day there was a great Solemnity at Court, which ended at Night in a Ball for the Divertisement of the Ladies.

Count Philip Bassigny has been very ill of a Fever, but is now pretty well; I gave him this Evening a Visit▪ and found him in his Bed, but much better than he was: His Brother Count Bas∣sgny who was with him, told me they had both intentions of kissing your Lordship's Hands in Holland before your Return, if his Brother's Health would permit. Count Philip told me your Lord∣ship was saely arriv'd, which I was very glad to hear, the Winds having been very stormy and con∣trary since your Lordship's Imbarcation.

This is all that has occurr'd here since my last, worth your Lordship's Knowledge, and I shall not fal to give your Honour a constant Account of
all Passages here whilst your Lordship continues in Holland.

As to the Business of our Ships, on Saturday the Lords of the Admiralty met upon it the first time, and have taken into Consideration the George of London, and the John of Yarmouth, which are two Ships of great Consideration, and both taken by virtue of the 14th Article of the Treaty of 1667 for want of Passports; and according as they shall determine upon those, we shall be able to give a Judgment of all the rest; but these Proceedings are so slow, that they dishearten all that follow the Business: The President tells me that the Business of these two Ships will take up their time for four or five Days; and I am told that they will not give a Judgment upon any, till they have heard all the Cases depending. Many of the Papers and Process are still behind at Ostend; but I have moved his Excellency there∣in, who has now sent an Express for all the rest. I have been with the President and the Counsel∣lors to desire their Dispatch of this Business, ur∣ging the great Consequence of it, and the prodi∣gious Charge our Merchants are at in their Prose∣cution, besides the Loss they must needs suffer in their perishable Goods, though their Ships should be deliver'd. They tell me that Satisfaction shall be given to the last Farthing, where their Seizure cannot be justified, and that no Business shall interfere till this be dispatched; of the daily Progress they make therein I shall not fail to give your Lordship a particular Account, and of whatever else may be worth your Honour's Notice.
At present I have nothing else to add, but humbly to subscribe my self with all imaginable Zeal and Duty,

CLOSER.SIGNED: Your Honour's most humble, most obedient, and most entirely devoted Servant, R. B.

DIV2.P:
HIS Excellency being much unsatisfied with the unusual Delays made by the States in Flanders concerning their Subsidies for the Year ensuing, has thereupon thought necessary for re∣moving all Difficulties, and bringing that Matter to a speedy Issue, which is of so great Conse∣quence for carrying on the War, to send for those States hither, and accordingly they are all expe∣cted here this Night. (viz.) two Abbots for the Ecclesiasticks, two Deputies for Bruges, two for the Free, two for Gaunt, and two for Ypres; and till these have adjusted their Proportions for Flan∣ders, all the other Provinces are at a stand. The true Reason of this their long Delay, is the great Povety that Province is really reduced to; so that when they have adjusted their Quota's, they
know not which way to raise the Money, this War having brought such Misery upon them, which has made them much inclinable to Peace, if an honourable one may be procur'd.

The Prince of Vaudemont goes in few Days for Spain, in relation to the Affairs of this Country as well as for his own particular Concerns, ha∣ving receiv'd a Passport from France for his free Passage.

We hear from Liege, that General Spork has sent thither to demand Quarter there for five Regi∣ments of his Army this Winter; and that unless they will admit it, he will endeavour to force them. It's said, that he has detached Three thou∣sand Men towards Treves, and that he will en∣deavour to reduce Bouillon and Thuin, the last of which will much incommode Charleroy; but we think it will not so easily be taken as Dinant. If he have Success in those Places, he will then make Incursions into the French Territories, and Winter-quarter upon their Borders.

His Excellency has this Day receiv'd Letters from Germany, by which he is assured that the greatest part of the Confederates Armies are mar∣ching towards Burgundy, thereby to oblige Mon∣sieur Turenne to decamp. By the same Letters his Excellency hath receiv'd some Advice in relation to Burgundy, with which he is much pleas'd, not doubting but that a considerable Design now in hand will suddenly take Effect, which will prove much to the Advantage of the Spanish Interest and their Allies.

There is nothing here more worthy your Lord∣ships Notice, but what the inclosed Paper will your Honour; and therefore I shall end your
present Trouble, by subscribing my self with all imaginable Duty and Observance.

CLOSER.SIGNED: Your Honour's most humble, most obedient, and most intirely devoted Servants, R. B.

POSTSCRIPT.P: The Business of our Ships continues in the same Posture, this first Process not being like to be ended this four or five Days.

DIV2.P:
ON Friday Morning being inform'd by Mr. Lynch the Consul, that he had the Night before been serv'd with an Order by the Court of Admi∣ralty here in the Case of the George of London; we thereupon went to consult with Council therein, who much wondring at the unusual Se∣verity thereof, advised I should that Day present a Memorial to his Excellency, which I did accor∣dingly, and took Mr. Lynch with me. I acquain∣ted his Excellency with the Strangeness of such Proceedings, that the Court of Admiralty by an interloury Order should appoint the Lading of a Ship of Ten thousand Pounds Value, being all Piece Goods, and no perishable Commodities to
be sold by the Capers without Caution, and be∣fore a definitive Sentence; and that neither the Parties concern'd, nor their Council had seen the Proofs, or any of their Proceedings, and there∣fore pray'd his Excellency would interpose his Authority for stopping the Sale not only of this, but of all other Ships belonging to any of his Majesty's Subjects, till a definitive Sentence had been given, and his Excellency consulted therein. And that for the Original Contract in this parti∣cular Case, of which they had an authentick Copy, we would engage it should be brought hither in fifteen Days, an Express being sent to Ostend for it. But in case upon sight of that Con∣tract the Process should go for the Owners, it would be impossible for them to have Restitution, if this Sale should be permitted, since it was well known at what Rates the Capers us'd to sell, and that no more could be answer'd than for what they sold.

His Excellency in his Answer was very short, and something quick, and told us, that their Pro∣ceedings here were no more unusual than ours in Engnd, for that there was at this time a Cap∣tain o Ostend Prisoner in England, without any legal Prcess▪ and when I told him it was for an unheard of Insolency committed upon one of his Majesty's Ships, his Excellency replyd, he should then have been sent back to him that he might hve punished him, which was all the Answer e could get: And this Morning I have received Answer to my Memorial, that I should ad∣dress my self to the Court of Admiralty, to whom e recommended it to do Justice, as it I could ot have done that without Recommendation. th as far I can reasonably judge, we are
not like to find any Justice amongst them, at least it will be attended with so long Delays and great Charges, that there will be little difference be∣twixt our Merchants giving up their Ships, and seeking Relief. It being a severe Truth, that the Capers have dispers'd so much Money to make an Interest here, that they account all the Ships they have taken as much their own, as if they were condemn'd already; and 'tis more than probable that those Papers are conceal'd which should make for the Owner's Advantage, otherwise we cannot imagine upon what ground they could make this Order, the Property of that Ship (as Mr. Lynch informs me) and the Lading being re∣ally prov'd to belong to English Merchants, and was taken going from Dover to Dunkirk; so that by the Proceedings of this we judge all the rest lost.

They are this Day begun upon Mr. Graunt's Ship that came from Tangier, and had in her be∣sides her rich Lading Forty thousand Pieces of Eight, and we make no question but they will likewise condemn her. I have sent Mr. Secretary Coventry a particular Account, to give his Ma∣jesty full and true Information, and am in ex∣pectation of receiving Orders from his Honour how I shall govern my self therein. In the Inte∣rim I conceiv'd it my Duty to give your Lord∣ship this Account, that your Honour may see how Affairs go here; and I have inclosed a Copy of the Order for the Sale of the Lading, though there is also a Mistake in the Original Order, naming the Ship St. Joseph for St. George; of which if Advantage can be taken it shall not be lost.

For News we have not much stirring: Gene∣ral Spork is at this time battering the Castle of Huy, which refuses to receive an Imperial Garri∣son; he has also put Garrisons into the Castles of Hautepene, Colonburgh, and other Castles round Liege, which gives a great Alarm to that City, fearing his coming thither after he hath reduc'd Huy.

This Morning the Prince of Vaudemont is gone for Madrid, and Baron de Bergeyk is hastning for England with all speed, and goes from hence this Week. His Excellency expresses a great Dissatis∣faction and Anger against Fonseca for some foolish Carriage of his in England, the Particulars he does not divulge; but he said to one in Confidence, that he had sent him a sharp Reprimand this last Post, and would be very cautious how he em∣ploy'd him for the future.
The Marquis Wargnie is made Governour of Bouchain, Marquis de Lede has his Regiment, and Monsieur Druhot the former Governour is made Governour of Ayre.

The last Week his Excellency sent two of the principal Magistrates of this City Prisoners to the Castle of Vilvord, for having done something in pursuance of their City-Privileges, contrary to what his Excellency had commanded, which is much resented by the Citizens; and 'tis said his Excellency will find the Effects of it, when he demands their Subsidies, which he intends to do so soon as the States of Flanders have agreed with him; in order to which the four Members of Flanders arrivd here last Night, and have this Day presented their Proposals to his Excellency in relation to their Subsidies.

On Wednesday his Excellency goes hence for some Days; but whether into Flanders, or first to Antwerp, I am not able to say. This Day a strict Placaert was issued, commanding all Officers of the Army upon a severe Penalty to quit this City within six Hours, and to repair immediately to their respective Charges and Garrisons, whereby 'tis judged his Excellency intends to take a Turn to view his Garrisons in Flanders.
I have nothing else to add, but humbly to subscribe my self with all imaginable Zeal and Duty,

CLOSER.SIGNED: Your Honour's most humble, most obedient, and most entirely devoted Servant, R. B.

DIV2.HEAD: En la Causse de Esti∣enne Lintz autho∣rizé par procure de Jean Kint, Jean Smitz, & Jaques Welenston Mar∣chands de Londres, Suppliant, par Re∣queste du Onsieme, May 1674. Contra les Armeurs du Capitain François Belten Defendans.
DIV2.P:
LE tout Veu apara∣vant fre dit n
definitive, le Conseil & Conseilliers entrevenant or∣donnement d' Office au sup∣pliant d' exhiber le Con∣tract de Vente du Navire nommè le St. Joseph en date du quinzieme Feb∣vrier dernier, dont faict mention la declaration que Maistre Rogier Crefort Merchand de Nieuport a fait par devant le Magi∣strat de la dite ville de Nieuport le second de Mars aussy dernier, & ce endeans quinze Jours de l' insinuation per emp∣turement, a paine de for∣clusion, & que droict ul∣terteurement serat faict, & sans prejudice de ce, e mesme Consel & Con∣illiers Intervenans accor∣dent aux defendeurs la escharge & vente provi∣sionelles des Marchandises n question selon stylle, reservant les despens en deffinitive, faict au Con∣ll supreme de l' Admi∣ute du Roy tenu a Bruxelles le 28 Novembre 1674. Signé

CLOSER.DATELINE: Copie de la Relation Insinuatio facta per me le 29. Novembre 1674. estoit soub∣signe A. Lombaerts.

DIV2.HEAD: In the Cause of Ste∣phen Lintz, autho∣rized by Letter of Attorney from John Kent, John Smith, and James Welen∣ston Merchants of London, Complai∣nant, by Petition of the 11th of May 1674. against the Owners of the Pri∣vateer of Capt. Fran∣çois Belten. Def.
DIV2.P:
HAving seen the whole Proceedings befor
giving a final Sentence, the Council and Coun∣sellers interposing, do or∣der the Complainant to exhibit the Bill of Sale of the Ship the St. Joseph, dated the 15th of Februa∣ry last past, whereof men∣tion is made in the De∣claration which Mr. Ro∣gier Crefort Merchant at Newport did make be∣fore the Magistrate of the said City of Newport the 2d of March also last past, and to do this with∣in fifteen days perempto∣rily after notice given, on Penalty of being fore∣closed, and final Sentence given thereupon; and this without prejudice hereto, the said Council and Counsellors interpo∣sing, give leave to the Defendants to unlade, and provisionally expose to Sale the Wares and Merchandises in Debate according to Custom, saving of Cost till Sen∣tence pronounced Done in the supreme Council of the Admiralty of the King, held at Brussels the
28th of November 1674. Signed

CLOSER.DATELINE: Copy of the Order. Notice then given by me the 29th of No∣vember 1674. un∣der-signed A. Lombaerts.

DIV2.P:
YEsterday Morning early his Excellency ac∣companied in his Coach with Marquis Bur∣gemenie and my Lord Castlehaven (his two Bosom-Favourites) went for Flanders, and lay last Night at Bever, two Leagues from Antwerp in the way to Gaunt, where they are this Night, and will be absent from hence till the middle of the next Week. The publick Occasion of his Excellency's Voyage is discours'd to be, to adjust the Matter of the Subsidies in that Province for the Year en∣suing, the four Members of Flanders being thi Day gone down after him. But the private Rea¦son is whisper'd to be some intended Design toward the French Conquests; and I am told in confidence
that the States of Flanders have privately represen∣ted to his Excellency, that the only way for them to give him Satisfaction in the Point of the Subsi∣dies, will be to fix a Quarter in Fuerns, which is an open Place left by the French; and by possessing of it will make an Addition of Four or five thou∣sand Rations daily, and will command Contribu∣tion to the Walls of Dunkirk and Winnoxberg; so that it is believed his Excellency will send some Troops to take Possession of it, and make it a Winter-quarter, and that he will not return from Flanders till that business be effected.

This Morning Count de Rasch went towards Flanders with the Troops that were here and in the adjacent Places, and the Troops in Louvain and those Quarters are march'd towards Liege to join with Monsieur Louvigny and the Imperialists, who are in great hopes of being suddenly Masters of the City and Cittadel of Lage, and of making the Cardinal of Baden Coadjutor to the Prince

It is written from that Army, that they have pos∣sessed all the Eminencies round about Lge and ve∣ry near to the Town, having taken all the Posts that are necessary to prevent any thing going in or out to them on both sides the Mu, and ve fixed a principal Quarter at the Charter house, that there are great Disorders in the , the Party of the Imperialists being ready to cut the Throats of the French Party, so that they doubt not but thee shall be receivd into the City, and re∣duce that Cittadel under the Emperor's Obedience, the Presence of the Cardinal having made great Alterations in the Affections of that People.

To morrow Morning Count Egmond goes hence for Flanders, being appointed Commissioner by his
Excellency, with some Commissaries for electing new Magistrates through all the Cities in Flan∣ders for the Year ensuing.

He has sent to Marquis d' Ancre at Aeth for a Passport, that they may not be put to any trou∣ble in their Voyage, which he expects this Night by a Trumpet, as does also Baron de Bergeyk, who is prepared to go for England, his Excellency ha∣ving sent to his Majesty to desire a Yacht for his Transportation; but the Weather has been so had, that we have four or five Packets lying at Newport, and we now want three from England:
The Marquis Ragi and Marquis Imperiali being very desirous to see England, do take the Advan∣tage of going over with Monsieur Bergeyk.
Our Letters from France give us an Account that the Chevalier de Rohan, Madam de Villars, the Chevalier de Preaux, and a School-master were beheaded the 27th past.

And we are told from Germany, that the Di∣visions amongst the Confederate Generals are in∣creased since the Retreat of Mareschal Turenne, and that the Elector of Brandenburgh has abso∣lutely refused to advance any farther with his Army, as was desired by some of the others, declaring he will not ruin his Army which he may have need of at home; which Resolution has not only hindred their following Mareschal Turenne, but also their advancing into Bur∣gundy.

The business of our Ships goes on as it did they condemning all that come before them: That Ship wherein was the Money that cam from Tangiers, they have not condemned, bu they have given an Order to the Master to a¦gree
with the Capers as well as he can; and if he does not, they will then give a Sentence in it. I have given a particular Account of all their Proceedings to Mr. Secretary Coventry, and am in daily Expectation of receiving some Directions therein. I did this Day discourse the thing with the Baron Bergeyk, who tells me his Excellency has yet given him no Orders concerning that Affair, but that he shall speak with him about it in Flanders.
We are this Night or to morrow in expecta∣tion of our Spanish Courier, and by the next I shall give your Lordship an Account what we receive from thence.
I have nothing else to add, but after laying my self low at your Honour's Feet humbly to subscribe my self with all possible Zeal and Duty,

CLOSER.SIGNED: Your Honour's most humble, most obedient, and most intirely devoted Servant, R. B.

DIV2.P: I Am to rectifie a Mistake in my last, of Count de Rasche's going for Flanders, he be∣ing sent to Guelders to take a Review of the Troops there and in Limburg, Monsieur Louvignie being appointed to do the like in Lutzenburg. Lieutenant General Agourto is gone to Hainault and Cambray upon the same Account, and Lieu∣tenant General Marco de Velasco is gone to St. O∣mers to review the Troops in Artois. His Excel∣lency will himself take a View of his Troops in Flanders, and the Duke de Villa Hermosa of this Province, whereby his Excellency may have a true Account in what Condition his Troops are, and be the better enabled to take his Measures for preparing against the next Campaign.

We hear from Flanders that his Excellency is still at Gaunt, not having yet accorded with the States for the next Year's Subsidies, wherein 'tis thought they will abate eight thousand Rations of what they paid the last Year. Before his Ex∣cellency's Return, 'tis said, he will take a turn to Ostend, to see in what Condition the great Work of the Sluce is, as also to see some Horses, a rich Coach, and a great Quantity of rich Hanging imbarked for Spain, which he is sending to th Queen Regent as a Present.

On Thursday Night the Spanish Ordinary arr¦ved here, by whose Letters there is no Appea¦ance of his Excellency's leaving this Governmen not of Don Juan's coming hither; that all the
Preparations in Spain, both by Land and Sea, are design'd for reducing of Messina, all that Affair being wholly remitted to the Care of Don Juan, who goes in Person into Italy Vicar General, and is to command all the King of Spain's Domini∣ons there and in Sicily, for the better carrying on the War against the rebellious Messineses; that there are no Preparations for any Supplies for these Provinces, nor any Master de Camp Ge∣neral named, nor any Governor for the Province of Namur, but that Monies will be remitted hi∣ther by Christmas.

The Duke of Arschott is fallen here dangerously sick of a continued violent burning Feaver, he hath been three times let Blood in the Arm, and the Feaver still continuing, he was this Morning let Blood in the Foot; the Feaver is accompany∣ed with a great Oppression of Flegm and Choler at his Stomach, and not without some ill Symp∣toms, which occasions frequent Consultations a∣mongst all the Doctors in Town.

Baron de Bergeyk has been something indispo∣sed these two Days, which has retarded his go∣ing for Flanders, but he now intends to depart to Morrow, and after receiving his Excellency's In∣structions to hasten to Ostend, in Expectation of meeting a Yatch for his Transportation, his Excel∣lency having written to his Majesty for one. We are here four Posts behind from England, and we are inform'd that both Packets were fourteen Days at Newport, and could not get our to Sea till Wednesday last.
