As for the Business of our secured Ships, the Court of Admiralty daily proceed here, and do now acknowledge the Articles of 67 as the Rule
to walk by, and do nothing in any Case before them without consulting those Articles.

There hath been two or three Ships condemn'd by them, occasion'd purely by the Confessions and Depositions of the Masters and Seamen, who ac∣knowledge their Bills of Lading to be false, and taken only pro formâ, and that their true Bills of Lading were sent over Land from Bourdeaux to Dun∣kirk, whither they were really bound.

The Master of the Ship that came from Tan∣ier has also compounded, fearing a Sentence a∣gainst him; most of his Mony and Lading being taken in at Cadiz upon French Account, and the Ship really belonging to a French Man at St. Ma∣lces, as he himself voluntarily confessed to the Ad∣miralty of Ostend.

I must not omit likewise to acquaint your Lordship, that upon a more narrow Enquiry we find there has been much Deceit used by the Ma∣sters of many of those Ships in question, that after they have been laded in France, they have made to the Downs for their Security, and from thence gotten Passports from the Mayor of Do∣vr, and thereby avoided paying his Majesty's Cu∣stoms; and then they have returned again to∣wards ance by vertue of such Passports. And so after having deceiv'd his Majesty of his right, then they procure his Letters in their Favour. This, I can assure your Honour, we find to be the Case of those Ships that have been hitherto qstion'd, their Bills of Lading being all to En∣ Ports, to which they never went, but after being in the Downs have returned back again to Frnc Ports, and so taken; which I conceive my self oblig'd to give your Lordship a true Ac∣count
of, having done the like to Mr. Secreta∣ry Coventry. However, there shall be nothing wanting on my part, either in Care, or diligent Application for their Discharge.

I have nothing more to add in this Particular, nor any thing else of News, but what the inclo∣sed Paper will inform, and therefore I shall end your Honour's farther Trouble, by subscribing my self with all imaginable Zeal and Duty,

CLOSER.SIGNED: Your Honour's most humble, most obedient, and most entirely devoted Servant, R. B.

DIV2.P: I Am told in Confidence, from a very good Hand, that this unusual Proceeding of his Excellency, in sending his Major Generals into the several Provinces, has given great Distasts to the Governours of those Provinces, and that the Duke of Arschot's Sickness was principally occa∣sion'd by a Disgust he took upon that Account, and some other ill Usage from his Excellency.

That the Night preceding his Excellency's go∣ing for Flanders he spake to the Duke to return to his Government, who gave him for Answer, That he would no more return thither, nor inter∣meddle in his Government, 'till he had Satisfa∣ction given him in Point of his Honour, and that the Privileges of his Government were restored to him; and that he had written to the Queen to know her Pleasure, whether he should have his Privileges made good to him, which were granted him by Patent from his Catholick Majesty; that he did not much value the Loss of his Estate in this War, which was but a small Sacrifice to his Majesty's Service, but that now his Reputation and Honour were at Stake, much dearer to him than his Life or Estate; and that if the Queen thought not fit to do him right in what he desi∣red, he would then serve his Majesty with a Pike in his Hand, but in no other Capacity; and that till he should receive her Majesty's Answer, he wou'd no return to, nor meddle in his Govern∣ment. This I am assur'd he spake, and much more, and that in his Letters to Spain he has min∣gled much Gll in his Ink.

Yesterday his Lady arrived almost drown'd in ears, and in the most disconsolate Condition i∣maginable, finding the Duke extremely ill, ha∣ving then receivd the last Rights of the Church, and made his Will in Presence of Duke de Vil Herma and many others, there being then little Hopes of his Life. The Dutchess brought with her a Dict t om Mans, who, being better ac¦quined with the Duke's Constitution than the Dras Doctors, prescrib'd him something las Nght, which had so good Operation that he rest¦ed
well, and though his Feaver still continues, yet there is this Day great Hopes of his Recovery, which much rejoices the Hearts of many, he be∣ing extremely beloved of all sorts, both Civil, Mi∣litary, and Religious, and his Death in this Con∣juncture would be an unvaluable Loss to this Country.

Monsieur la Motte has been also dangerously sick, but not so much griev'd for; he is now upon his Recovery, and Baron Bergeyk is so well that he resolves to go to Morrow to meet his Excel∣lency at Antwerp, hoping there to receive his Di∣spatches, that he may from thence go forward towards Ostend.

We hear from Luxemburgh, the Prince de Chimay is so much unsatisfied with Monsieur Louvignies coming thither, with a Power Inde∣pendent from his, that he is coming hither in great Discontent, and will not return to his Go∣vernment whilst the other stays there. The like is fear'd will be done by Prince Robeck in Artois, and Prince Mammy in Gueldres, which the Count de Rasch well foreseeing, offered to lay down his Commission to his Excellency, rather than go thither, affirming it would be to his Majesty's Disservice; however, his Excellency would hear no Excuse, but he must either go to Ruremond or Vilvord Castle.

Neither are the Governours of Provinces only dissatisfyed in this Particular, but also that his Excellency has placed Sur Intendants in each Province to beard the Governours, and are as Controllers upon them; they being never used in any of these Provinces but only in Flanders, where the Sur Intendant commands as Governour.

These are all the visible Preparations which are made here for this next Campaign, the Con∣sequence of which may be easily foreseen. And though they generally rail against Count de Horn, de Ruiter, and Van Trump, for doing nothing in their Behalf at Sea, yet they hope to be more vi∣gorously assisted the next Campaign by Land, by his Highness the Prince of Orange, upon whom all their Hopes depend; there being no talk of any Supplies from Spain, neither are they recrui∣ting their Troops nor making any Levies, whilst they find great Difficulty to pay those they have, and are this Year fallen two Months short of what they promis'd; but in the new Conquests we are told the French make all imaginable Prepa∣rations.

The Province of Flanders have at last agreed for their next Years Subsidies at fifteen thousand Rations, the one half of what his Excellency de∣manded, and eight thousand less than they gave last Year, declaring they know not where to raise this, and their Proposition of fixing a Quar∣ter at Fuerns, for increasing their Subsidies, was not accepted by his Excellency.

This Abatement in their Subsidies will be fol∣lowed by this Province, especially by this City, who seem much unsatisfy'd for Imprisonment of their Magistrates, which they are like to shew when Occasion serves.

It is whisper'd here very strongly, that though his Excellency leaves not this Government so soon as was expected, yet that he will be removed before the next Campaign, it being confidently reported the Duke de Villa Hermosa shall succeed him, at least for some time, and great Court
and Applications are already made to him upon that Account; and I am assur'd from a good Hand that there is more than ordinary ground for it, and that the principal Cause of Prince Vaudemont's Departure for Spain was to secure to himself the Charge of General of the Horse.

Duke de Montalto has made a step hither from Gaunt, whilst his Excellency has been there, not enduring the smell of the Court, and so soon as he hears his Excellency is at Antwerp, he will return to Gaunt.

Our Letters from Aix la Cbappelle tell us, that the Prince de Salm continues still very ill, with a Bruise he received by a Fall in his Coach; and the last Letters from Strasburgh say, the Con∣federates (notwithstanding they are in their Wn∣ter Quarters) have left eight thousand Men in their Camp near that City, which are releived each fifteen Days, that there is great fear lest the Duke de Hannover should joyn his Forces with the Swedes; but of all these Affairs 'tis needless to give your Lordship an Account, since it comes much earlier and truer to the Haue thn hither.

As to the Business of ¦miralty sit and condemn all Ships that they have hitherto question'd; those that are un∣doubtedly English Vessels, and their Lading not Couerband Goods, run the same Fortune with the rest, for they will hear nothing as to Proof on our pa and where there is the least Ap∣pearance of ud, by double Bills of Lading, or Contradiction n the Testimony of the Masters and Mariners, they never hear more, but condemn them to lose all, and to pay Cost and Charges.

Of all these Proceedings I have given particu∣lar Accounts to Mr. Secretary Coventry, but four or five of our Packets being staid at Newport till Thursday in the last Week; I have not yet re∣ceiv'd any farther Directions how to govern my self, which I hope to have this Night or to Mor∣row, we being now two Posts in Arrear, having received three on Tuesday Night.

I must not forget humbly to acknowledge the Honour of your Lordship's of the 24th past, S. V. for which I am to render all possible Thanks, and shall continue to pay my Duty of this kind till I shall receive your Lordship's Orders to the contrary. In the Interim I beg leave humbly to subscribe my self,

CLOSER.SIGNED: Your Honour's most humble, most obedient, and most entirely devoted Servant, R. B.

DIV2.P:
LAST Night his Excellency returned hither from Flanders, having stay'd two Days at Antwerp, and notwithstanding that Province would not be induced to give more than Fifteen thousand
Rations: Yet they have made his Excellency a considerable Present as to his own Particular of One hundred thousand Crowns, a great part of which his Excellency has disposed of at Antwerp in fine Pictures, Hangings and other Curiosities to send for Spain.

This Day the News was very warm at Court, that the Imperialists under the Command of Prince de Baden Dourlach to the number of Twelve thou∣sand Horse have entred Burgundy, whilst on the other hand the Duke of Lorrain has made a great Incursion into his own Territories, and that many have taken Arms with him: It's also written that Brisack is very much streighten'd, most of the Mills about the Town being destroy'd, and the Town so blocked up on all sides, with so many People in it, that they will suddenly be reduced to great Necessities.
Letters of a late Date from Luxenburgh tell us, the Prince de Chimay their Governour is fallen sud∣denly and dangerously ill of a Lethargy, but there was hopes of Recovery.

The Duke of Arschet is still alive, though not likely long to continue so. Yesterday his Brother the Prince of Arembergh came, but he knew him not; yet last night some knowledge came to him, and he rested pretty well, which gave some hopes to those about hm; but the Doctors despair of him, but say he may linger a day or two

Don Pedro Ronquillo has been upon his way hi∣ther since the 23d of the last Month, when he parted from Thorn intending to come by the way of Hamburgh, from thence to Amsterdam, and so hither in his way for England; but being like to make sme stay here before his going for England,
his Excellency is thereupon hastning the Baron Bergeyk, who came hither to me whilst I was writing this Letter, to tell me, that his Excellen∣cy has commanded his Departure to morrow Mor∣ning early, expecting the Yacht will be arrived at Ostend before him, Secretary Coventry having writ∣ten to me by the last Post that Orders were dis∣patched for a Yacht.

I am this Afternoon told by Letters from my Lord Clare and Mr. Meredith, that your Lordship is returning on Tuesday; and therefore I though not fit to lose this Opportunity of wishing you Lordship a more gentle Passage into England than you had out of it, and to subscribe my self wit all possible Zeal and Duty,

CLOSER.SIGNED: Your Honour's most humble, most obedient, and most entirely devoted Servant, R.
